revision.text:
{{Infobox professional wrestler |name = Cameron |image = Cameron Sep 2014.jpg |alt = |caption = Cameron in April 2014 |birthname = Ariane Nicole Andrew |names = Ariane
Ariane Andrew
Cameron
Cameron Lynn[http://www.wwe.com/inside/ecks-factor-2012-01-13 "Eck's Factor": Weekly Analysis for 1/13/12] |height = {{height|ft=5|in=6}}{{cite web|title=Cameron bio|url=http://www.wwe.com/superstars/cameron|publisher=[[WWE]]|accessdate=August 3, 2017}} |weight = {{convert|120|lb|kg|abbr=on}} |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1987|11|3|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Northridge, Los Angeles]], [[California]], United States |spouse = |alma_mater = [[California State University, Northridge]] |resides = [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]], United States |billed = [[Orlando, Florida]]
"Planet Funk"
Northridge, California{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/superstars/cameron|title=Cameron|website=[[WWE]]}} |trainer = [[Florida Championship Wrestling]]
[[Norman Smiley]]
[[Sara Del Rey]] |debut = July 7, 2011 |website = {{URL|www.ArianeAndrew.com}} }} '''Ariane Nicole Andrew'''{{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/c/cameron-lynn.html|title=OWW profile|publisher=Online World of Wrestling|accessdate=September 4, 2011}}[http://www.familytreelegends.com/records/calbirths?c=search&first=Ariane&last=Andrew&spelling=Exact&4_year=&4_month=0&4_day=0&5=&7=&SubmitSearch.x=77&SubmitSearch.y=19 California Birth Index] (born November 3, 1987){{cite web|url=http://www.fcwwrestling.info/cameronlynn1.html |title=FCW roster |accessdate=4 September 2011 |publisher=[[Florida Championship Wrestling]] |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502170855/http://www.fcwwrestling.info/cameronlynn1.html |archivedate=2 May 2012 |df= }} last is an [[Americans|American]] [[professional wrestling|professional wrestler]], [[actress]], [[singer]], [[Model (person)|model]] and [[dancer]] best known for her time in [[WWE]] under the [[ring name]] '''Cameron''' (shortened from '''Cameron Lynn'''). Under her real name, Ariane joined the 2011 season of ''[[WWE Tough Enough|Tough Enough]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.usanetwork.com/series/toughenough/theshow/characterprofiles/andrew/|title=Ariane Andrew – Meet the Contestants – WWE Tough Enough|accessdate=2011-04-04|publisher=[[USA Network]]}} where she was the first competitor eliminated. She later signed with WWE and joined [[Naomi (wrestler)|Naomi]] in forming [[The Funkadactyls]]. From July 2013 to March 2015, Andrew was featured as one of the main cast members of the [[reality television]] show ''[[Total Divas]]''. == Early life == Andrew was born and raised in [[Northridge, Los Angeles]], [[California]]. She graduated from [[Granada Hills Charter High School]], where she was active in [[Track and field|track]] and [[Cross country running|cross country]], and was a member of the school's drama club. She later graduated from [[California State University, Northridge]] with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[business marketing]] and a [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[psychology]]. After graduating, she moved to [[North Hollywood, California|North Hollywood]], where she worked as a [[Behavior therapy|behavior therapist]] for [[autistic]] children. She is of African American and Korean descent. == Professional wrestling career == === ''Tough Enough'' (2011) === In 2011, Andrew competed in a non-televised ''[[WWE Diva Search|Diva Search]]'' with [[WWE|World Wrestling Entertainment]] (WWE).{{cite web|title=Funky Divas: Bringing the WWE to Reality TV [INTERVIEW]|url=http://www.ebony.com/entertainment-culture/funky-divas-bringing-the-wwe-to-reality-tv-interview-987#.VXTBXE2TrIU}} Later that year, Andrew was one of fourteen contestants on the revival of ''[[WWE Tough Enough|Tough Enough]]'', where she was the first eliminated. === Florida Championship Wrestling (2011–2012) === Immediately after being eliminated from ''Tough Enough'', Andrew confirmed on her [[Twitter]] account that WWE had signed her to a contract. She was then assigned to WWE's then-[[Farm team|developmental territory]], [[Florida Championship Wrestling]] (FCW), and made her debut on July 7, 2011, as a [[ring announcer]] at an FCW [[house show]].{{cite web|url=http://www.diva-dirt.com/2011/07/08/another-tough-enough-contestant-debuts-in-wwe-developmental/|title=Another Tough Enough Contestant Debuts in WWE Developmental|date=2011-06-08|work=Diva Dirt|accessdate=2011-09-25}} On July 9, she made her in-ring debut, under the [[ring name]] Cameron Lynn, in a [[WWE Diva|Divas]] [[Professional wrestling battle royal|battle royal]], which consisted of [[Audrey Marie]], [[Caylee Turner]], [[Kaitlyn (wrestler)|Kaitlyn]], [[Maxine (wrestler)|Maxine]], [[Raquel Diaz]], Sonia, and [[Aksana (wrestler)|Aksana]], in which Lynn was eliminated first.{{cite web|url=http://www.diva-dirt.com/2011/07/11/fcw-live-event-notes-pictures-from-july-9th-arianes-in-ring-debut-divas-battle-royal/|title=FCW Live Event Notes & Pictures from July 9th: Ariane's In-Ring Debut, Divas Battle Royal|date=2011-06-11|work=Diva Dirt|accessdate=2011-09-25}} On the October 9, 2011, episode of ''[[FCW (TV series)|FCW TV]]'', she made her televised debut with [[Byron Saxton]], accompanying [[Naomi Knight]] to ringside during her match against Leah West, which Knight won. On the October 23 episode of ''FCW TV'', Lynn teamed with Knight in a winning effort against Caylee Turner and Kaitlyn. === The Funkadactyls (2012–2014) === {{Main|The Funkadactyls}} [[File:Funkasaurus and the Funkettes.jpg|thumb|left|Cameron (right) at the ring along [[Brodus Clay]], dance partner [[Naomi Knight|Naomi]], and [[Hornswoggle]] (front) in April 2012]] On the January 9, 2012 episode of ''[[WWE Raw|Raw]]'', she (billed simply as Cameron) made her WWE main roster debut as one of the dancers and [[Manager (professional wrestling)|valets]], along with [[Naomi (wrestler)|Naomi]], for the returning [[Brodus Clay]].{{cite web |last=Stephens |first=David |title=Raw Results - 1/9/12 |url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1326168590 |publisher=Wrestleview |accessdate=January 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113003830/http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1326168590 |archivedate=January 13, 2012 |df= }} She made her [[WrestleMania]] debut at [[WrestleMania XXVIII]] alongside Naomi in a segment with Clay.{{cite web|title=BRODUS CLAY CALLS HIS MOMMA: PHOTOS |url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/28/brodus-clay-momma-dance-photos |publisher=[[WWE]] |accessdate=17 December 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Cyfch8r5?url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/28/brodus-clay-momma-dance-photos |archivedate=17 December 2012 |quote=Accompanied by the beautiful Naomi and Cameron, The Funkasaurus, Brodus Clay, dances his way onto The Grandest Stage of Them All. |deadurl=yes |df= }} On the [[TLC: Tables, Ladders & Chairs (2012)|TLC: Tables, Ladders & Chairs]] pre-show on December 16, 2012, Cameron participated in her first televised match on the main roster, which was a "[[Santa Claus|Santa's]] Little Helpers" [[Battle royal (professional wrestling)|battle royal]] which was won by her fellow Funkadactyl Naomi, who would go on to face [[Eve Torres]] later that night for the [[WWE Divas Championship|Divas Championship]].{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=James|title=CALDWELL'S WWE TLC PPV RESULTS 12/16: Complete "virtual-time" coverage of final 2012 PPV - Cena vs. Ziggler main event, Shield makes a statement|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wweppvs/article_67280.shtml|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=17 December 2012}} On the February 6, 2013 episode of ''[[WWE Main Event|Main Event]]'', The Funkadactyls got into a backstage altercation with [[Tamina Snuka]] and [[Aksana (wrestler)|Aksana]], after Snuka and Aksana began to persuade Brodus Clay to fire The Funkadactyls and hire them as his backup dancers instead.{{cite web|last=Martin|first=Adam|title=WWE Main Event Results - 2/6/12 (Sheamus vs. Cody Rhodes)|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/wwe-news/39587-wwe-main-event-results-2-6-12-sheamus-vs-cody-rhodes|publisher=Wrestleview|accessdate=6 February 2013}} This led to Cameron and Naomi's first match as a team, in which they defeated Snuka and Aksana.{{cite web|last=Cupach|first=Michael|title=CUPACH'S WWE MAIN EVENT RESULTS 2/6: Rhodes Scholars in singles action, Tag Champs argue, Sheamus's Impersonation Night, Divas tag match (updated w/Box Score)|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwsuperstarsreport/article_68476.shtml#.UtXgx-3TnIU|publisher=PWTorch|accessdate=Feb 6, 2013}} On the March 15 episode of ''[[WWE SmackDown|SmackDown]]'', The Funkadactyls were attacked by the returning [[The Bella Twins|Bella Twins]] in a backstage segment. On the March 22 episode of ''SmackDown'' and March 25 episode of ''Raw'', The Funkadactyls attacked the twins after they interfered both times in [[Brodus Clay#Tons of Funk .282013.29|Tons of Funk]] (Brodus Clay and [[Matt Bloom|Tensai]])'s match against Team Rhodes Scholars ([[Cody Rhodes]] and [[Damien Sandow]]).{{cite web|title=PARKS' WWE SMACKDOWN REPORT 3/22: Ongoing "virtual time" coverage of the Friday night show, including Chris Jericho vs. Jack Swagger in a rematch from last week|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwesmackdownreport/article_69461.shtml}}{{cite web|last=Mike Tedesco|first=Mike|title=WWE RAW Results - 3/25/13 (Rock/Cena Q and A)|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/wwe-wrestling-results/wwe-raw-results/40536-wwe-raw-results-3-25-13-rock-cena-q-and-a|publisher=Wrestleview|accessdate=March 25, 2013}} The four women eventually faced off in a tag team match on the March 27 episode of ''Main Event'', where the Bella Twins emerged victorious when [[The Bella Twins|Nikki Bella]] pinned Naomi after an interference by Rhodes.{{cite web|last=Bowman|first=Clinton|title=WWE Main Event Results - 3/27/13 (Kane vs. Cesaro)|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/wwe-news/40578-wwe-main-event-results-3-27-13-kane-vs-cesaro|publisher=Wrestleview|accessdate=March 27, 2013}} Cameron and Naomi were set to team up with Brodus Clay and Tensai against Team Rhodes Scholars and the Bella Twins at [[WrestleMania 29]] in an [[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Mixed tag team match|eight-person mixed tag team match]], however the match was cancelled due to time restraints. The match instead took place the following night on ''Raw'', where Tons of Funk and The Funkadactyls emerged victorious.{{cite web|title=CALDWELL'S WWE RAW RESULTS 4/8: Complete "virtual-time" coverage of live Raw - WM29 fall-out, new World Champ, no Rock, Taker live, crowd takes over|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_69884.shtml}} [[File:Cameron Suplex.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Cameron wrestling [[Rosa Mendes]] at the [[WrestleMania XXX]] event in April 2014]] On the August 26 episode of ''Raw'', Cameron and Naomi accompanied [[Natalya Neidhart|Natalya]] to an unsuccessful singles match against [[Brie Bella]], until [[AJ Lee]] interrupted and ignited a feud on the cast of ''[[Total Divas]]'', criticizing them as undeserving.{{cite web|first=Anthony|last=Benigno|title=Brie Bella def. Natalya: Dropping her own version of her ex-paramour’s famous pipe bomb, the "Black Widow" administered a lethal dose of poison to her fellow Divas, whom she felt were gifted the opportunities she had to sacrifice for. "You’re all worthless excuses for women, and you will never be able to touch me, And that’s reality."|date=26 August 2013|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/2013-08-26/wwe-raw-results-26143822/page-5|publisher=[[WWE]]}} On the September 27 episode of ''Smackdown!'', Cameron was defeated by Lee in singles match.{{cite web|author=David Stephens|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/wwe-wrestling-results/wwe-smackdown-results/44064-wwe-smackdown-results-9-27-13-orton-vs-the-miz|title=WWE Smackdown Results - 9/27/13 (Orton vs. The Miz)|publisher=Wrestleview|date= 27 September 2013|accessdate= 27 September 2013}} Cameron joined Team "Total Divas" in a 7-on-7 [[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Elimination tag team matches|elimination tag-team match]] against Team "True Divas" ([[Alicia Fox]], [[Aksana (wrestler)|Aksana]], AJ Lee, [[Kaitlyn (wrestler)|Kaitlyn]], [[Rosa Mendes]], Tamina Snuka, and [[Summer Rae]]) at the [[Survivor Series (2013)|Survivor Series]] pay-per-view and the following night on ''Raw'' in a rematch; although Cameron was eliminated by Mendes in the former event and by Snuka in the latter, her team was ultimately victorious in both competitions.{{cite web|last=Johnson|first=Mike|title=COMPLETE WWE SURVIVOR SERIES BLOG, OR...DANIEL BRYAN IS SORELY MISSED IN THE MAIN EVENT PICTURE|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/81796/ongoing-wwe-survivor-series-blog-pregame-show-thoughts.html?p=1|publisher=PWInsider|accessdate=2013-11-24}}{{cite web|last=Trionfo|first=Richard|title=LIVE, ONGOING, WWE RAW REPORT: 14 DIVAS ELIMINATION MATCH TWICE IN TWO DAYS|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/81817/live-ongoing-wwe-raw-report-14-divas-elimination-match-twice-in-two-days.html?p=1|publisher=PWInsider|accessdate=2013-11-25}} On December 15 at the [[TLC: Tables, Ladders & Chairs (2013)|TLC: Tables, Ladders & Chairs]] pay-per-view, Cameron, along with fellow Funkadactyl Naomi and Tensai, abandoned Brodus Clay because of his attitude, effectively disbanding Tons of Funk.{{cite web|title=WWE TLC PPV Results - 12/15/13 (Unification Main Event)|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/wwe-news/45575-wwe-tlc-ppv-results-12-15-13-unification-main-event}} The following night on an episode of ''Raw'', Cameron and Naomi aligned themselves with [[Ron Killings|R-Truth]] and [[Xavier Woods]], and began accompanying them to their matches.{{cite web|first=James|last=Caldwell|title=CALDWELL'S WWE RAW RESULTS 12/16: Complete "virtual-time" coverage of live Raw following TLC - Orton vs. Bryan excellent main event, HBK surprise appearance, more |date=16 December 2013|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_75158.shtml#.UsNVgvRdVps|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}} In January 2014, The Funkadactyls began feuding with AJ Lee and her bodyguard Tamina Snuka, when Naomi received a [[Push (professional wrestling)|push]] and defeated Lee in various tag team matches on both ''Raw'' and ''SmackDown''.{{cite web|first=James|last=Caldwell|title=CALDWELL'S WWE RAW RESULTS 1/13: Complete "virtual-time" coverage of live Raw - Big show-closing angle involving Daniel Bryan, Hall of Fame, Rumble hype, more |date=13 January 2014|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_75656.shtml#.UtbRp_RdVps|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/2014-01-20/wwe-raw-results-26176775 |title=Raw live results: January 20, 2014|publisher=WWE.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/2014-01-20/wwe-raw-results-26176775 |title=Raw live results: January 20, 2014|publisher=WWE.com|date=2014-01-20|accessdate=2014-01-20}} However, their rivalry was cut shortly after Naomi suffered a [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Legit|legitimate]] eye injury during her match with Aksana on the February 3 episode of ''Raw''.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/2014-02-03/wwe-raw-results-26179509/page-10|title=Raw results: Outlaws survive the steel, The Shield & The Wyatts circle the wagons and Bryan de-fangs the Champion of Champions|publisher=WWE.com |date=2014-02-03|accessdate=2014-02-04}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/2014-02-10/naomi-injury-update-26179897|title=UPDATE: Naomi suffers eye injury on Raw|work=WWE}} On the February 10 episode of ''Raw'', Cameron pinned Aksana during a six-Diva tag team match,{{cite web|first=James|last=Cardwell|title=CALDWELL'S WWE RAW RESULTS 2/10: Complete "virtual-time" coverage of live Raw - Orton vs. Cena, Bryan follow-up, Henry returns, Betty White, U.S. Title match, more from L.A.|date=10 February 2014|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_76265.shtml#.Uv6s4Pl_tps|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}} and on the February 19 episode of ''Main Event'', Cameron defeated her in a singles match.{{cite web|first=James|last=Cardwell|title=CALDWELL'S WWE MAIN EVENT RESULTS 2/19: The Shield tries to one-up The Wyatts, Kofi vs. Axel, final PPV hype|date=19 February 2014|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwsuperstarsreport/article_76465.shtml#.UwZcG_l_tps|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}} On February 23 at [[Elimination Chamber (2014)|Elimination Chamber]], Cameron received her first shot at the Divas Championship, a match which she won by disqualification after Tamina Snuka accidentally hit a [[Professional wrestling attacks#Superkick|superkick]] on AJ Lee.{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=James|title=WWE E. CHAMBER PPV RESULTS 2/23 (Hour 2): Shield vs. Wyatts big six-man tag, Batista vs. Del Rio, Divas Title|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wweppvs/article_76567.shtml#.UwvSyfl_tps|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=February 23, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/ViewArticle.php?id=83779&p=2|title=COMPLETE WWE ELIMINATION CHAMBER COVERAGE|author=Johnson, Mike|website=PWInsider|date=June 2014}} Cameron received a rematch on the February 28 episode of ''SmackDown'', which she would lose. At [[WrestleMania XXX]], Cameron failed to capture the title in the "[[Vickie Guerrero]] Divas Championship Invitational" match, which was ultimately won by Lee.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/PPVReports/2014/04/06/21585306.html|title=CANOE -- SLAM! Sports - Wrestling - PPVReports: WrestleMania XXX brings the beginning and end of eras|work=canoe.com}} === Singles competition (2014–2016) === In June 2014, after the [[Payback (2014)|Payback]] pay-per-view, Cameron started a brief [[Feud (professional wrestling)|feud]] with new Divas Champion [[Paige (wrestler)|Paige]], in which Cameron would begin displaying signs of a [[Heel (professional wrestling)|villainous]] persona and would unsuccessfully challenge Paige in three non-title matches on ''[[WWE Superstars|Superstars]]''{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_78499.shtml|title=James's WWE Superstars report 6/5: Divas champ in action, Titus vs. Big E. main event, Overall Reax|author=James, Justin|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch|date=5 June 2014|accessdate=6 June 2014}} and ''Raw'',{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_79059.shtml|title=Caldwell's WWE Raw results 6/16: Complete "virtual-time" coverage of live Raw – Cena in main event, MITB title match set, Shield Explodes Week 3, more|author=Caldwell, James|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch|date=16 June 2014|accessdate=17 June 2014}} all of which Paige would win.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwsuperstarsreport/article_79080.shtml|title=Caldwell's WWE Main Event results 6/17: Sheamus & Usos vs. Wyatts main event, Rollins-Ambrose scrap, more|author=Caldwell, James|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch|date=17 June 2014|accessdate=18 June 2014}} Paige then lost to a non-title match to Cameron's [[The Funkadactyls|tag team partner]] [[Naomi Knight|Naomi]], who would get a shot at the Divas Championship at [[Money in the Bank (2014)|Money in the Bank]],{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wweppvs/article_79316.shtml|title=CALDWELL'S WWE MITB PPV RESULTS 6/29: Ongoing "virtual-time" coverage of WWE Title ladder match, MITB match, more|author=Caldwell, James|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch|date=29 June 2014|accessdate=30 June 2014}} after which The Funkadactyls began to fall out and had several disagreements during and after their matches.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_79338.shtml|title=Caldwell's WWE Raw Results 6/30: Ongoing "virtual-time" coverage of the Big Reset Raw post-Money in the Bank|author=Caldwell, James|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch|date=30 June 2014|accessdate=30 June 2014}} [[File:Cameron WrestleMania Axxess 2014 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|left|Cameron in 2014]] On the July 7 episode of ''Raw'', Cameron and Naomi were defeated by [[AJ Lee]] and Paige after Cameron tagged herself in and was pinned by Paige. After the match, Cameron and Naomi began brawling in and out of the ring, and as a result, Cameron cemented her villainous turn and the team was disbanded.{{cite web|first=James|last=Caldwell|title=CALDWELL'S WWE RAW RESULTS 7/7: Complete "virtual-time" coverage of live Raw - Cena vs. Rollins, Jericho vs. Miz, Bret Hart returns to Montreal, more|date=July 7, 2014|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_79464.shtml|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}} The following night on an episode of ''[[WWE Main Event|Main Event]]'', Cameron was scheduled to team with Naomi, [[Natalya Neidhart|Natalya]], [[Eva Marie]], [[Rosa Mendes]], and [[Summer Rae]] against [[Nikki Bella]] in a six-on-one [[Professional wrestling match types#Handicap match|handicap match]], but only showed up to attack Naomi and Nikki.{{cite web|first=James|last=Caldwell|title=CALDWELL'S WWE MAIN EVENT RESULTS 7/8: Sheamus defends U.S. Title, Jericho hosts Hart on the Highlight Reel|date=July 8, 2014|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwsuperstarsreport/article_79475.shtml|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}} Cameron competed in her first match as a villain on the July 15 episode of ''Main Event'' losing to [[Emma (wrestler)|Emma]] and attacked her after the match, only to be scared off by Naomi.{{cite web|last1=Martin|first1=Adam|title=WWE Main Event Results - 7/15/14 (Sheamus vs. The Miz)|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/wwe-news/49605-wwe-main-event-results-7-15-14-sheamus-vs-the-miz|publisher=Wrestleview|accessdate=18 July 2014}} This led to a match between the two on the [[Battleground (2014)|Battleground]] pre–show, where Cameron defeated Naomi after grabbing her tights.{{cite web|last1=Taylor|first1=Scott|title=Cameron def. Naomi by pinning her whilst pulling her tights |url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/wwebattleground/2014/naomi-cameron-26484156|publisher=WWE.com|accessdate=2 July 2014}} Throughout the summer, Cameron continued her rivalry with Naomi{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=James|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_79722.shtml|title=Caldwell's WWE Raw Results 7/21: Complete "virtual-time" coverage of live Raw – Battleground fall-out|date=July 21, 2014|accessdate=July 21, 2014|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}}{{cite web|last=Parks|first=Greg|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_79857.shtml#.Vj3yWbfhDIU|title=PARKS'S WWE RAW REPORT 7/28: Ongoing "virtual time" coverage of the continuing road to Summerslam, follow-up on the Stephanie McMahon arrest angle|date=July 28, 2014|accessdate=July 28, 2014|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}} and competed in various handicap,{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=James|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_80978.shtml#.Vj31TLfhDIU|title=CALDWELL'S WWE RAW RESULTS 9/29: Complete "virtual-time" coverage of Raw vs. NFL Week 4 - Chicago Raw, Ambrose & Cena vs. Orton & Kane, Hogan back on TV, Heyman, more|date=September 29, 2014|accessdate=September 29, 2014|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}} singles{{cite web|last=James|first=Justin|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwsuperstarsreport/article_80064.shtml#.Vj30D7fhDIU|title=JAMES'S WWE SUPERSTARS REPORT 8/7: U.S. champ Sheamus vs. O'Neil solid main event, plus Divas match|date=August 7, 2014|accessdate=August 8, 2014|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}}{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=James|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_80751.shtml#.Vj303bfhDIU|title=CALDWELL'S WWE RAW RESULTS 9/15: Complete "virtual-time" coverage of Raw vs. NFL Week 2 - Brock Lesnar returns, final Night of Champions PPV hype, more|date=September 15, 2014|accessdate=September 16, 2014|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}}{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=James|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwsuperstarsreport/article_80776.shtml#.Vj31srfhDIU|title=CALDWELL'S WWE MAIN EVENT RESULTS 9/16: Battle of Iowa in the main event, Ziggler, Brie, final PPV hype|date=September 16, 2014|accessdate=September 16, 2014|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}} and tag team matches.{{cite web|last=Parks|first=Greg|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_81244.shtml#.Vj3yVbfhDIV|title=CALDWELL'S WWE RAW RESULTS 10/13: Complete "virtual-time" coverage of Raw vs. NFL Week 6 - Cena vs. Ambrose PPV give-away, Big Show vs. Rusev, long matches|date=October 13, 2014|accessdate=October 14, 2014|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}} In November, at [[Survivor Series (2014)|Survivor Series]], Cameron participated in a four-on-four [[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Elimination tag team matches|elimination tag team match]], where she was eliminated by Naomi before her team ultimately lost the match.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wweppvs/article_81932.shtml#.VHKSCIusUv4|title=CALDWELL'S WWE S. SERIES PPV RESULTS 11/23: Ongoing "virtual-time" coverage of Team Cena vs. Team Authority, more|publisher=PWTorch|date=November 23, 2014|author=James Caldwell}} In early 2015, Cameron competed in various singles matches losing to the likes of Summer Rae,{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwsuperstarsreport/article_82792.shtml#.Vj33ELfhDIV|title=JAMES'S WWE SUPERSTARS REPORT 1/16: Rhodes Bros. & Fandango six-man tag, Summer vs. Cameron, Tom Phillips|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch|date=January 16, 2015|author=Justin James}} Naomi{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwsuperstarsreport/article_82950.shtml|title=JAMES'S WWE SUPERSTARS REPORT 1/23: Final WWE show pre-Rumble features Sin Cara vs. Fandango, Cameron vs. Naomi|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch|date=January 23, 2015|author=Justin James}} and Paige.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwesmackdownreport/article_83446.shtml|title=PARKS'S WWE SMACKDOWN REPORT 2/19: Ongoing "virtual time" coverage of the Thursday show, including Seth Rollins vs. Dolph Ziggler, with J&J Security banned from ringside|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch|date=February 19, 2015|author=Greg Pakrs}} On the April 13 episode of ''Raw'', Cameron competed in a number one contender's [[Professional wrestling battle royal|battle royal]] for Nikki Bella's WWE Divas Championship, which would be won by Paige.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_84473.shtml#.VSxfLPnF8v4|title=CALDWELL'S WWE RAW RESULTS 4/13: Ongoing "virtual-time" coverage of London Raw - Cena's latest U.S. Title Open Challenge, #1 contender battle royal, Extreme Rules hype, more|author=Caldwell, James|website=Pro Wrestling Torch|date=April 13, 2015|accessdate=April 13, 2015}} After being the [[special guest referee]] for a match between [[Alicia Fox]] and Natalya, Cameron would attack both [[WWE Divas|Divas]] on the April 9 episode of ''Smackdown'',{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwesmackdownreport/article_84425.shtml#.VTFAYJMso8U|title=PARKS'S WWE SMACKDOWN REPORT 4/9: Ongoing "virtual time" coverage of Thursday show, including Miz TV, Neville's Smackdown debut|author=Parks, Greg|website=Pro Wrestling Torch|date=April 9, 2015|accessdate=April 9, 2015}} which would lead to a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic non-elimination matches|triple threat match]] the following week, with Cameron coming out victorious.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwesmackdownreport/article_84525.shtml#.VTFA2pMso8U|title=PARKS'S WWE SMACKDOWN REPORT 4/16: Ongoing "virtual time" coverage of Thursday show, including Cesaro & Tyson Kidd vs. Daniel Bryan & John Cena|author=Parks, Greg|website=Pro Wrestling Torch|date=April 16, 2015|accessdate=April 16, 2015}} A few weeks later, on the April 30 episode of ''SmackDown'', Cameron confronted Nikki Bella during a backstage segment that led to a non–title match between the two, which Cameron lost.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwesmackdownreport/article_84787.shtml#.Vj3457fhDIU|title=PARKS'S WWE SMACKDOWN REPORT 4/30: Complete coverage of the Thursday night show, including Dean Ambrose vs. Seth Rollins, Extreme Rules Tag Title rematch|author=Greg Parks|website=Pro Wrestling Torch|date=April 30, 2015|accessdate=April 30, 2015}} After taking a hiatus from WWE television, Cameron was moved to [[WWE NXT]] and made her return on the November 4 episode of ''[[WWE NXT (TV series)|NXT]]'', losing to [[Kana (wrestler)|Asuka]].{{cite web|last=Trionfo|first=Richard|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/97631/ongoing-wwe-nxt-report-balor-versus-crews-continues.html?p=1|title=WWE NXT REPORT: BALOR VERSUS CREWS, ASUKA AND A TOTAL DIVA, BONJOUR EVA MARIE, TAG TITLE MATCH NEXT WEEK, TURMOIL AT THE END OF THE SHOW|date=November 4, 2015|work=Pro Wrestling Insider|accessdate=November 4, 2015}} On the January 13, 2016, episode of ''NXT'', Cameron competed in a battle royal to determine the number one contender for [[Bayley (wrestler)|Bayley]]'s [[NXT Women's Championship]], which was won by [[Carmella (wrestler)|Carmella]].{{cite web|last=James|first=Justin|title=1/13 WWE NXT – Women’s #1 contender Battle Royal, NXT Title drama, more|url=http://www.pwtorch.com/site/2016/01/13/jan13nxtresults/|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|date=January 13, 2016|accessdate=January 14, 2016}} On the February 10 episode of ''NXT'', Cameron faced [[Alexa Bliss]] in a losing effort.{{cite web|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/99719/wwe-nxt-report-women39s-title-match-plus-some-extracurricular-activities-gargano-versus-corbin-and-more.html?p=1|title=WWE NXT REPORT: WOMEN'S TITLE MATCH . . . PLUS SOME EXTRACURRICULAR ACTIVITIES, GARGANO VERSUS CORBIN, AND MORE|last=Richard|first=Trionfo|date=February 10, 2016|accessdate=February 10, 2016|work=PWInsider}} After two months of inactivity, WWE announced on May 6 that Andrew had been released from her contract.{{cite web|title=Damien Sandow, King Barrett, Santino Marella, Hornswoggle, Alex Riley and other Superstars released|url=http://www.wwe.com/article/hornswoggle-alex-riley-released|publisher=WWE|date=May 6, 2016|accessdate=May 6, 2016}} == Other media == Andrew played a main role for the [[reality television]] show ''Total Divas'' produced by [[WWE]] and [[E!]], which began airing in July 2013.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/WWE_News_3/article_71912.shtml|title=WWE News: WWE & E! announce "Total Divas" details, number of episodes, male cast members|date=July 12, 2013|last=Caldwell|first=James|accessdate=November 6, 2013|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch}} In May 2015, it was announced that Andrew would not be featured as a full-time cast member on the show for season 4, although she still appears as a guest star.{{cite web|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/93886/total-divas-moving-days-cast-changes.html?p=1|title=TOTAL DIVAS MOVING DAYS?, CAST CHANGES?|website=PWInsider|date=May 21, 2015|accessdate=May 21, 2015|author=Johnson, Mike}} Cameron has appeared in four [[WWE]] video games. She made her in-game debut at ''[[WWE 13]]'' as an [[Non-player character|NPC]] along her then-tag team partner Naomi as "The Funkadactyls" appearing during Brodus Clay's entrance and winning celebration as well as in ''[[WWE 2K14]]'', she later made her playable character debut in ''[[WWE 2K15]]'' and was playable once again in ''[[WWE 2K16]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/2k/wwe-2k16/wwe-2k16-roster-playable-characters-superstars-divas-27794108|title=Superstars and Divas featured on WWE 2K16 roster list|date=September 15, 2015|last=WWE.com|first=Staff|accessdate=September 15, 2015|publisher=[[WWE|WWE.com]]}} In September 2015, Andrew launched an anti-[[bullying]] campaign called "Wrong #".{{cite web|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/fighting/article34323681.html|title=WWE Diva Cameron starts right cause with ‘Wrong #’|website=[[The Miami Herald]]|date=September 8, 2015|accessdate=September 15, 2015}} Andrew competed on the [[MTV]] reality series ''[[The Challenge (TV series)|The Challenge]]'' titled ''[[The Challenge: Champs vs. Stars|Champs vs. Stars]]''.{{Cite web |url=http://people.com/tv/the-challenge-champs-vs-stars-cast-reveal/ |title=Cast Revealed! Josh Murray, Shawn Johnson and More Stars to Compete in MTV’s The Challenge: Champs vs. Stars |last=Russian |first=Ale |date=2017-10-11 |website=[[People (magazine)|People]] |language=en-US |access-date=2017-10-11}} == Filmography == === Television === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 2011 | ''[[WWE Tough Enough]] '' | rowspan="3"| Herself | Contestant; 14th place (season 5) |- | 2013–2015 | ''[[Total Divas]]'' | Main cast (season 1–3)
Recurring (season 4): 30 episodes |- |2017 | ''[[The Challenge: Champs vs. Stars]]'' | |} == Discography == {{Infobox musical artist | name = Ariane | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Ariane Andrew | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Dance music|dance]], [[electropop]], [[R&B]] | years_active = 2013–present | label = | website = {{URL|www.ArianeAndrewNOW.com}} }} === Singles === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Single ! Album |- | 2014 | "Bye Bye (feat. Ice)" | rowspan="2" |Non album single |- | 2015 | "Wrong Number (feat. Lovely)" |} == Personal life == Andrew has previously lived in [[Tampa, Florida]]. Andrew was in a relationship with Vincent Isayan, and their relationship was featured on ''[[Total Divas]]''. On the May 24, 2016 episode of [[Stone Cold Steve Austin]]'s podcast, Andrew revealed that she and Isayan had broken up.{{cite web|url=http://podcastone.com/pg/jsp/program/episode.jsp?programID=542&pid=1651789|title=Ariane Andrew aka Cameron on the Steve Austin Show - EP327}} She has a younger brother, Quentinn, and a younger sister, Aniyah.{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w7ROSKYrXys|title=Cameron confronts her brother and his friends: Total Divas Preview Clip, Oct. 5, 2014|date=2 October 2014|work=YouTube}} She has two degrees.http://www.pwinsider.com/article/101882/cameron-comments-on-her-wwe-release.html?p=1 She cites [[Maryse Ouellet|Maryse]], [[Melina Perez|Melina]], and [[Alicia Fox]] as her inspirations.http://www.pwmania.com/wwe-diva-wants-to-be-top-heel-wwe-polls-fans-on-biggest-splash-in-2014-nxt-tickets In August 2012, Andrew was arrested for [[driving under the influence]], and trying to bribe the arresting officer.{{cite web|url=http://www.tmz.com/2012/08/29/wwe-cameron-arrested-dui-bribary-police/|title=WWE Star Cameron Busted for DUI ... Allegedly Tries to Bribe Cops|work=TMZ SPORTS}} Andrew was punished with a two-week suspension by WWE for the incident.{{cite web|url=http://www.cagesideseats.com/2012/9/2/3287758/wwe-suspends-ariane-andrew-aka-cameron-for-fifteen-days|title=WWE suspends Ariane Andrew aka Cameron, for fifteen days|author=Keith Harris|work=Cageside Seats}} == Awards and accomplishments == * '''''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]''''' ** Ranked No. 17 of the best 50 female singles wrestlers in the ''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated|PWI Female 50]]'' in 2014{{cite web|url=http://www.diva-dirt.com/98351/paige-tops-pwi-female-50/|title=Paige Tops PWI Female 50|date=November 13, 2014}} *'''''[[List of Wrestling Observer revision.text:
A '''caption contest''' or '''caption competition''' is a competition between multiple participants, who are required to give the best description for a certain [[image]] offered by the [[Competition|contest]] organizer. Rules and information about the competition process are also given by the competition organizer.
== General information == Caption contest participants have to describe a given image as accurately and [[originality|originally]] as possible. Contests may vary by image type ([[photograph|photo]] or [[drawing]]), [[Photo caption|caption]] format ([[description]] of a situation or a [[dialogue]]), as well as [[judgement|judging]] criteria. The competition organizer is required to give information about caption submission rules and other information that is important for the contest.
Caption contests are mainly arranged as an [[amusement]], and they can be organized under different conditions (between separate individuals, in public events, [[mass media]], etc.), as well as using various means (drawn pictures on paper, digital image, printed image, press publication, etc.). Traditionally, the most popular and typical format has been publication of caption contests in [[newspaper]]s or [[magazine]]s, but with the development of modern technologies, it is also very popular to organize caption contests on the [[Internet]].
Caption contests can be used not only as an [[entertainment]] but also for other purposes, such as newspaper promotion, bringing forward a certain [[problem]], or product [[advertising|advertisement]]. An important aspect of caption competition is to look at an object, event or issue from unusual point of view.
The caption, unless competition rules do not restrict, can be in any form of literary expression - [[prose]], [[poetry]], as one [[word]] or a [[word play]]. Usually the submitted captions are judged by the originality and [[wit]], but not always the decisive assessment is [[humour]]. It is generally assumed that the caption has to describe image as precisely as possible, so both humour and precision are equally important.
As caption writing is an [[art]] of words, it is rarely possible to evaluate the superiority of one caption over others accurately and [[objectivity (philosophy)|objectively]]. Consequently, the judging of submitted captions is usually quite [[subjectivity|subjective]]. Sometimes competition rules limit caption size, but usually the caption is no longer than one [[sentence (linguistics)|sentence]] (10 - 20 words). As an exception, the caption can consist of several sentences. Usually it is not allowed to use [[profanity|profane]] or offensive language in submitted captions.
In several caption contests, [[champion|winners]] are awarded with [[prize]]s.
== History == It is considered that the origins of caption contests are related to the increase of [[popularity]] of [[cartoon]]s and [[comics]] as well as widespread use of [[illustration]]s and the rise of [[photojournalism]] in printed media at the end of the 19th century. All these areas share the combination of words and images that could be multiplied and made available to a wide audience with the beginnings of mass printing and wide spread of newspapers and magazines.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/20/business/earlier-media-achieved-critical-mass-printing-press-yelling-stop-presses-didn-t.html D. J. R. Bruckner. "How the Earlier Media Achieved Critical Mass." ''The New York Times'', November 20, 1995.]</ref>
From currently available information, the first caption contests in printed media appeared in the [[United States|U.S.]] press of the late 19th century (such as ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine<ref>[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-11-07/ed-1/seq-25/ "$1000.00 in Prizes." ''New-York tribune'', November 07, 1920.] chroniclingamerica.loc.gov. Retrieved May 31, 2012.</ref> which was published from year 1883 to 1936). At that time these competitions were called ''picture title'' or ''picture headline'' contests, but their concept and meaning was identical to current caption contests. It must be considered, that the term ''caption'' in its present sense firstly appeared in [[English language]] only in the first half of the 20th century.<ref>http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=caption&allowed_in_frame=0 Retrieved May 31, 2012.</ref>
In the beginning of the 20th century, at least in the U.S. press (for example, ''[[The San Francisco Call]]'',<ref>[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85066387/1912-01-07/ed-1/seq-17/ "The Sunday Call Will Pay $20 for the Best Title for This Picture." ''The San Francisco call'', January 07, 1912.] chroniclingamerica.loc.gov. Retrieved May 31, 2012.</ref> ''[[Daily News (New York)|The Daily News]]'',<ref>[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-03-23/ed-1/seq-11/ "What does this Picture mean?" ''New-York tribune'', March 23, 1920, p.11.] chroniclingamerica.loc.gov. Retrieved May 31, 2012.</ref> ''[[Connecticut Post|The Bridgeport Telegram]]''<ref>[https://newspaperarchive.com/bridgeport-telegram/1921-12-20/page-30/ "$10 A Week for the Best Titles in Sunday Post Caption Contest" ''Bridgeport Telegram'', December 20, 1921, p.30.] newspaperarchive.com. Retrieved May 31, 2012.</ref>) caption contests were already quite popular. In these competitions drawn pictures and cartoons were mainly used. [[Photo caption]] contests appeared little later with the improvement of printing quality (towards the second quarter of 20th century).
During the course of the 20th century, caption contests were published in printed media in many countries of the world. For example, in Soviet Union one of the first caption contests was published in daily newspaper ''Izvestia'' Sunday supplement ''Nedelya'' (''The Week'') at the beginning of the 1960s.<ref>[http://www.odnako.org/magazine/material/show_14096/ "Золотой глаз-Геолог и Мальтус".] odnako.org. Retrieved June 21, 2012.</ref> Little later a newspaper ''Literaturnaya gazeta'' began to publish caption contests that became very popular and they are part of this newspaper up until now.<ref>[http://www.lgz.ru/article/18729/ "Что бы это значило?".] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620052849/http://www.lgz.ru/article/18729/# |date=2012-06-20 }} lgz.ru. Retrieved June 21, 2012.</ref>
The spread of caption contests increased even more with the emergence of the Internet by the end of the 20th century, and at the beginning of the 21st century. Internet has made the organization of caption contests and participation in them possible for wide audiences across the world.
== Present situation == Although a considerable amount of caption contests are now on Internet, caption contests in printed media still exist and are quite popular. A very popular and prominent is a weekly caption contest published in American magazine ''[[New Yorker (magazine)|The New Yorker]]''.<ref name="a">[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424053111904199404576538831896448132 Russell Adams. "How About Never-Is Never Good for You?" ''The Wall Street Journal'', September 10, 2011.]</ref> The contest first appeared in 1998 and has been published regularly in each issue since 2005.<ref>[http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2005/05/02/your-caption-here Your Caption Here] The New Yorker. 2 May 2005.</ref> Each week several thousand participants take part in this competition.<ref>[http://www.newyorker.com/cartoons/bob-mankoff/seven-reasons-why-hard-to-win-caption-contest Seven Reasons It's Hard To Win The Caption Contest] Mankoff, Robert. 8 November 2014.</ref> On the Internet, a very popular is the weekly caption competition on ''[[BBC]]'' website (''[[BBC News Magazine Monitor|Magazine Monitor]]'' section), held since 2006.
Along the traditional caption contests, there have appeared different forms of this [[genre]] such as anti-caption contests<ref name="a" /> for worst submitted caption and reverse caption contests where the most suitable picture must be submitted for a given caption. There are also caption contests devoted to particular themes such as [[history]]<ref>[http://blogs.archives.gov/prologue/?p=9388 "Thursday Photo Caption Contest"] blogs.archives.gov. Retrieved May 31, 2012.</ref> or [[association football|football]].<ref>[http://www.footytube.com/forums/funny-football/the-silly-captions-competition-2770/ "The Silly Captions Competition"] footytube.com. Retrieved May 31, 2012.</ref>
In 2006, the website caption.me <ref>http://www.caption.me/</ref> (then captioncompetition.co.uk) was founded, featuring amusing photos loaded automatically from photo-sharing site [[Flickr]]. Visitors submit captions and vote for others. Caption.Me features a real-time collaborative mind-mapping feature called [http://www.caption.me/forum/discussion/557/maption-is-live#Item_0 Maption]
In 2009, there was released an online multiplayer caption writing game called ''[[Caption That (Game)|Caption That]]'' where players write captions for a given image and then vote for their favourite from the list others have written.<ref>http://www.captionthat.com {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219001151/http://www.captionthat.com/ |date=2012-02-19}}</ref>
In 2014, the iPhone app [http://www.captionit.co Captionit] was released on the Apple App Store. Captionit is a free mobile app that allows people to play and create caption contests on their iPhone, iPad, and iPod Touch.<ref>[http://www.sbwire.com/press-releases/waste-your-creativity-with-captionits-new-iphone-app-483131.htm/ Waste Your Creativity with Captionit's New Iphone App"] SBWire, March 26, 2014.</ref><ref>http://www.captionit.co/</ref>
In 2016, mobile phone application [http://tinnbin.com TinnBin] was released for both iPhone and Android. TinnBin users create contests called "Bins" by uploading a picture from their device and selecting how long they would like the contest to run. While the bin is open, users can add and vote on comments, called "Tinns". Once the bin is closed, the winning tinn is appended to the image in the form of a caption. TinnBin is different from most other caption contests as the winner is chosen strictly by users of the application, and not the contest creators, and all the contests are created by users of the application.<ref>http://www.tinnbin.com/</ref>
''The New Yorker'' magazine, noting the popularity of its cartoon caption contest, has created a caption contest [[board game]]<ref>[https://archive.is/20120731102549/http://www.familyandpartygames.com/pdf/NY_instructions.pdf/ "The New Yorker Cartoon caption game"] familyandpartygames.com. Retrieved May 31, 2012.</ref> and issued a book with the most interesting cartoons and winning captions as well as comprehensive information covering this theme.<ref>Mankoff, Robert (2008). [https://books.google.com/books?id=ckSXGMV2UJYC&printsec=frontcover&hl=en#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The New Yorker Cartoon Caption Contest Book''] Kansas City: Andrews McMeel Publishing. {{ISBN|0-7407-7750-5}}.</ref>
Also concerning the ''New Yorker'' caption contest, several scientific studies have been carried out: researchers from [[University of New Mexico]], Department of Anthropology, in 2010 have compared humour ability in males and females in context of this competition;<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0160289611000523/ | doi=10.1016/j.intell.2011.03.006 | volume=39 | title=Humor ability reveals intelligence, predicts mating success, and is higher in males | journal=Intelligence | pages=188–192}}</ref> members of ''The New Yorker'' editorial board and [[University of Colorado at Boulder|University of Colorado Boulder]] [[Leeds School of Business]] in 2011 analysed several thousand entries of this contest to study the concept of humour.<ref>[http://leeds.colorado.edu/news/113 Leeds School of Business "What It Takes To Win The New Yorker`s Cartoon Caption Contest"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121204013344/http://leeds.colorado.edu/news/113 |date=December 4, 2012}} leeds.colorado.edu, April 25, 2011.</ref>
== Future perspectives == The future of caption contests depends on the [[imagination]] and [[creativity]] of their organizers and participants, as well as future development of information and [[Information and communications technology|communication technologies]].
== In popular culture == In U.S. TV series ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)|The Office]]'', seventh-season episode ''[[The Search (The Office)|The Search]]'',<ref>[http://www.nbc.com/the-office/episode-guide/season-7/42801/the-search/episode-715/281549/ "The Search".] "The Office" episode guide. nbc.com. Retrieved May 31, 2012.</ref> its character [[Pam Beesly|Pam]] starts a caption contest in the office, with her co-worker [[Gabe Lewis|Gabe]] instituting rules that no one wants to follow.
In [[British sitcom]] ''[[Green Wing]]'', the second series, episode six, its character [[Alan Statham]] wins a caption competition on the ''Consultant Radiologists International'' website, an organisation of which Alan claims to be an "Esteemed member".<ref>[http://www.tv.com/shows/green-wing/episodes/ "Episode 6 – Season 2".] "Green Wing" episode guide. tv.com. Retrieved June 3, 2012.</ref>
In a children's novel ''[[Absolute Zero (novel)|Absolute Zero]]'' by [[Helen Cresswell]] its character Uncle Parker has won a trip to the [[Caribbean]] in a caption contest. The rest of the family immediately enter similar competitions in an attempt to better his prize but, much of the time, beating the others to an entry form is a victory in itself.
In season two of the [[HBO]] series ''[[Bored to Death]]'', George (played by [[Ted Danson]]) struggles to caption a New Yorker cartoon, which portrays a police duck interacting with a suicidal bear.
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == * Mendrinos, James (2004). [https://www.amazon.com/Complete-Idiots-Guide-Comedy-Writing/dp/1592572316#reader_1592572316 ''The Complete Idiot's Guide to Comedy Writing''.] Indianapolis: Alpha Books. {{ISBN|1-4406-9048-0}}. * Sale, Jonathan (1981). ''If the Caption Fits: The Best of the Punch Caption Competition''. London: Elm Tree Books. {{ISBN|0-241-10668-0}}. * Glasser, Selma (1980). ''The Complete Guide to Prize Contests, Sweepstakes, and How to Win Them''. New York: F. Fell Publishers. {{ISBN|0811903273}}. * LaRocque, Paul (2003). [https://books.google.com/books?id=ekyU8CoNwNwC&printsec=frontcover&hl=en#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Heads You Win!: An Easy Guide to Better Headline and Caption Writing''.] Portland: Marion Street Press. {{ISBN|0-9729937-0-3}}.
== External links == * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/magazinemonitor/caption_comp/rss.xml BBC Magazine Monitor caption competition] * [http://www.newyorker.com/humor/caption "The New Yorker" magazine caption contest] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20131001000123/http://giggletrigger.com/ Giggle Trigger - Survival of the Wittiest - Daily Caption contest]
[[Category:Humour]] [[Category:Leisure activities]] [[Category:Entertainment]] [[Category:Competitions]]

{{See also|Children's songs|Nursery rhyme}} {{Infobox music genre |stylistic_origins = {{hlist|[[Nursery Rhymes]]|[[educational music]]|[[easy listening]]|[[bubblegum pop]]}} |instruments = {{hlist|[[piano]]|[[drums]]|[[guitar]]|voice}} }}
'''Children's music''' or '''kids' music''' is music composed and performed for children. In European-influenced contexts this means music, usually songs, written specifically for a juvenile audience. The composers are usually adults. Children's music has historically held both entertainment and educational functions. Children's music is often designed to provide an entertaining means of teaching children about their [[culture]], other cultures, good behavior, facts and skills. Many are [[folk song]]s, but there is a whole genre of [[educational music]] that has become increasingly popular.
==History==
===Early published music=== The growth of the popular music publishing industry, associated with New York's [[Tin Pan Alley]] in the late 19th and early 20th centuries led to the creation of a number of songs aimed at children. These included 'Ten little fingers and ten little toes' by Ira Shuster and Edward G. Nelson and '[[School Days (1907 song)|School Days]]' (1907) by Gus Edwards and Will Cobb.<ref>E. C. Axford, ''Song Sheets to Software: A Guide to Print Music, Software, and Web Sites for Musicians'' (Scarecrow Press, 2004), p. 18.</ref> Perhaps the best remembered now is "[[Teddy Bears' Picnic]]", with lyrics by [[Jimmy Kennedy]] in 1932 and the tune by British composer John William Bratton was from 1907.<ref>[[Peter van der Merwe (musicologist)|van der Merwe, Peter]]. ''Roots of the Classical: The Popular Origins of Western Music'' (Oxford University Press, 2004), p. 436.</ref>
=== Early recordings for children === Recordings for children were intertwined with recorded music for as long as it has existed as a medium. The first words ever recorded (in 1860 by [[Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville]]) was the first verse of the French folk/children's song "[[Au Clair de la Lune]]". In 1888, the first recorded discs (called "plates") offered for sale included [[Mother Goose]] nursery rhymes. The earliest record catalogues of several seminal figures in the recording industry such as Edison, Berliner, and Victor all contained separate children's sections.
Throughout the 1930s, 1940s, and 1950s record companies continued to produce albums for children. Such companies as [[RCA Records|RCA Victor]], [[Decca Records]], [[Capitol Records]], and [[Columbia Records]] (among others) published albums based on popular cartoons or nursery rhymes. Recordings based on [[Walt Disney|Disney]] films and cartoons were released at that time by RCA Victor and Capitol Records, and beginning in the late 1950s by [[Disneyland Records]] and [[Buena Vista Records]]. Often the albums were read-alongs that contained booklets that children could follow along with. Many of the biggest names in theater, radio, and motion pictures were featured on these albums, such as: [[Bing Crosby]], [[Harold Peary]] ("The Great Gildersleeve"), [[Orson Welles]], [[Jeanette MacDonald]], [[Roy Rogers]], [[Fanny Brice]], [[William Boyd (actor)|William Boyd]] ("Hopalong Cassidy"), [[Ingrid Bergman]], [[Danny Kaye]], and [[Fredric March]].
The role of Disney in children's cinema from the 1930s meant that it gained a unique place in the production of children's music. The first popular Disney song was 'Minnie's Yoo Hoo' (1930) the theme song from a [[Mickey Mouse]] cartoon.<ref name="Jasen2003">D. A. Jasen, ''Tin Pan Alley: An Encyclopedia of the Golden Age of American Song'' (Taylor & Francis, 2003), p. 111-13.</ref> After the production of their first feature-length animation ''[[Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937 film)|Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs]]'' in 1937, with its highly successful score by [[Frank Churchill]] and Larry Morey, which included the songs "[[Whistle while you work]]", "[[Some Day My Prince Will Come]]" and "[[Heigh-Ho]]", the mould for a combination of animation, fairy tale and distinctive songs was set that would carry through to the 1970s with songs from films such as ''[[Pinocchio (1940 film)|Pinocchio]]'' (1940) and ''[[Song of the South]]'' (1946).<ref name="Jasen2003"/>
=== Growth during the 20th century ===
The mid-20th-century arrival of the baby boomers provided a growing market for children's music as a separate genre. [[Woody Guthrie]], [[Pete Seeger]] and [[Ella Jenkins]] were among a cadre of politically progressive and socially conscious performers who aimed albums to this group. During this time, such novelty recordings as "[[Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer (song)|Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer]]" (a [[Montgomery Ward]] jingle that became a book and later a classic children's movie) and the fictional music group, [[The Chipmunks]], were among the most commercially successful music ventures of the time ("The Chipmunk Song" was a No. 1 hit single in 1958). TV personality [[Bob Keeshan]] (''[[Captain Kangaroo]]'') recorded several children's albums, as did [[Shari Lewis]].
In the 1960s, as the baby boomers matured and became more politically aware, they embraced both the substance and politics of folk ("the people's") music. [[Peter, Paul, and Mary]], [[The Limeliters]], and [[Tom Paxton]] were acclaimed folk artists who wrote albums for children. In 1969, the [[Children's Television Workshop]] in the United States launched ''[[Sesame Street]]''. The quality of ''Sesame Street''{{'}}s children's music, much of it created by noted composers [[Joe Raposo]] and [[Jeff Moss]], has dominated the children's music landscape to this day - the show has won 11 [[Grammy Awards]].
Children's music gained an even wider audience in the 1970s when musical features such as ''[[Schoolhouse Rock!]]'' and the original Letter People were featured on network and public television, respectively. These represented an effort to make music that taught specific lessons about Math, History, and English to youngsters through the high-quality, award-winning music. The classic public television children's show ''[[Mister Rogers]]' Neighborhood'' had music heavily featured as well. In the late 1970s, Canadian artist [[Raffi (musician)|Raffi]], coincided with the rise of children's music as a distinct music industry genre.
In the early 1990s, [[songwriter]], [[record producer]], and [[performer]] [[Bobby Susser]], emerged strongly with his easy-to-learn, award-winning young children's songs and series, ''Bobby Susser Songs For Children'' that exemplified the use of children's music to educate young children in schools and at home.<ref>''Educational Dealer'' magazine, August 1997</ref> Musical duo [[Greg & Steve]] have focused on the positive reaction children have to music.
Disney also re-entered the market for animated musical features, beginning with ''[[The Little Mermaid (1989 film)|The Little Mermaid]]'' (1989) from which the song "[[Under the Sea]]" won an [[Academy Award|Oscar]] for best song.<ref name="Jasen2003"/> This was followed by successful features including ''[[Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)|Beauty and the Beast]]'' (1991) ''[[Aladdin (1992 Disney film)|Aladdin]]'' (1992), and ''[[The Lion King]]'' (1994), the last of which had music by [[Elton John]] and [[Tim Rice]], and ''[[Pocahontas (1995 film)|Pocahontas]]'' (1995), all of which were awarded best song Oscars.<ref name="Jasen2003"/>
=== Recent history === In the United States, children's music continues to be a force in the commercial music industry. At one point in early 2006, the top three albums on the Billboard charts were all children's music: [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]]'s ''[[High School Musical]]'' soundtrack, the ''[[Kidz Bop]]'' series, and the ''[[Curious George (film)|Curious George]]'' film soundtrack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://billboard.com/bbcom/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1002113930|title=Billboard News|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=22 December 2017}}</ref> Most albums targeted nationally to children are soundtracks for motion pictures or symbiotic marketing projects involving mass-marketed acts such as, [[The Wiggles]] or [[VeggieTales]].
The 21st century has also seen an increase in the number of independent children's music artists, with acts like [[The Dirty Sock Funtime Band]], [[Dan Zanes]], [[Parachute Express]], Cathy Bollinger, [[Laurie Berkner]] and [[Lah-Lah]] getting wide exposure on cable TV channels targeted to children. [[Trout Fishing in America (band)|Trout Fishing in America]] has achieved much acclaim continuing the tradition of merging sophisticated folk music with family-friendly lyrics. [[Secret Agent 23 Skidoo]] infuses hip-hop with family friendly messages and imaginative stories and is known as "The King of Kid-Hop". Also recently, traditionally rock-oriented acts like [[They Might Be Giants]] have released albums marketed directly to children, such as ''[[No!]]'' and ''[[Here Come the ABCs]]''. [[Jimmy Buffett]] simply remade his "[[Cheeseburger in Paradise]]" song into children's music with cleaned up lyrics ("Root Beer" instead of "Draft Beer"). His songs were already kid friendly with catchy lyrics and simple melodies punctuated with penny whistles and ship bell sound effects. Conversely, [[Koo Koo Kanga Roo]], a children-oriented comedy [[synthpop]] duo, made a successful crossover from performing children's events into touring with adult rock and punk bands such as [[Reel Big Fish]] and [[Frank Turner]]. In Canada, artists such as [[The Kerplunks]] have paved modern pathways to the genre following in the footsteps of Raffi, [[Fred Penner]] and [[Sharon, Lois & Bram]].
Sanitized versions of earthy songs like Harry McClintock's "[[Big Rock Candy Mountain]]" have regularly been adapted for younger audiences. The 2008 version by Gil McLachlan re-tells the story as a child's dream, the last stanza being: :In the Big Rock Candy Mountains you're going on a holiday :Your birthday comes around once a week and it’s Christmas every day :You never have to clean your room or put your toys away :There's a little white horse you can ride of course :You can jump so high you can touch the sky :In the Big Rock Candy Mountains.
Many children's stores and sometimes music outlets sell covers of pop songs, performed by adults for children, especially Christmas songs. These were especially popular during the early 2000s.
The use of children's music, to educate, as well as entertain, continued to grow, as evidenced in February 2009, when [[Bobby Susser]]'s young children's series surpassed five million CD sales.<ref>Educational Dealer magazine, April 2009, Industry news section, page 34.</ref> In September 2016 Smithsonian Folkways Recordings label acquired the [[Bobby Susser]] series, to further the exposure of children's music that teaches as well as entertains, throughout the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/battersby-duo/smithsonian-folkways-acqu_b_12285162.html|title=Smithsonian Folkways acquires Bobby Susser's New Hope Records Catalog|first=Battersby|last=Duo|date=4 October 2016|publisher=[[Huff Post]]|accessdate=22 December 2017}}</ref>
As more children are using smart phones, tablets, laptops and smart-TVs, kids songs have entered the on-demand streaming content era. On YouTube, some children's songs, like "[[Baby Shark]]" and "[[Let It Go (Disney song)|Let it go]]", have surpassed 1 billion views, easily becoming some of the [[List of most-viewed YouTube videos|most viewed YouTube videos]] of all time.
==See also== * [[Bubblegum pop]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Jarnow, Jill. ''All Ears: how to Choose and Use Recorded Music for Children''. New York: Penguin Books, 1991. {{ISBN|0-14-011254-5}} * Smith, Barbara, and Charles Smith. ''The Non-Musician's Guide to Children's Music'', in series, ''I.C.L. Concept Book[s]''. Glendale, Calif.: International Center for Learning, 1977. {{ISBN|0-8307-0492-2}}
{{Children's music}}
[[Category:Children's music| ]]

revision.comment: /* Rationale */ CTTOI, not really relevant (might be at Memory Alpha, but that's not us)
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=December 2016}} A '''clip show''' is an episode of a [[Television program|television series]] that consists primarily of excerpts from previous episodes. Most clip shows feature the format of a [[frame story]] in which cast members recall past events from past installments of the show, depicted with a clip of the event presented as a [[flashback (literary technique)|flashback]]. Clip shows are also known as '''cheaters''', particularly in the field of animation. Clip shows are often played before [[series finale]]s, or once [[100 episodes|syndication becomes highly likely]]. Other times, however, clip shows are simply produced for budgetary reasons (i.e. to avoid additional costs from shooting in a certain setting, or from casting actors to appear in new material).
==Origin== Clip shows have their origin in theatrical [[short film]]s and [[Serial (film)|serials]]. Every serial chapter always had a brief recap showing where the previous chapter left off, but, beginning in 1936, entire chapters were largely devoted to material that audiences had already seen. In these '''recap chapters''' (also called "economy chapters"), previous chapters were summarized for those who may have missed some episodes (which were unlikely to be rerun). The practice began with the [[Republic Pictures]] serial ''[[Robinson Crusoe of Clipper Island]]''. Adverse weather conditions slowed the filming of this outdoor adventure budgeted for 12 chapters, and screenwriter Barry Shipman was forced to create two more chapters to recoup the lost production costs. Shipman wrote a few scenes in which the screen characters recount their adventures to date, and [[stock footage]] from previous chapters is shown instead of new sequences. Shipman's brainstorm was a convenient way to economize on production, and soon Republic made the recap chapter standard procedure.
Movie studios often resorted to old footage to save money. The most famous example is the short comedies of [[The Three Stooges]] which, from 1949 until 1957, borrowed lengthy sequences and often entire storylines from old shorts. Only a few new scenes would be filmed as a framework for the old footage. This practice was adopted because the studios could charge more money for "new" films than for old ones.
Animation studios were also known to periodically make cartoon shorts - often referred to as "cheaters" - made up primarily of clips for earlier cartoons in order to save money. Examples of this include ''[[Betty Boop's Rise to Fame]]'' ([[Fleischer Studios|Fleischer]]/[[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]], 1934), ''[[What's Cookin' Doc?]]'' (1944, [[Warner Bros. Cartoons|Schlesinger]]/[[Warner Bros.]]) and a regular yearly series of ''[[Tom & Jerry]]'' "cheaters" such as ''[[Smitten Kitten]]'' (1952, [[MGM cartoon studio|MGM]]).
==Variations== One variant of the modern clip show is the '''compilation episode''', using clips from the most popular episodes, assembled together in one episode, sometimes without a frame story as such.
Another format is to have a host who describes various characters and characteristics of the show to introduce various clips from past episodes. For example, a special one-hour clip show episode of ''[[All in the Family]]'' featured actor [[Henry Fonda]] discussing the main characters on the show followed by relevant clips from previous episodes; a similar two-part clip show appeared on ''[[Three's Company]]'', hosted by [[Lucille Ball]]. This format was parodied in a clip show for ''[[The Simpsons]]'' ("[[The Simpsons 138th Episode Spectacular]]"), in which fictional actor [[Troy McClure]]—a recurring ''Simpsons'' character—introduced the clips.
A third variation, used in a two-part clip show episode of ''[[Cheers]]'' featured the entire cast of the show, including former cast members, sitting on a stage while being interviewed by talk host [[John McLaughlin (host)|John McLaughlin]] about their characters on the show, with clips of previous episodes mixed in. A similar clip episode of ''[[Barney Miller]]'' aired after the death of cast member [[Jack Soo]], with flashbacks introduced by the rest of the cast highlighting Soo's character [[Detective Sergeant]] Nick Yamana.
''[[Clerks: The Animated Series]]'' had a flashback episode 2 episodes in to the series. The two main leads reminisce on the previous episode and other adventures they went on. The episode was highly praised.<ref>{{cite web |title=98, Clerks: The Animated Series |url=http://tv.ign.com/top-100-animated-tv-series/98.html |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=2017-04-18 |date=2009-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090119005244/http://tv.ign.com/top-100-animated-tv-series/98.html |archivedate=2009-01-19 |df= }}</ref>
In the ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'' episode "The Ember Island Players", the show's main characters watch a play about themselves based upon the events of the series thus far. Although the episode contains no actual footage from previous episodes, the actors recount many scenes from the series and show all the significant plot events. "The Ember Island Players" was the last episode before the four-part series finale.
The [[NBC]] sitcom [[Community (TV series)|''Community'']] used the clip show format with the episode "[[Paradigms of Human Memory]]", but rather than using clips from previous episodes, the cut-away scenes in that episode were all newly shot. In some cases the clips were set in events of previous episodes, and in other cases the clips showed events that had never before occurred on the show, such as visiting an Old West ghost town, taking over for a glee club killed in a bus crash or going on a fishing trip. The creator of ''Community'', [[Dan Harmon]], used the same format in another one of his shows, ''[[Rick and Morty]]'', where all the clips were completely new and related to the episode, 'Total Rickall', in some way.
In [[anime]], a common type of episode is the '''Recap episode''', which presents clips from previous episodes in a manner to remind viewers of the story so far and help newer viewers catch up on the plot and details.
==Rationale== While clip shows do reduce production costs, they were originally employed in an era when there were far fewer program outlets and it was less likely that episodes from previous seasons would be aired again. Clip shows typically received strong [[Nielsen ratings|ratings]], and it was expected for any successful comedy series to feature clip shows regularly in its later years. However, the episodes were subject to some ridicule due to their forced or "corny" framing devices (such as a family sitting peacefully around a fireplace) and the frequently awkward transitions between the frame story and the clips (such as characters staring into space while the screen blurs to represent "remembering").{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}}
Daytime [[soap operas]] frequently present clip shows as a way to commemorate a show's milestone anniversary or the death of a long-running character. Many fans take advantage of the shows in order to see vintage clips of a particular soap opera. One example was an episode of ''[[As the World Turns]]'' in which seven of the longest running characters were stranded in a forest and remembered some of their best moments, all in honor of ''AtWT''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s 50th anniversary.
Another common rationale for a clip show is the lack of a new show to air, due to failure to meet production schedules. For example, the computer-animated series ''[[Roughnecks: Starship Troopers Chronicles]]'' used clip shows four times for this purpose, interrupting in-progress story arcs. Similarly, the ''[[Moonlighting (TV series)|Moonlighting]]'' season 3 episode "The Straight Poop" helped to fill out a production schedule that was rife with delays: in 15 weeks since that season began, only 8 episodes of the "weekly" series had been broadcast. ''[[Chappelle's Show]]'' resorted to producing ''five'' clip shows (using material from only 25 episodes) over the course of its first two seasons.
Other times budgetary considerations force clip shows. At the end of its second season, ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' had one more episode to shoot. However, [[Paramount Television|Paramount]] cut that show's budget to make up for an episode earlier in the season that had gone over budget—and, similarly, over schedule, leaving only three days for [[principal photography]]. Because the season had gotten off to a slow start due to a [[1988 Writers Guild of America strike|writers' strike]], the producers had no scripts set aside for future use as they normally would have.<ref name="ST:TNG 365">{{cite book|last1=Block|first1=Paula M.|last2=Erdmann|first2=Terry J.|last3=Moore|first3=Ronald D.|title=Star Trek: The Next Generation 365|date=2012|publisher=Abrams|isbn=9781613124000|page=330|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JCbTA9wMmEAC&pg=PT330|accessdate=May 24, 2015}}</ref> The result was "[[Shades of Gray (Star Trek: The Next Generation)|Shades of Gray]]", in which the "clips" were the induced dreams of a comatose [[William T. Riker]]. The episode is widely considered among the worst of any ''[[Star Trek]]'' series.<ref name="ST:TNG companion">{{cite book|last1=Nemecek|first1=Larry|title=The Star Trek: The Next Generation Companion: Revised Edition|date=2003|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|isbn=9780743476577|page=94|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ah1k_EsaOHsC&pg=PA94|accessdate=May 24, 2015}}</ref>
Clip shows today tend to offset such criticism by trying to make the frame tale surrounding the clips compelling, or by presenting clip shows without any framing device. A show might also diffuse the awkwardness by indulging in [[self-parody]], explicitly acknowledging or intentionally over-playing the device. Many series have included parody clip shows using "clips" from episodes which never happened. The ''[[South Park]]'' episode "[[City on the Edge of Forever (South Park)|City on the Edge of Forever]]" shows scenes from previous episodes, but the details are always wrong, and in the end, everyone gets ice cream. As another example, ''[[Clerks: The Animated Series]]'' ran a clip show as its second episode, even though there was only one prior episode from which to pull material. The aforementioned ''Moonlighting'' clip episode, in typical fashion for the show, used a framing story that broke the [[fourth wall]] to determine if the characters themselves were the source of the show's notorious production delays, and ended with the characters promising a "new episode next week!".
The clip show has been employed more seriously as a means to bring viewers up to date on highly serialized dramas, such as on ''[[Lost (TV series)|Lost]]'', ''[[Once Upon a Time (TV series)|Once Upon a Time]]'' and [[Battlestar Galactica (2004 TV series)|the reimagined ''Battlestar Galactica'']]. Many [[anime]] dramas used similar techniques, particularly when a series ran for more episodes in one season than could be reasonably rerun (such as ''[[Mobile Suit Gundam Wing]]'' running for 49 episodes, which were originally aired weekly).
Sometimes clip shows air before or during a [[series finale]] as a way for audiences to reminisce about their favorite moments. Some examples of shows that have used clip shows in this sense are: ''[[Animaniacs]]'', ''[[Frasier]]'', ''[[The Golden Girls]]'', ''[[Seinfeld]]'', ''[[Friends]]'', ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]'', ''[[Everybody Loves Raymond]]'', ''[[The Outer Limits (1995 TV series)|The Outer Limits]]'', ''[[Stargate SG-1]]''/''[[Stargate Atlantis|Atlantis]]'', and ''[[Cheers]]''.
Clip shows are also a way to compile the best episodes or sketches from a series to air in a single, concise package when rerunning a whole episode or series is implausible. The annual Scottish New Year special ''[[Scotch and Wry]]'' was condensed into four feature film-length episodes for home video release. ''[[Carson's Comedy Classics]]'' compiled memorable sketches from the first 20 seasons of ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'' for airing in syndication. Surviving content from [[Bozo the Clown]] and other Chicago children's television programs was incorporated into ''[[Bozo, Gar and Ray: WGN TV Classics]]'', an annual holiday special.
==See also== * [[Compilation movie]] * [[Fix-up]] * [[Bottle episode]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClipShow Clip Show at [[TV Tropes]]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox comic book title <!--Wikipedia:WikiProject Comics--> | title = Dracula | image = DraculaDell2.jpg | caption = Cover to Issue #2. | schedule = | format = |ongoing=y | publisher = [[Dell Comics]] | date = November 1966-March 1967 | issues = 3 | main_char_team = | writers = [[Don Segall]] | artists = [[Tony Tallarico]] | pencillers = [[Bill Fracchio]] | inkers = | colorists = | creative_team_month = | creative_team_year = | creators = <!-- |subcat= |sort={{PAGENAME}} --> }} '''''Dracula''''' is a [[superhero]] [[comic book]] series published by [[Dell Comics]], based on the literary and movie character [[Count Dracula]]. The book was part of a line of three superhero comics based on the [[Universal Monsters]] characters; the other two were ''[[Frankenstein (Dell Comics)|Frankenstein]]'' and ''[[Werewolf (Dell Comics)|Werewolf]]''.
==Publication history== ''Dracula'' lasted 3 issues from 1966 through 1967, numbered 2 through 4. (#1, published in 1962, was an adaptation of the [[Dracula (1931 English-language film)|1931 film]]). In 1972-73, Dell reprinted the series, numbering them #6-8 (the reason for skipping issue #5 is unknown).
==Series background== '''Dracula''' is a modern-day direct descendant of the original [[Count Dracula]] now working as a medical researcher in the old family castle in [[Transylvania]] where, due to his experiments to develop a cure for [[brain damage]] using a serum developed from [[bat]] [[blood]], he accidentally gains strange "[[vampire]]"-like powers, including the ability to turn into a bat and superhuman sight and hearing. He decides to embark on a superhero career in order to redeem his family name, developing his body through diet and exercise to the peak of physical perfection and designing himself his own distinctive crimson-cowled purple costume with a bat-shaped gold belt buckle, after which he vows to fight evil and [[superstition]] in all its forms.
Leaving for America after the local peasants burn down his castle, he adopts the [[secret identity]] of "'''[[ Son of Dracula (1943 film)|Al U. Card]]'''" (a hastily chosen [[pseudonym]] short for "Aloyisius Ulysses Card"). In issue #4, his girlfriend and confidante, blond [[socialite]] '''B.B. Beebe''', gains the same powers and became his blue-clad sidekick '''Fleeta''' (from "[[Die Fledermaus|fledermaus]]", the German word for bat), bringing to the team not only a [[black belt (martial arts)|black belt]] in [[judo]] but also an abandoned hidden underground government [[radar]] installation/[[bomb shelter]] on her family's mountain estate that Dracula uses as his secret laboratory lair.
==Dracula's Oath== "I pledge by the strange powers which have become mine to fight against the injustice, corruption, evil and greed which fills this Earth in the hopes that somehow my example will be an example to all men."
==External links== *[http://www.internationalhero.co.uk/d/delldrac.htm Dracula's entry at International Catalog of Superheroes] *[http://www.toonopedia.com/dracdell.htm Dracula (1966)] at [[Don Markstein's Toonopedia]]. [https://www.webcitation.org/6gyCSNd0K?url=http://toonopedia.com/dracdell.htm Archived] from the original on April 22, 2016. {{Dracula}} {{comics-stub}} [[Category:Dell Comics titles]] [[Category:1966 comics debuts]] [[Category:1967 comics endings]] [[Category:Comics based on films]] [[Category:Comics based on Dracula]] [[Category:Horror comics]] [[Category:Comics set in Romania]] [[Category:Dell Comics characters]] [[Category:Male characters in comics]]

'''Dynamo''', in '''comics''', may refer to:
* [[Dynamo (Fox Feature Syndicate)]], a 1940s comic book character * Dynamo, one of the [[T.H.U.N.D.E.R. Agents]] * [[Captain Dynamo (comics)]], a comic book superhero * [[Crimson Dynamo]], the name of several Marvel Comics characters * [[Dynamo 5]], a superhero team formed of the children of Captain Dynamo * Dynamo Boy, an expelled member of the [[List of Legion of Super-Heroes members#Expelled members|Legion of Super-Heroes]] *''[[Dynamo Joe]]'', a 1980s comic book series
