{{Redirect|Fire eater|other uses|Fire eater (disambiguation)}}
[[Image:Fire Eater Performing Dragons Breath Trick.jpg|thumb|200px|A fire eater performing a vapor pull at [[Transformus]], 2013.]]
[[File:Brian Brushwood eating fire at TWiT's Grand Opening party..webm|thumb|[[Brian Brushwood]] performing fire eating tricks.]]
[[File:Fire Gypsy performing Fire Eating.jpg|thumb|200px|A fire eating trick performed at a bar in New York City]]
[[Image:fireeatingtorch.JPG|thumb|200px|A set of simple cast iron fire eating torches]]
[[File:Sandy Eating Fire ~ Marshall Sylver Turning Point.webm|thumb|Video of fire eating.]]
'''Fire eating''' is the act of putting a flaming object into the mouth and extinguishing it. A '''fire eater''' can be an [[entertainer]], a [[street performance|street performer]], part of a [[sideshow]] or a [[circus]] act but has also been part of spiritual tradition in [[India]].
==Physics== Fire eating relies on the quick extinction of the fire in the mouth or on the touched surfaces and on the short term cooling effects of water evaporation at the surface on the source of fire (usually with a low percentage of alcohol mixed in the water) or saliva in the mouth. This allows for igniting a damp handkerchief or a bill of money without it burning. Closing the mouth, or covering it with a slap of the hand cuts off the [[oxygen]] to the fire. Blowing on it can remove the very thin area of reaction from the source of fuel, and thus extinguish the fire in some cases, where the blown air is faster than the fire front and the flame is small enough to be entirely removed.<ref>[https://books.google.co.il/books?id=4x7QHE7sm2gC&pg=PA30&lpg=PA30&dq=why+alcohol+burns+and+does+not+ignite&source=bl&ots=wMvPZXlAF2&sig=d2U4Ce3LXHm-IRoXgK_i6PzcDnQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiX2faDh-_RAhVEnRoKHd5mA1kQ6AEIVDAJ#v=onepage&q=why%20alcohol%20burns%20and%20does%20not%20ignite&f=false Why alcohol burns and does not ignite] in Classic Chemistry Demonstrations published by the Royal Society of Chemistry. ([[Google Books]])</ref><ref>[http://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/103447/why-does-a-candle-blow-out-when-we-blow-on-it-our-breath-is-16-oxygen-and-only Why does a candle blow out when we blow on it?] (Answer on [[Stack Exchange]] physics questions site)</ref>
The flame itself is not a [[cold flame]], and the performers do not use any other material besides the fuel. Certain materials are avoided when doing the trick, such as materials which may easily ignite, melt or store the heat and release it later. These include paraffin candles, plastic, and thick multithreaded rope.<ref name="juggling">[http://www.juggling.org/help/circus-arts/fire-eat/fire-eat.html Fire eating instructions] including instructions repeatedly stressing the importance of an attending experienced skilled master, and giving instructions as to the recommended materials to be used. (juggling.org website)</ref>
==History and hazards== Fire eating was a common part of [[Hindu]], [[Sadhu]], and [[Fakir]] performances to show spiritual attainment. It became a part of the standard sideshow acts in the late 1880s and was often seen as one of the entry-level skills for sideshow performers,<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/title/blitzs-book-of-magic-and-fire-eating-made-easy/oclc/317384178 Blitz' book of magic and fire eating made easy], Library of Congress catalog first published in 1880. (Following a series of books published since 1875)</ref> although skilled fire performers, such as those who can use the difficult and dangerous vapor transfers and produce large breaths of fire are regarded as equals in the circus community for their skill and devotion to their art.
Other than sound fire safety precautions and some practical advice regarding the laws of [[physics]] (i.e. "hot air rises"), there are few secrets to eating fire. Torches do not burn with "[[cold flame]]s" nor is there any special substance in the performer's mouth other than [[saliva]]. It is instead the cutting off of the [[oxygen]] from the flame which extinguishes it and the evaporation of saliva with the water in the alcoholic solution which keeps the nearby surfaces cool while it is still burning. Even so, according to Daniel Mannix's 1951 sideshow memoir ''Step right up!'', the real "secret" to fire eating is enduring pain; he mentions that tolerating constant blisters on your tongue, lips and throat is also necessary. Many other fire eaters dismiss this, claiming that a skilled fire eater should not burn themselves. The most common method of safely performing fire eating acts relies on the fact that it takes time to transfer heat, and that heat rises in air. Fire eating and fire breathing (and all variants) is a skill which should be passed on from a skilled master to an appropriate student<ref name="juggling" /> and almost all teachings include instructions on first aid, fire safety, chemistry and other appropriate skills.<ref name="juggling" /><ref>{{cite journal | pmc= 3481926 | pmid=23130274 | doi=10.4103/2229-5178.93491 | volume=3 | title=Fire-breathing burn | journal=Indian Dermatol Online J | pages=73–4 | last1 = Saraf | first1 = S}}</ref><ref>[https://stuff.mit.edu/afs/athena/activity/s/spinning-arts/safety-docs/fire-eating-fleshing-safety.pdf Safety for Fire Eating and Contact Fire] (Retrieved from the [[MIT]] students portal)</ref> Accidental ingestion of fuel or improper technique can lead to a serious condition known as [[fire eater's pneumonia]].
==Famous fire eaters== A famous fire eater from the 18th century was [[Robert Powell (fire-eater)|Robert Powell]] who allegedly not only swallowed fire but also red-hot coals, melted [[sealing wax]] and even [[sulfur|brimstone]]. He performed, often in front of British and other European royalty and nobility, for nearly sixty years and, in 1751, was awarded a purse of gold and a large silver medal.<ref>[http://www.fullbooks.com/The-Miracle-Mongers-An-Expose-1.html ''Miracle Mongers and their Methods''], Houdini: particularly chapters II, V, VI . Retrieved on 2008-06-12</ref>
Although not the earliest, the first to attract the attention of the [[upper classes]] was an [[Englishman]] named Richardson, who first performed in [[France]] in 1667. His methods were subsequently made public by his servant.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=6-E8AAAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA313&lpg=RA2-PA315&ots=ktt2h7zORF&dq=powell+richardson+Panthot "Hot Meals"], ''The Every-day Book and Table Book; or, Everlasting Calendar of Popular Amusements, Sports, Pastimes, Ceremonies, Manners, Customs, and Events, Each of the Three Hundred and Sixty-Five Days, in Past and Present Times; Forming a Complete History of the Year, Months, and Seasons, and a Perpetual Key to the Almanac, Including Accounts of the Weather, Rules for Health and Conduct, Remarkable and Important Anecdotes, Facts, and Notices, in Chronology, Antiquities, Topography, Biography, Natural History, Art, Science, and General Literature; Derived from the Most Authentic Sources, and Valuable Original Communication, with Poetical Elucidations, for Daily Use and Diversion. Vol III.'', ed. William Hone, (London: 1838) p 314-16. Retrieved on 2008-06-12</ref>
==Guinness World Records==
The most torches extinguished in one minute with the mouth (using multiple rods) is 99 and was achieved by Bret Pasek (U.S.) at the Minnesota Renaissance Festival in Shakopee, Minnesota, on 7 September 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/fire-eating-most-torches-extinguished-in-one-minute/ |title=Fire eating – most torches extinguished in one minute |publisher=Guinnessworldrecords.com |date=2014-09-07 |accessdate=2015-03-03}}</ref>
The longest duration fire torch teething is 3 minutes 38.39 seconds and was achieved by Alexander Spitfire (U.S.) at Circo Draconum's Draco's Inferno in Hell's Kitchen Lounge Newark, New Jersey on August 30, 2015.
==Fire-eating tricks== While trick categories (vapor, transfers, extinguishes, etc.) are recognized by most, it is important to note that specific trick names may vary greatly depending on the region of the world in which the student learned.
===Vapor tricks=== Vapor tricks use the fuel vapors held in the mouth during or before an extinguish. * Cigarette light – light a cigarette with a Human Candle * Human candle – slowly feed a candle sized flame with vapors you hold * Vapor transfer – ignite one torch with the vapor from another * Moonshot – shoot vapors straight up * Fiery Kiss - Small amounts of fuel on the palm of the hand is ignited by a vapor pull, creating the effect of the performer blowing a kiss of fire.
===Transfers=== Transfers are methods of moving a flame from one area to another, by using the body, or another surface or medium. * Body transfers – transfer the flame from one torch to the other with parts of your body, e.g. arm, leg, chest, buttocks, toes etc. * Finger transfer – transfer the flame from one torch to the other with your fingers (most common form of transfer) * Fire floor transfer – transfer the flame from one torch to the other on the floor * Tongue transfer – transfer the flame from one torch to the other with your tongue
===Extinguishes=== Extinguishes are methods of extinguishing torches, and are the traditional hallmark of fire eating. * The Blow Out – Using breath control to extinguish * Multiple fire eat – basic fire eat with several torches at once * Flaming cotton ball extinguish – put out a cotton ball as you would a torch * Hand snuff – put the torch out by snuffing it with your hand * Jellyfish extinguish – pull the torch down out of the flame to extinguish it
===Others=== * Teething – hold a lit torch by the wick in your teeth * Immolation – passing any part of the body through the flame * Retention – Holding a lit fire torch by your hand with the lit wick within your mouth for an extended period of time * Straight snuff – Fire eating whilst keeping your head level * Tongue rest – Letting the lit wick of a fire torch rest on the tongue * Shotgun – lighting a trail of fuel on the body to light an unlit fire torch. * Slow burn – Very slowly dragging a lit fire torch on the skin
==See also== * [[Fire breathing]] * [[Fire performance]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Brushwood |first=Brian |authorlink=Brian Brushwood|title=Professional's Guide to Fire Eating |year=2002 |publisher=Bizarre Magic, Inc. |isbn=978-0-9713646-0-8 |pages=170 |oclc=224122749 }} <!-- ASIN 0971364605 --> * {{cite book | last=Mannix |first= Daniel P. |authorlink= Daniel P. Mannix |title=Step right up!| publisher=Harper |location= New York|year=1951 |pages=270| oclc= 529468}}
==External links== {{Commons|Fire eater}} * [http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/Penn-Jillette-Reveals-the-Secrets-of-Fire-Eating-179731871.html Penn Jillette Reveals the Secrets of Fire-Eating, Smithsonian Magazine, December 2012]

game|Single-player]] }} '''''Forgotton Anne''''' is an [[Independent game|indie]] [[adventure game|adventure]]-[[platform game|platformer]] video game developed by ThroughLine Games and published by [[Square Enix|Square Enix Collective]].{{cite web|url=https://nordic.ign.com/xbox-one-gaming-hardware/9265/preview/forgotton-anne-lets-you-play-anime-in-a-new-way|title=Forgotton Anne Lets You Play Anime in a New Way|last=DeFreitas|first=Casey|date=2018-01-10|work=[[IGN]] Nordic|accessdate=2018-03-14}}{{cite web|url=https://www.pcgamer.com/forgotton-anne-is-an-indie-game-that-looks-like-a-studio-ghibli-movie/|title=Forgotton Anne is an indie game that looks like a Studio Ghibli movie|last=Yarwood|first=Jack|date=2017-10-26|work=[[PC Gamer]]|accessdate=2018-03-14}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pushsquare.com/news/2017/08/gamescom_2017_remember_forgotton_anne_with_ps4_story_trailer|title=Gamescom 2017: Remember Forgotton Anne with PS4 Story Remember|last=Loeffler|first=Jordan|date=2017-09-29|work=DualShockers|accessdate=2018-03-14}}{{cite web|url=http://jstationx.com/2017/08/29/adventure-game-forgotton-anne-story-trailer/|title=Beautiful One]], and [[PlayStation 4]].{{cite web|url=https://www.pcgamer.com/beautiful-ghibli-inspired-adventure-game-forgotton-anne-comes-out-next-month/|title=Beautiful Ghibli-inspired adventure game Forgotton Anne out next month|last=Wood|first=Austin|date=2018-04-12|work=PC Gamer|accessdate=2018-04-26}} ''Forgotton Anne'' takes place in a fictional world called Forgotten Lands, a magical parallel universe where lost objects — everything from missing socks to discarded lamps — come to life, hoping one day that they might be remembered again and returned to the real world.{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/5/15/17357202/forgotton-anne-indie-game-ps4-xbox-ghibli|title=This gorgeous indie game is like a Ghibli film brought to life|last=Webster|first=Andrew|date=2018-05-15|work=[[The Verge]]|accessdate=2018-05-20}} The player controls Anne, an Enforcer who keeps order in the Forgotten Lands, who sets out to extinguish a rebellion that could prevent her master, Bonku, and herself from returning to the human world.{{cite web|url=https://www.forgottonanne.com/|title=Forgotton Anne - Cinematic Adventure Game (PS4, Xbox One, & PC)|work=Forgotton Anne|accessdate=2018-05-20}} {{clear}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = (PC) 76/100{{cite web |url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/forgotton-anne |title=Forgotton Anne for PC Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=May 29, 2018}}
(PS4) 78/100{{cite web |url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-4/forgotton-anne |title=Forgotton Anne for PlayStation 4 Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=May 29, 2018}}
(XONE) 83/100{{cite web |url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-one/forgotton-anne |title=Forgotton Anne for Xbox One Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=May 29, 2018}}}} Since its release ''Forgotton Anne'' has received "generally favorable reviews" on [[Metacritic]], across PC, PS4 and Xbox One. The game was nominated for "Original Song" with "Forgotten Anne" at the [[9th Hollywood Music in Media Awards]],{{cite web|url=https://www.hmmawards.com/2018-music-in-visual-media-nominations/|title=2018 Music in Visual Media Nominations|website=[[Hollywood Music in Media Awards]]|accessdate=November 14, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.hmmawards.com/2018-hmma-winners/|title=2018 HMMA WINNERS|website=[[Hollywood Music in Media Awards]]|date=November 14, 2018|accessdate=November 15, 2018}} and for "Best Storytelling" at the 2018 [[Golden Joystick Awards]].{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/gaming/news/golden-joysticks-2018-nominees-announced-voting-open-now/|title=Golden Joysticks 2018 nominees announced, voting open now|last=Hoggins|first=Tom|date=September 24, 2018|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=October 6, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.gamesradar.com/golden-joystick-awards-2018-winners/|title=Golden Joystick Awards 2018 winners: God of War wins big but Fortnite gets Victory Royale|last=Sheridan|first=Connor|date=November 16, 2018|website=[[GamesRadar+]]|accessdate=November 17, 2018}} {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official|https://www.forgottonanne.com/}} *[https://www.throughlinegames.com/ Developer website] [[Category:2018 video games]] [[Category:Adventure games]] [[Category:Fantasy video games]] [[Category:Indie video games]] [[Category:Nintendo Switch games]] [[Category:Platform games]] [[Category:PlayStation 4 games]] [[Category:Square Enix games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Denmark]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox One games]] {{videogame-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Audrey Hepburn and gamines of the 1950s */Updated Jean Simmons death year
revision.text:
{{other uses}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} [[File:Audrey Hepburn screentest in Roman Holiday trailer.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Audrey Hepburn]] has been cited as the epitome of a gamine.]] A '''gamine''' is a slim, elegant young woman who is, or is perceived to be, mischievous, teasing or sexually appealing.
The word ''gamine'' is a French word, the feminine form of ''gamin'', originally meaning [[Street Urchin|urchin]], [[waif]] or playful, naughty child. It was used in English from about the mid-19th century (for example, by [[William Makepeace Thackeray]] in 1840 in one of his Parisian sketches), but in the 20th century, came to be applied in its more modern sense.
== Lexicography == In 1997 the publisher [[HarperCollins]] drew up a list of 101 words – one a year – that defined the years 1896 to 1997.<ref>See ''The Times'', 3 November 1997</ref> "Gamine" was chosen for 1899, being described by Philip Howard in ''[[The Times]]'' as follows:
{{quote|An [[elf]]ish young woman. [[Audrey Hepburn]] in ''[[Roman Holiday (1953 film)|Roman Holiday]]'' was the archetypal, unforgettable, adorable gamine.<ref>''The Times'', 3 November 1997</ref>}}
''Gamine'' has been used particularly of such women in the performing arts or world of fashion. In that context, the closest English word – of [[Anglo-Norman langauge|Anglo-Norman]] origin – is probably "waif" (although "gamine" is often seen as conveying an additional sense of style and [[chic (style)|chic]]). For example, in a press release of 1964, impresario [[Andrew Oldham]] described the 17-year-old singer [[Marianne Faithfull]] as "shy, wistful, waif-like";<ref>''Faithfull – An Autobiography'', 1994</ref> and writer and musician John Amis referred to German-born actress [[Luise Rainer]] (b. 1910) as [[Paul Muni]]'s "waif-wife" in the 1937 film, ''[[The Good Earth (film)|The Good Earth]]''.<ref>''The Oldie'', August 2006</ref>
''Gaminerie'' has sometimes been used in English with reference to the behaviour or characteristics of gamin(e)s.
== In silent films == In the early 20th century, [[silent films]] brought to public attention a number of actresses who sported a gamine look. These included the Canadian-born [[Mary Pickford]] (1892–1979), who became known as "America’s Sweetheart" and, with her husband [[Douglas Fairbanks]], was one of the founders of the film production company [[United Artists]]; [[Lillian Gish]] (1893–1993), notably in ''[[Way Down East]]'' (1920); and [[Louise Brooks]] (1906–86), whose short [[bob cut|bobbed]] [[hairstyles, eponymous|hairstyle]], widely copied in the 1920s, came to be regarded as both a gamine and a "[[boho-chic|Bohemian]]" trait (this style having first appeared among the Paris ''demi-monde'' before World War I and among London art students during the war.<ref>Virginia Nicholson (2002) ''Among the Bohemians''</ref>) In 1936, [[Charlie Chaplin]] cast his then-girlfriend [[Paulette Goddard]] (1910–1990) as an orphaned gamine (credited as "A Gamin") in one of his last silent films, ''[[Modern Times (film)|Modern Times]]''.
== Audrey Hepburn and gamines of the 1950s == In the 1950s "gamine" was applied notably to the style and appearance of the [[Belgium|Belgian]]-born actress [[Audrey Hepburn]] (1929–1993): for example, in the films, ''[[Sabrina (1954 film)|Sabrina]]'' (1954) and ''[[Funny Face]]'' (1957). Hepburn also played the role of the gamine Gigi in New York (1951) in the play of that name, based on the novel (1945) by [[Colette]], who had personally "talent-spotted" her when she was filming in [[Monte Carlo]].<ref>Judith Thurman (1999) ''Secrets of the Flesh – A Life of Colette''</ref> On film and in photographs, Hepburn’s short hair and petite figure created a distinct and enduring "look", well defined by Don Macpherson,<ref>''Stars of the Screen'' (Marks & Spencer, 1989)</ref> who cited her "naïveté which did not rule out sophistication", and described her as "the first gamine to be accepted as overpoweringly chic".
Other film actresses of the period regarded as gamines included [[Leslie Caron]] (b. 1931), who played the leading role in the 1958 musical film of ''[[Gigi (1958 film)|Gigi]]''; [[Jean Seberg]] (1938–79), best known in ''[[Bonjour Tristesse]]'' (1957) and [[Jean-Luc Godard]]’s ''[[Breathless (1960 film)|À bout de souffle]]'' (1960); [[Jean Simmons]] (1929-2010), for example, in ''Angel Face'' (1952); and [[Rita Tushingham]] (b. 1940), whose first starring role was in ''[[A Taste of Honey (film)|A Taste of Honey]]'' (1961). The French singer [[Juliette Greco]] (b. 1926), who emerged from [[Bohemian style#Post-Liberation Paris|Bohemian]] Paris in the late 1940s to become an international star in the 1950s, also had gamine qualities.
== 1960s and beyond == In many ways, the "gamine look" of the 1950s paved the way for the success of the following English models: [[Jean Shrimpton]] (b. 1942), one of the first to promote the [[mini-skirt]] in 1965; [[Twiggy]] (b. Lesley Hornby, 1949), who became "The Face of '66";<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/breakfast/4725427.stm "The face of '66"] ''BBC News''</ref> and [[Kate Moss]] (b. 1974), associated in the 1990s with the "[[waif]]" look and what, notably through an advertising campaign for [[Calvin Klein]] in 1997, became known as "[[heroin chic]]." Moss was part of a trend of "wafer" thin models which was satirized in [[Neil Kerber]]’s strip cartoon "Supermodels" in the magazine ''[[Private Eye]]''.
Gamines share similarities with the modern, cinematic "[[Manic Pixie Dream Girl]]" stock character.
== Other gamines == Others who have been described as gamines include Danish-French actress [[Anna Karina]] (b. 1940); American actresses [[Julia Roberts]] (b. 1967) (she was often compared to Audrey Hepburn at the start of her career), [[Edie Sedgwick]] (1943–1971), [[Elizabeth Hartman]] (1943–1987), [[Mia Farrow]] (b. 1945), [[Sissy Spacek]] (b. 1949), [[Winona Ryder]] (b. 1971),<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Traill-Nash|first1=Glynis|title=Cream of the gamine crop|journal=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=1 April 2007|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/film/cream-of-the-gamine-crop/2007/03/31/1174761805542.html|accessdate=29 August 2014}}</ref> [[Michelle Williams (actress)|Michelle Williams]] (b. 1980), [[Gwyneth Paltrow]] (b. 1972),<ref>[http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Calendar/Film?Film=oid%3A747453 The Austin Chronicle 2009-02-27]. Austinchronicle.com (27 February 2009). Retrieved on 18 October 2011.</ref> [[Calista Flockhart]] (b. 1964),<ref>[http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20125250,00.html People Magazine 11 May 1998]. People.com (11 May 1998). Retrieved on 18 October 2011.</ref> [[Bridget Fonda]] (b. 1964),<ref>{{cite book|last=Kael|first=Pauline|title=5001 Nights at the Movies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0NlZpWZn4JsC&pg=PA657|date=15 May 1991|publisher=Henry Holt and Company|isbn=978-0-8050-1367-2|page=657}}</ref> [[Mary Stuart Masterson]] (b. 1966),<ref>{{cite news|last1=McEnroe|first1=Colin|title=Casting About In A Sea Of Same-named Actresses|url=http://articles.courant.com/1992-01-27/features/0000206592_1_mary-magdalene-mary-renault-mary-alice-williams|accessdate=25 August 2014|work=Hartford Courant|date=27 January 1992}}</ref> [[Jennifer Jason Leigh]] (b. 1962),<ref>{{cite book|last=Lodge|first=David|title=Consciousness & the Novel: Connected Essays|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IuPzOOXEBJQC&pg=PA212|year=2002|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-00949-3|page=212}}</ref> and [[Ginnifer Goodwin]] (b. 1978); British actresses [[Carey Mulligan]] (b. 1985), [[Susannah York]] (1939–2011),<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/jan/16/susannah-york-dies-battle-cancer Susannah York, the gentle star of 1960s cinema, dies after battle against cancer | Film | guardian.co.uk]. Guardian. Retrieved on 18 October 2011.</ref> [[Suzanna Hamilton]] (b. 1960), [[Helena Bonham Carter]] (b. 1966), [[Elisabeth Sladen]] (1946-2011), [[Carole Ann Ford]] (b. 1940) <ref>[http://www.calendarlive.com/movies/reviews/cl-movie000091421nov16,0,6442030.story Movies – Movies, film, Hollywood, business, entertainment – latimes.com – latimes.com]. Calendarlive.com. Retrieved on 18 October 2011.</ref> [[Tara FitzGerald]] (b. 1967), [[Olivia Williams]] (b. 1968), [[Rachel Weisz]] (b. 1970),<ref>Richard Ward, ''She'', July 2005</ref> [[Keira Knightley]] (b. 1985),<ref>{{cite news|last=Hohenadel|first=Kristin|title=Summer Movies – Keira Knightley: Acting Without the Acting Out|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40C17F83A590C7A8CDDAC0894DC404482|work=New York Times|date=9 May 2004|access-date=September 30, 2017}}</ref> and [[Emma Watson]] (b. 1990);<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tookey|first1=Chris|title=Hermione's the new Hepburn!|journal=The Daily Mail|date=27 September 2012|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2209714/Emma-Watson-starring-role-Harry-Potter-The-Perks-Of-Being-A-Wallflower.html|accessdate=29 August 2014}}</ref> Portuguese actress [[Maria de Medeiros]] (b. 1965); French actresses [[Juliette Binoche]] (b. 1964), [[Audrey Tautou]] (b. 1976), and [[Vanessa Paradis]] (b. 1972); Israeli-American actress [[Natalie Portman]] (b. 1981); Canadian model [[Linda Evangelista]] (b. 1965);<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hochswender|first1=Woody|title=The Ultimate Marketplace – The Models and the Glamour Trade|work=The New York Times|date=12 November 1989|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/12/magazine/the-ultimate-marketplace-the-models-and-the-glamour-trade.html|accessdate=23 July 2014}}</ref> American models [[Kristen McMenamy]] (b. 1964)<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sajbel|first1=Maureen|title=Style : Spring Beauty : The Latest on Looks : Making Waifs|work=Los Angeles Times|date=4 April 1993|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-04-04/magazine/tm-18790_1_waifs|accessdate=15 August 2014}}</ref> and [[Tina Chow]] (1951–92) (whose "gamine look made her the darling of [photographers] [[Cecil Beaton]] and [[Arthur Elgort]]"<ref>''The Times'', 2 November 2006</ref>); Russian tennis player [[Anastasia Myskina]] (b. 1981); and American singer [[Cat Power]] (b. Chan Marshall, 1972) ("The French, in particular, took to her gamine looks and confused air"<ref>Sasha Frere-Jones, ''The New Yorker'', 10 December 2007</ref>).
[[Penelope Chetwode]] (1910–86), later Lady Betjeman, wife of the Poet Laureate, [[John Betjeman]], was described by Betjeman's biographer [[A. N. Wilson]] as "gamine of feature, but large-breasted".<ref>A. N. Wilson (2006) ''Betjeman''</ref> [[Corinne Bailey Rae]] alleged that she was called a gamine in her song, "Choux Pastry Heart" (2005).
Japanese 1990s J-Pop rock band vocalist Maki Watase was called a "spry gamine firecracker" in a review in the New Music Express.
=== In film === Among the notable gamine characters of film are Gelsomina, the street performer from ''[[La Strada]]'', played by [[Giulietta Masina]]; Bree Daniels, the prostitute played by [[Jane Fonda]] (b. 1937) in ''[[Klute]]'' (1971) (whose hairstyle was sometimes referred to as the "Klute shag"); Nikita ([[Anne Parillaud]], b. 1960), the titular [[Punk subculture|punkish]] [[Substance dependence|junkie]] in [[Luc Besson]]'s [[Nikita (film)|1990 film]]; and, most recently, Amélie (Audrey Tautou) in the [[Amélie|2001 romantic comedy of that name]].
==Notes== {{reflist|33em}}
==External links== *{{wiktionary-inline}}
[[Category:1950s fashion]] [[Category:20th-century fashion]] [[Category:Fashion aesthetics]] [[Category:Film and video terminology]]

revision.comment: /* See also */ add NASA's Commercial Lunar Payload Services. Remove a couple of insufficiently relevant entries
revision.text:
{{for|the visual phenomenon created on the Moon by lunar craters|Lunar x}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox award | name = Google Lunar XPRIZE | current_awards = | image = GoogleLunarXPRIZE Logo.png | imagesize = | alt = Google Lunar X Prize logo | caption = | description = "landing a robot on the surface of the Moon, traveling 500 meters over the lunar surface, and sending images and data back to the Earth." | presenter = [[X Prize Foundation]] (organizer),
[[Google]] (sponsor) | country = Worldwide | location = | reward = US$20 million for the winner,
US$5 million for second place,
US$4 million in technical bonuses,
US$1 million diversity award | year = | year2 = | holder = | website = [http://lunar.xprize.org/ lunar.xprize.org] }} [[File:Back to the Moon for Good (EN trailer).webm|thumb|Trailer for the prize.]] The '''Google Lunar XPRIZE''' ('''GLXP'''), sometimes referred to as '''Moon 2.0''',Is an incredible competition where countries compete to race to the Moon winning a prize money of $30 million dollars; organised by XPRIZE and sponsored by Google. {{cite web|title=Moon 2.0 Is The Next Mission For X Prize Group, And Google |publisher=[[Investor's Business Daily]] |url=http://www.wirednextfest.com/inform/press07/CNN_Money%209.13.07.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=12 April 2008 }}{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite news |last = Koman |first = Richard |title = Moon 2.0: Google Funds $30 Million Lunar X Prize |publisher = Newsfactor |date = 14 September 2007 |url = http://www.newsfactor.com/story.xhtml?story_id=03300316K1J9 |accessdate = 22 September 2007 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110516205835/http://www.newsfactor.com/story.xhtml?story_id=03300316K1J9 |archive-date = 16 May 2011 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }} was a 2007–2018 [[Inducement prize contest|inducement prize]] [[space competition]] organized by the [[X Prize Foundation]], and sponsored by [[Google]]. The challenge called for [[Private spaceflight|privately funded]] teams to be the first to land a robotic spacecraft on [[Moon|the Moon]], [[Lunar rover|travel]] 500 meters, and transmit back to Earth high-definition video and images.{{Cite web|title = Overview|url = http://lunar.xprize.org/about/overview|website = Google Lunar XPRIZE|accessdate = 18 February 2016|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160303201424/http://lunar.xprize.org/about/overview|archivedate = 3 March 2016|df = dmy-all}} In 2015, [[X Prize Foundation|XPRIZE]] announced that the competition deadline would be extended to December 2017 if at least one team could secure a verified launch contract by 31 December 2015.{{Cite web|title = Deadline For $30 Million Google Lunar XPRIZE Extended To End of 2017|url = http://lunar.xprize.org/news/deadline-30-million-google-lunar-xprize-extended-end-of-2017|website = Google Lunar XPRIZE|access-date = 18 February 2016}} Two teams secured such a launch contract, and the deadline was extended.{{Cite web|title = Israeli Google Lunar XPRIZE Team Is First to Sign Launch Agreement For Private Mission to the Moon on SpaceX Falcon 9|url = http://lunar.xprize.org/press-release/israeli-google-lunar-xprize-team-first-sign-launch-agreement-private-mission|website = Google Lunar XPRIZE|accessdate = 18 February 2016}} In August 2017, the deadline was extended again, to 31 March 2018.{{cite news|url=https://www.space.com/37813-google-lunar-x-prize-deadline-extended-march-2018.html|title=Deadline for Google Lunar X Prize Moon Race Extended Through March 2018|last=Wall|first=Mike|date=16 Aug 2017|work=space.com|accessdate=19 September 2017}} Entering 2018, five teams remained in the competition: [[SpaceIL]],{{Cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/1.767535|title=Israel’s SpaceIL One of Five Finalists in Global Race to the Moon|last=TheMarker|date=2017|work=Haaretz|access-date=12 September 2017|language=en}} [[Moon Express]], [[Synergy Moon]], [[Team Indus]], and Team [[Hakuto]],{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/01/24/technology/google-lunar-xprize-competitors/index.html|title=Meet the 5 finalists in the Google XPrize moonshot|last=Wattles|first=Jackie|work=CNNMoney|access-date=12 September 2017}} having secured verified launch contracts with [[Spaceflight Industries]], [[Rocket Lab]], [[Interorbital Systems]], and [[ISRO]] (jointly for the last two teams).{{Cite web|title = XPRIZE Verifies Moon Express Launch Contract, Kicking Off New Space Race|url = http://lunar.xprize.org/press-release/xprize-verifies-moon-express-launch-contract-kicking-new-space-race|website = Google Lunar XPRIZE|accessdate = 18 February 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://lunar.xprize.org/press-release/xprize-verifies-launch-agreement-team-synergy-moon-third-google-lunar-xprize|title=SYNERGY MOON Team Member Interorbital Systems to Serve as Launch Provider|publisher=Google Lunar XPRIZE|date=30 August 2016|accessdate=8 September 2016}} On 23 January 2018, the X Prize Foundation announced that "no team would be able to make a launch attempt to reach the Moon by the [31 March 2018] deadline... and the US$30 million Google Lunar XPRIZE will go unclaimed."https://www.space.com/39467-google-lunar-xprize-moon-race-ends.htmlhttps://lunar.xprize.org/news/blog/important-update-google-lunar-xprize On 5 April 2018, the X Prize Foundation announced that the Lunar XPRIZE would continue as a non-cash competition.{{cite news|last1=Potenza|first1=Alessanda|title=X Prize relaunches its Moon competition, but without a cash prize|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/4/5/17201902/lunar-xprize-relaunch-google-private-moon-missions|accessdate=15 April 2018|date=5 April 2018}} ==Competition summary== The Google Lunar XPRIZE was announced at the [[Wired (magazine)#NextFest|Wired Nextfest]] on 13 September 2007. {{Cite journal | last = Reiss | first = Spencer | title = Google Offers $20 Million X Prize to Put Robot on Moon | publisher = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | volume=15 | issue=10 | date = 13 September 2007 | url = https://www.wired.com/science/space/magazine/15-10/ff_moon | accessdate = 16 September 2007 | postscript = }} The competition offered a total of US$30 million in prizes to the first privately funded teams to land a robot on the Moon that successfully travels more than 500 meters (1,640 ft) and transmits back high-definition images and video. The first team to do so would have claimed the US$20 million grand prize; while the second team to accomplish the same tasks would have been awarded a US$5 million second prize.{{Cite web|title = Guidelines|url = http://lunar.xprize.org/about/guidelines|website = Google Lunar XPRIZE|access-date = 18 February 2016}} Teams also earned additional money by completing additional tasks beyond the baseline requirements required to win the grand or second prize, such as traveling ten times the baseline requirements (greater than 5,000 meters (3 mi)), capturing images of the remains of [[Apollo program]] hardware or other man-made objects on the Moon, verifying from the lunar surface the recent detection of water ice on the Moon, or surviving a lunar night. Additionally, a US$1 million diversity award was to be given to teams that make significant strides in promoting ethnic diversity in [[STEM fields]]. To provide an added incentive for teams to complete their missions quickly, it was announced that the prize would decrease from US$20 million to US$15 million whenever a government-led mission lands on and explores the lunar surface.{{cite web|title=About the Google Lunar XPRIZE|url=http://www.googlelunarxprize.org/prize-details|accessdate=3 December 2011}} However, in November 2013, the organizers and the teams agreed to drop this rule, as the launch of the Chinese [[Chang'e 3]] probe—which landed on the Moon in December 2013—approached.{{cite web|url=http://www.googlelunarxprize.org/blog/new-player-return-moon|title=A New Player in the Return to the Moon|publisher=Google Lunar XPRIZE |date=13 November 2013}} In 2015, [[X Prize Foundation|XPRIZE]] announced that the competition deadline would be extended to December 2017 if at least one team could secure a verified launch contract by 31 December 2015. Two teams secured such a launch contract, and the deadline was extended. XPRIZE announced 5 finalists on 24 January 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://lunar.xprize.org/news/blog/meet-5-teams-are-launching-moon-year|title=Meet The 5 Teams That Are Launching To The Moon This Year|date=24 January 2017|newspaper=Google Lunar XPRIZE|language=en|access-date=24 January 2017}} [[SpaceIL]], [[Moon Express]], [[Synergy Moon]], [[Team Indus]], and [[Hakuto]] having secured verified launch contracts for 2017 (with [[SpaceX]], [[Rocket Lab]], [[Interorbital Systems]] and [[Isro|ISRO]] respectively). All other teams had until the end of 2016 to secure a verified launch contract, but failed to meet this deadline.{{Cite web|title = FAQ|url = http://lunar.xprize.org/about/faq#toc-when-are-launches-happening-|website = Google Lunar XPRIZE|accessdate = 18 February 2016}} The Google Lunar XPRIZE expired on 31 March 2018 as none of the five final teams were able to launch their vehicles by the deadline. Another extension of the deadline was ruled out by Google,{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/22/google-will-not-extend-lunar-xprize-deadline.html|title=Google's $20 million race to the moon will end with no winner — and Google is OK with that|last=Sheetz|first=Michael|date=2018-01-22|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-01-23}} and the prize went unclaimed.{{Cite news|url=https://www.space.com/39467-google-lunar-xprize-moon-race-ends.html|title=Ex-Prize: Google's $30 Million Moon Race Ends with No Winner|work=Space.com|access-date=2018-01-23}} ==Overview== [[Peter Diamandis]], the project founder, wrote on the official web page in 2007: {{cquote|It has been many decades since we explored the Moon from the lunar surface, and it could be another 6–8 years before any government returns. Even then, it will be at a large expense, and probably with little public involvement.{{cite web |url=http://www.googlelunarxprize.org/ |title=A Word From the Founders of X Prize & Google |accessdate=16 September 2007 }}}} The goal of the Google Lunar X Prize was similar to that of the [[Ansari X Prize]]: to inspire a new generation of private investment in hopes of developing more cost-effective technologies and materials to overcome many limitations of space exploration that are currently taken for granted. ==History== The Google Lunar XPRIZE was announced in 2007.{{cite news |last1 = Laursen|first1 = Lucas|title = Google Lunar Race Teams Discuss Next Steps, House on the Moon|url = http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/aerospace/robotic-exploration/google-lunar-x-prize-summit|accessdate = 12 June 2014|publisher = IEEE Spectrum|date = 5 June 2014}} ===Origin of the prize=== [[File:Carnegie Mellon University Google Lunar X-Prize Moon Rover.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Carnegie Mellon University]] lunar rover]] Similar to the way in which the [[Ansari X Prize|Ansari XPRIZE]] was formed, the Google Lunar XPRIZE was created out of a former venture of Peter Diamandis to achieve a similar goal. Dr Diamandis served as CEO of [[BlastOff! Corporation]], a commercial initiative to land a robotic spacecraft on the Moon as a mix of entertainment, internet, and space. Although it was ultimately unsuccessful, the BlastOff! initiative paved the way for the Google Lunar X Prize.{{cite web|title=Origin of the prize|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G-zGwqO5BwY|publisher=[[X Prize Foundation]]|accessdate=23 February 2008}} Initially, [[NASA]] was the planned sponsor and the prize purse was just US$20 million. As NASA is a federal agency of the United States government, and thus funded by US tax money, the prize would only have been available to teams from the United States. The original intention was to propose the idea to other national space agencies, including the [[European Space Agency]] and the [[JAXA|Japanese space agency]], in the hope that they would offer similar prize purses.{{cite web|title=Is it true that originally the Google Lunar X Prize was going to be the NASA Lunar X Prize (or the ESA or similar)? |url=http://thelaunchpad.xprize.org/2011/02/is-it-true-that-originally-google-lunar.html|publisher=[[X Prize Foundation]]|accessdate=19 February 2011}} However, budget setbacks stopped NASA from sponsoring the prize. Peter Diamandis then presented the idea to [[Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]], co-founders of Google, at an [[X Prize Foundation|XPRIZE]] fundraiser. They agreed to sponsor it, and also to increase the prize purse to US$30 million, allowing for a second place prize, as well as bonus prizes.{{when|date=June 2014}} ===Extensions of the deadline=== The prize was originally announced in 2007 as "a contest to put a robotic rover on the Moon by 2012," with a $20 million prize to the winner if the landing was achieved by 2012; the prize decreased to $15M until the end of 2014, at which point the contest would conclude. The five-year deadline was optimistic about schedule. Jeff Foust commented in ''Space Review'' that as the end of 2012 approached, "no team appeared that close to mounting a reasonable bid to win it."Jeff Foust, [http://www.thespacereview.com/article/2164/1 "The Google Lunar X PRIZE at five: can it still be won?]" ''The Space Review'', 1 October 2012 (accessed 25 July 2013) In 2010, the deadline was extended by one year, with the prize to expire at the end of December 2015, and the reduction of the grand prize from $20 million to $15 million changed from originally 2012 to "if a government mission successfully lands on the lunar surface." On 16 December 2014, XPRIZE announced another extension in the prize deadline from 31 December 2015 to 31 December 2016.{{cite web|url=http://lunar.xprize.org/press-release/deadline-30-million-google-lunar-xprize-extended-end-of-2016|title=Deadline For $30 Million Google Lunar XPRIZE Extended To End of 2016|date=16 December 2014|publisher=lunar.xprize.org}} In May 2015, the foundation announced another extension of the deadline. The deadline for winning the prize was now December 2017, but contingent on at least one team showing by 31 December 2015 that they have a secured contract for launch. On 9 October 2015, team [[SpaceIL]] announced their officially verified launch contract with [[SpaceX]], therefore extending the competition until the end of 2017. On 16 August 2017, the deadline was extended again, to 31 March 2018. nasaspaceflight.com None of the remaining teams were be able to claim the Google X-Prize money due to the inability to launch before the final deadline. ===Objections to the Heritage Bonus Prizes=== Some observers have raised objections to the inclusion of the two "Heritage Bonus Prizes," particularly the Apollo Heritage Bonus Prize, which was to award an additional estimated US$1 million to the first group that successfully delivers images and videos of the landing site of one of the [[Apollo Program]] landing sites, such as [[Tranquility Base]], after landing on the lunar surface.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/la-oe-walsh1-2009jun01,0,5840745.story|title=Space archaeology|first1=Jill|last1=Thomas|first2=Justin St P.|last2=Walsh|date=1 June 2009|publisher=|via=LA Times}} Such sites are widely regarded as archaeologically and culturally significant, and some have expressed concern that a team attempting to win this heritage bonus might inadvertently damage or destroy such a site, either during the landing phase of the mission, or by piloting a rover around the site.{{cite web|last=Billings|first=Lee |url=http://seedmagazine.com/content/article/preserving_tranquility/ |title=Billings, Lee, "Should the Sites of Lunar Landings Be Protected as PArt of our Cultural Inheritance?" |publisher=SEED |date=28 October 2008 |accessdate=19 February 2011}} As a result, some archaeologists went on record calling for the Foundation to cancel the heritage bonus and to ban groups from targeting landing zones within {{convert|100|km|sp=us}} of previous sites.[http://www.hdtvtotal.com/module-pagesetter-viewpub-tid-1-pid-1393.html "uncomPRESSed: Google Lunar X PRIZE – William Pomerantz"] Andreas -horn- Hornig, HDTVTotal.com, 1 August 2010 In turn, the Foundation noted that, as part of the competition's educational goals, these bonuses fostered debate about how to respectfully visit previous lunar landing sites, but that it does not see itself as the appropriate adjudicator of such an internationally relevant and interdisciplinary issue. This response left detractors unsatisfied.{{cite web|last=Matson |first=John |url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/blog/60-second-science/post.cfm?id=can-space-faring-companies-be-entru-2009-06-09 |title=Matson, John, "Can space-faring companies be entrusted with the Apollo program's history?," Scientific American, "60-Second Science," Comments, 9 June 2009 |publisher=Scientificamerican.com |date=9 June 2009 |accessdate=15 December 2010}} The Foundation pointed to the historical precedent set by the [[Apollo 12]] mission, which landed nearby the previous [[Surveyor 3]] robotic probe. [[Pete Conrad]] and [[Alan Bean]] approached and inspected Surveyor 3 and even removed some parts from it to be returned to Earth for study; new scientific results from that heritage visit, on the exposure of manmade objects to conditions in outer space, were still being published in leading papers nearly four decades later.{{cite web|url=https://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2008/20jun_apollorelic/ |title=Apollo Relic Reveals its Secrets |publisher=NASA |date=20 June 2008 |accessdate=19 February 2011}} However, as Surveyor 3 and Apollo 12 were both NASA missions, there was no controversy at the time. In January 2011, NASA's manager for lunar commercial space noted on Twitter that work was underway to provide insight and guidelines on how lunar heritage sites could be protected while still allowing visitations that could yield critical science.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/rmkelso/status/28216037832925184 |title=Twitter / @Rob Kelso – Great meeting yesterday at ... |publisher=NASA |date=20 January 2011 |accessdate=19 February 2011}} And in July 2011, NASA issued ''Recommendations to Space-Faring Entities: How to Protect and Preserve the Historic and Scientific Value of U.S. Government Lunar Artifacts''.{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/pdf/617743main_NASA-USG_LUNAR_HISTORIC_SITES_RevA-508.pdf |title=Recommendations to Space-Faring Entities: How to Protect and Preserve the Historic and Scientific Value of U.S. Government Lunar Artifacts |author=[[NASA]] |orig-year=First published 20 July 2011 |date=28 October 2011 |access-date=11 December 2017}} These guidelines were developed with the assistance of Beth O'Leary, an anthropology professor at New Mexico State University in Las Cruces, and a recognized leader in the emerging field of [[space archaeology]].{{cite web|url=https://www.space.com/13346-nasa-guidelines-protect-apollo-moon-landing-sites.html|title=NASA Sets Guidelines to Preserve Apollo Moon Landing Sites|publisher=}} However, these are only guidelines and recommendations and are not enforceable beyond the possibility of "moral sanctions."{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/10/science/space/a-push-for-historic-preservation-on-the-moon.html|title=A Push for Historic Preservation on the Moon|first=Kenneth|last=Chang|date=23 January 2018|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}} An organization called [[For All Moonkind, Inc.]] is now working to develop an international treaty that will include enforceable provisions designed to manage access to the Apollo sites and protect and preserve those sites, as well as others on the Moon, as the common heritage of all humankind.{{cite web|url=http://forallmoonkind.org/|title=For All Moonkind - Preserving Our First Off World Footsteps|website=forallmoonkind.org}} Nevertheless, some of the Apollo astronauts themselves have expressed support for the bonus, with [[Apollo 11]] Moonwalker [[Buzz Aldrin]] appearing at the Google Lunar XPRIZE's initial announcement and reading a plaque signed by the majority of his fellow surviving Apollo Astronauts.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=35qjYeddq9k |title=Buzz Aldrin at the Google Lunar X PRIZE Launch |publisher=X PRIZE Foundation |date=22 July 2009 |accessdate=19 February 2011}} ===Prize not won=== On 23 January 2018, the X Prize Foundation announced that "no team would be able to make a launch attempt to reach the Moon by the [31 March 2018] deadline... and the {{USD|30 million}} Google Lunar XPRIZE will go unclaimed." {{cite news |last=Foust|first=Jeff |url=http://spacenews.com/google-lunar-x-prize-to-end-without-winner/ |title=Google Lunar X Prize to end without winner |work=[[SpaceNews]] |date=2018-01-23 |accessdate=2018-01-24 |quote=The foundation running the Google Lunar X Prize announced Jan. 23 that the $20 million grand prize for a commercial lunar lander will expire at the end of March without a winner. The X Prize Foundation said none of its five finalist teams would be able to launch a mission before the current deadline of March 31. That deadline has been extended several times in the past, but foundation officials previously said there would be no further extensions of the competition. }} ==Competitors== Registration in the Google Lunar X Prize closed by 31 December 2010. The complete roster of 32 teams was announced in February 2011. By January 2017, there were just five officially registered Google Lunar X Prize teams continuing to pursue the prize objectives, as other teams had left the competition entirely, failed to achieve a competition interim [[Milestone (project management)|milestone]], or merged with other teams:{{cite web|url=http://lunar.xprize.org/news/blog/meet-5-teams-are-launching-moon-year|title=Meet The 5 Teams That Are Launching To The Moon This Year|date=24 January 2017|publisher=}} Initially 32 teams were registered, with 16 teams having actively participated in all activities and only 5 teams satisfying the rule requiring a verified launch contract by 31 December 2016.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! background: rgb(255,180,180)" | withdrawn |{{cite web|url=http://www.googlelunarxprize.org/lunar/teams/advaeros/about |title=Advaeros – About Us | X PRIZE Foundation |publisher=Googlelunarxprize.org |date=15 August 2007 |accessdate=15 December 2010}} |- | 34 | US | LunaTrex | | | style="text-align: center; background: rgb(255,180,180)" | not registered{{cite web|url=http://propertyintangible.com/2011/01/lunatrex-out-of-race.html|title=LunaTrex Out of the Race|date=9 January 2011|publisher=}} |{{cite web|url=http://www.googlelunarxprize.org/teams/lunatrex/blog/lunatrex-announces-entry-into-glxp|title=LunaTrex Blog - Google Lunar XPRIZE|publisher=}} |} Shortly after the announcement of the complete roster of teams, an X Prize Foundation official noted that a total of thirty one teams entered a partial registration program by filing a "Letter of Intent" to compete; of these, twenty did indeed register or join other registered teams, while eleven ultimately did not register. {{cite web|title=The Launch Pad: Well, let's start: How many LOI teams were there?|publisher=[[X PRIZE Foundation]]|url=http://thelaunchpad.xprize.org/2011/02/well-let-start-how-many-lois-were-there.html|accessdate=19 February 2011}} ==Terrestrial Milestone Prizes== ===Overview=== In November 2013 the X-Prize organization announced that several milestone prizes will be awarded to teams for demonstrating key technologies prior to the actual mission. A total of {{USD|6 million}} was awarded throughout 2014 for achieving the following milestones:{{cite web|url=http://www.googlelunarxprize.org/prize-details/milestone-prizes|title=Regulations – Milestone Prizes|publisher=Google Lunar X-Prize}} * $1 million (for up to 3 teams) for the ''Lander System Milestone Prize'' to demonstrate hardware and software that enables a soft-landing on the Moon. * $500,000 (for up to 4 teams) for the ''Mobility Subsystem Milestone Prize'' to demonstrate a mobility system that allows the craft to move 500 meters after landing. * $250,000 (for up to 4 teams) for the ''Imaging Subsystem Milestone Prize'' for producing "Mooncasts" consisting of high-quality images and video on the lunar surface. ===Selected teams=== In February 2014, a judging panel selected five teams which could compete for several interim prizes based on their proposals to achieve particular goals. The teams and their ultimate awards were:{{cite web|url=http://www.googlelunarxprize.org/media/press-releases/google-lunar-xprize-selects-five-teams-compete-6-million-milestone-prizes|title=Google Lunar XPRIZE Selects Five Teams to Compete for $6 Million in Milestone Prizes|publisher=googlelunarxprize.org|date=19 February 2014}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! Team ! Landing
($1 million) ! Mobility
($500,000) ! Imaging
($250,000) ! Total Prize Awarded |- | style="text-align: left;" | [[Astrobotic Technology|Astrobotic]] | style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | awarded | style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | awarded | style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | awarded | $1,750,000{{cite web|url=http://lunar.xprize.org/press-release/private-moon-race-heats-five-google-lunar-xprize-teams-take-home-525-million-key|title=Private Moon Race Heats Up As Five Google Lunar XPRIZE Teams Take Home $5.25 Million For Key Technological Advancements|publisher=lunar.xprize.org|date=26 January 2015}} |- | style="text-align: left;" | [[Moon Express]] | style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | awarded | style="background-color: #ffcccc;" | not awarded | style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | awarded | $1,250,000 |- | style="text-align: left;" | [[Team Indus]] | style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | awarded | style="background-color: #eeeeee;" | ''not selected'' | style="background-color: #ffcccc;" | not awarded | $1,000,000 |- | style="text-align: left;" | [[PTScientists|Part-Time Scientists]] | style="background-color: #eeeeee;" | ''not selected'' | style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | awarded | style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | awarded | $750,000 |- | style="text-align: left;" | [[Hakuto]] | style="background-color: #eeeeee;" | ''not selected'' | style="background-color: #ccffcc;" | awarded | style="background-color: #eeeeee;" | ''not selected'' | $500,000 |} The five selected teams were required to accomplish the milestones outlined in their submissions through testing and mission simulations, in order to be awarded the interim prizes. The teams had until October 2014 to complete the prize requirements. The winners were officially awarded on 26 January 2015 in San Francisco. == Teams with confirmed launch contracts as of the end of 2016 == Teams were required to have verified launch contracts by the end of 2016 in order to remain in the competition. Although the contest ended without a winner, some of these teams have expressed an intention to launch in the future. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Team(s) ! Planned launch date ! Launch vehicle ! Notes |- | [[Moon Express]] || || [[Rocket Lab]] [[Electron (rocket)|Electron]] || Moon Express's launch contract with Rocket Lab was verified by Google Lunar X Prize in December 2015.{{cite web |last1=Foust|first1=Jeff |title=X Prize Verifies Moon Express Launch Contract |url=http://spacenews.com/x-prize-verifies-moon-express-launch-contract/ |website=Space News|publisher=Space News |accessdate=29 June 2017 |date=8 December 2015}} Rocket Lab launched its first Electron rocket unsuccessfully in May 2017; its second launch reached orbit in January 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/348550/rocket-launch-marks-new-era-of-access-to-space|title=Rocket launch 'marks new era of access to space'|date=22 January 2018|publisher=}} A few weeks after the end of the monetary part of the Google prize (Jan 2018), Moon Express stated their hopes for funding from NASA's 2019 budget, for a collaborative launch of the planned [[International Lunar Observatory]].https://www.facebook.com/MoonExpress/photos/pb.151587294883933.-2207520000.1529361950./1956093747766603/?type=3&theater |- | [[SpaceIL]] || early 2019 || [[SpaceX]] [[Falcon 9 v1.1|Falcon 9]] || In July 2018, SpaceIL and the government-owned [[Israel Aerospace Industries]] announced their plan to use a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket provided by [[Spaceflight Industries]], launching in December 2018. The date was later changed to early 2019.{{cite news |last1=Baumer |first1=Lilach |title=SpaceIL Pushes Back Moon Launch Date to Early 2019 |url=https://www.calcalistech.com/ctech/articles/0,7340,L-3747450,00.html |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=CTech |date=11 October 2018}}{{cite news |last1=David |first1=Leonard |title=Israel Aims to Launch Moon Lander in December |url=https://www.space.com/41129-israel-launching-moon-mission-december.html |accessdate=25 July 2018 |work=Space.com |date=11 July 2018}}{{cite news |last1=Boyle |first1=Alan |title=Israeli moon lander to ride SpaceX rocket in Spaceflight’s first move beyond low Earth orbit |url=https://www.geekwire.com/2018/spaceil-moon-spaceflight-ssl-spacex/ |accessdate=11 September 2018 |work=GeekWire |date=11 September 2018}} |- | [[Synergy Moon]] || || [[Interorbital Systems]] Neptune || In August 2016, the Synergy Moon team had partnered with Interorbital Systems which was working on both a new "launch vehicle and launch process," and were hoping to launch their first rocket by the end of 2017. |- | [[TeamIndus]] || || [[Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle|PSLV-XL]] || [[Antrix Corporation]], the commercial arm of [[Indian Space Research Organisation|ISRO]] signed the deal with Team Indus. The launch contract had been officially verified by Google Lunar X Prize in November 2016.{{cite web |url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/team-indus-gets-slot-on-pslv-rocket-for-its-journey-to-moon-116110200836_1.html | title=Team Indus gets slot on PSLV rocket for its journey to moon | work=[[Business Standard]] | date=2 November 2016 | accessdate=4 November 2016 | author=Alnoor Peermohamed & Raghu Krishnan}} The contract for launch vehicle was cancelled in early 2018.{{cite web | url=https://inc42.com/buzz/google-lunar-xprize-teamindus-isro/ | title=Google Lunar Xprize: ISRO Calls Off Contract With TeamIndus | work=Inc42| date=9 January 2018 | accessdate=20 January 2018 | author=Suprita Anupam}} |- | [[Hakuto]]
→ [[ispace (Japanese company)|ispace]] || 2020 || SpaceX Falcon 9 || Hakuto was to have been a piggyback on [[TeamIndus]]'s [[PSLV]] flight. Contract for launch vehicle was cancelled in early 2018. In September 2018, Hakuto's parent company ispace announced a launch planned for 2020.{{cite web |last1=Grush |first1=Loren |title=Japanese company ispace says it will launch two missions to the Moon in 2020 and 2021 |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/9/26/17904898/ispace-hakuto-r-spacex-falcon-9-rocket-lunar-lander-rover |website=The Verge |accessdate=28 September 2018}} |} ===Other teams=== Three other competitors who were unable to get a verified launch contract by 31 December 2016, leading their disqualification from Google Lunar X Prize, are also still planning to launch their crafts independently. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Team(s) ! Planned launch date ! Launch vehicle ! Notes |- | [[PTScientists]] || 2019 || [[SpaceX Falcon 9]] || The proposed landing site is in the Taurus-Littrow valley, about two miles from the site of the final Apollo 17 mission.{{cite news |last1=Foust |first1=Jeff |title=Former Google Lunar X Prize teams still working on lunar landers |url=https://spacenews.com/former-google-lunar-x-prize-teams-still-working-on-lunar-landers/ |accessdate=8 November 2018 |work=SpaceNews |date=November 6, 2018}} |-It would deploy two rovers with the aim of tracking down NASA's moon buggy which was left behind by Gene Cernan, the last man on the Moon. The team is keen to find out how well the buggy has survived on the lunar surface for more than four decades. |- | [[Astrobotic]] || 2020 || [[United Launch Alliance|ULA]] [[Atlas V]] || Lander is called "Peregrine Lunar Lander".{{cite news |url=http://www.spaceflightinsider.com/missions/commercial/astrobotic-ready-become-delivery-service-moon/ |title=Astrobiotic Ready to Become Delivery Service to the Moon |first=Michael |last=Coli |work=Spaceflight Insider |date=19 March 2018 |access-date=27 July 2018}} |- | [[Team AngelicvM]] || 2020 || [[United Launch Alliance|ULA]] [[Atlas V]] with Astrobotic || Team AngelicvM signed a contracted with Astrobotic in 2015 to have their rover carried on board Astrobotic's lander.{{cite press release |date=27 October 2015 |title=TEAM ANGELICVM WILL FLY WITH ASTROBOTIC ON FIRST LUNAR MISSION |url=https://www.astrobotic.com/2015/10/27/team-angelicvm-will-fly-with-astrobotic-on-first-lunar-mission |publisher=[[Astrobotic]] |access-date=27 January 2018}} It's not clear whether this arrangement is still be in effect. |} ==See also== {{commons category}} * [[Ansari X Prize]] * [[Commercial Lunar Payload Services]] - a [[NASA]] partnership program including several Google Lunar X Prize contestants * [[Lunar Lander Challenge]] * [[NewSpace]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{wikinews|$20 million prize offered in lunar rover contest}} * [http://lunar.xprize.org/ Google Lunar X Prize] homepage * [https://www.youtube.com/view_play_list?p=86D7DAE50906C571 Google Lunar X Prize Video Playlist on YouTube] * [http://www.CentennialChallenges.nasa.gov NASA's Centennial Challenges competitive prizes program] * [https://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2011/02/lunar-x-prize-teams/ WIRED Science about GLXP] {{Google Lunar X Prize}} {{Challenges by the X PRIZE Foundation}} {{Google Inc.}} {{Moon spacecraft}} {{Space tourism}} {{Active inducement prize contests}} [[Category:X Prizes]] [[Category:Challenge awards]] [[Category:Google Lunar X Prize| ]] [[Category:Crowdsourcing]] [[Category:Google|Lunar X Prize]] [[Category:Robotics competitions]] [[Category:Private spaceflight]] [[Category:Exploration of the Moon]]

/* Dinner Shows */Dolly Parton’s Dixie Stampede rebranded in 2018 to drop the “Dixie” portion of the name. It is now known as Dolly Parton’s Stampede.
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=August 2010}} {{Infobox company | name = Herschend Family Entertainment | logo = Herschend Family Entertainment Corporation logo.png | logo_size = 250px | caption = | type = Private | traded_as = | genre = <!-- Only used with media and publishing companies --> | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{start date|1950}}<!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | founder = Hugo Herschend, Mary Herschend | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location_city = [[Atlanta, Georgia]] | location_country = | location = | locations = | area_served = [[United States]] | key_people = | industry = [[Amusement park]]s | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = <!-- Only used with financial services companies --> | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.hfecorp.com/}} <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Herschend Family Entertainment''' ('''HFE''') is a privately owned themed-entertainment company that operates several [[theme parks]] and [[tourist attractions]] within the United States.
Founded by Jack and Pete Herschend of [[Branson, Missouri]], in its early years HFE was simply known as '''Herschend Enterprises'''. In the 1980s the name was changed to '''Silver Dollar City Inc.''', and in 2003 the company gained the current name. HFE is currently headquartered in [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. The company's mission is to "Create Memories Worth Repeating."
==History== HFE traces roots back to Hugo and Mary Herschend from [[Chicago, Illinois]] along with sons Jack and Pete. The family vacationed in Missouri’s [[Ozark Mountains]] region and fell in love with the nature the area offered. In 1951 Hugo obtained a [[99-year lease]] on a [[Branson, Missouri]] area attraction called [[Marvel Cave]]. Hugo suffered a heart attack and later died in 1955, however Mary along with her two sons continued to improve the cave attraction by installing electric lighting and building cement walkways. A cable train was installed in 1958 to ferry guests out of the depths of the cave upon the end of the tour. The attendance nearly doubled and a small frontier town was erected to entertain visitors as they waited for their cave tour. In order to increase attendance furthermore at the attraction, a gimmick was used by naming the village "[[Silver Dollar City]]" and distributing [[Dollar (United States coin)|silver dollars]] as change to every visitor in hope that when they would spend the rare coins they would tell people where they had got them from. The idea was a success, and the Herschend family soon found themselves involved in the theme park business.
In 1969, Silver Dollar City drew national attention when producer [[Paul Henning]] brought the cast and crew of the popular ''[[Beverly Hillbillies]]'' television show to the park to film five episodes.
The park is also home to many bats which the park takes measures to try and protect from diseases that could prove fatal.
In 2010, Herschend Family Entertainment was featured on the reality TV series ''[[Undercover Boss]]''.
The company also co-owns and co-operates with partners [[Dolly Parton]] and her company The Dollywood Company, the dinner and theatre company Pirates Voyage Dinner and Show in [[Myrtle Beach, South Carolina]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gadling.com/2011/06/06/dolly-partons-pirates-voyage-replaces-dixie-stampede-in-myr/ |title=Dolly Parton's 'Pirates Voyage' replaces 'Dixie Stampede' in Myrtle Beach |publisher=Gadling |date=2011-06-06 |accessdate=2017-07-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=By MyrtleBeach.comSeptember 23, 2010 |url=http://www.myrtlebeach.com/blog/curtain-to-close-on-myrtle-beachs-dixie-stampede/ |title=Curtain to close on Myrtle Beach's Dixie today Stampede |publisher=MyrtleBeach.com |date=2010-09-23 |accessdate=2017-07-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myrtlebeachonline.com/entertainment/article16657346.html |title=Pirates Voyage all settled in former Dixie Stampede location, enjoying holiday shows | Myrtle Beach Sun News |publisher=Myrtlebeachonline.com |date=2013-12-20 |accessdate=2017-07-24}}</ref> and Dolly Parton's Stampede (formerly Dixie Stampede).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2008-01-08/news/stampede08_1_parton-dixie-dixie-stampede-pigeon-forge |title=Dolly Parton's Dixie Stampede dinner theater in Orlando sold, closed - tribunedigital-orlandosentinel |publisher=Articles.orlandosentinel.com |date=2008-01-08 |accessdate=2017-07-24}}</ref><ref name="soldorlando">{{cite news| title=Orlando's Dixie Stampede shuts down| last=Blake| first=Scott| publisher=Florida Today| url=http://www.floridatoday.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080108/BUSINESS/301080002/1003| archiveurl=http://www.floridatoday.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080108/BUSINESS/301080002/1003| date=2008-01-08| archivedate=2008-01-19| accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref><ref name=Stampede/>

Notes |- | [[Dollywood Cabins]] | [[Pigeon Forge, Tennessee|Pigeon Forge]] | 2010 | | Cabin style lodging in the [[Great Smoky Mountains]] |- | [[Dollywood's DreamMore Resort]] | [[Pigeon Forge, Tennessee|Pigeon Forge]] | 2015 | | Full Service [[resort]] and [[spa]] |- | [[Evergreen Resort]] | [[Stone Mountain, Georgia|Stone Mountain]], [[Georgia (U.S. State)|Georgia]] | | | In partnership with [[Marriott International]], Inc. a [[Convention (meeting)|conference]], [[golf]] and spa resort |- | [[Stone Mountain Inn]] | [[Stone Mountain, Georgia|Stone Mountain]], [[Georgia (U.S. State)|Georgia]] | | | |- |- | [[Stone Mountain Campground]] | [[Stone Mountain, Georgia|Stone Mountain]], [[Georgia (U.S. State)|Georgia]] | | | |- | The Wilderness | [[Branson, Missouri|Branson]] | | | Log cabins and campground |- |}
===Sports Entertainment Franchise=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:170px;"| Name ! style="width:150px;"| Location ! Year Opened ! Year Acquired ! Notes |- | [[Harlem Globetrotters|Harlem Globetrotters International Inc. ]] | [[Phoenix, Arizona]] | 1926 | 2013 | Exhibition Basketball team |- |}
==The Dollywood Company== The Herschends extended their brand in 1976 upon purchasing a small tourist attraction in [[Pigeon Forge, Tennessee]], called Goldrush Junction. The following year the attraction was renamed Silver Dollar City Tennessee as part of a development plan to transform the property into a theme park patterned after the original Silver Dollar City in Branson. For the Pigeon Forge park, the [[Ozark Mountains]] theme of the original Silver Dollar City was slightly reworked to represent the [[Great Smoky Mountains]] and [[Appalachia|Appalachia culture]] instead, fitting the location in the foothills of the Smokies.
In 1986, singer and actress [[Dolly Parton]], who grew up near Pigeon Forge, became a co-owner, and the park's name was changed to [[Dollywood]], reflecting her involvement. At this point, the Pigeon Forge park was branched off into a separate division of HFE called The Dollywood Company, which oversees all the properties that Dolly Parton has interest in.<ref>[http://www.dollywood.com/company-info/about.aspx About Dollywood: Company Information: Dollywood<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Along with the Herschend family, Dolly Parton co-owns the Dolly Parton's Stampede (formerly [[Dixie Stampede]]<ref name=Stampede>{{cite news|url=http://www.citizen-times.com/story/entertainment/2018/01/09/dolly-partons-dixie-stampede-gets-name-change-now-called-stampede/1017388001/|title=Dolly Parton's Dixie Stampede gets name change, now called Stampede|last=Jones|first=Maggie|work=[[USA Today]]|date=January 9, 2018|accessdate=January 9, 2018}}</ref>) dinner attraction chain, which has locations in Pigeon Forge (opened 1988), [[Myrtle Beach, South Carolina|Myrtle Beach]] (1992), and Branson (1995). A location in [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]] opened in 2003 and closed in early 2008.
In 2001 a new water park was opened adjacent to the Dollywood theme park called [[Dollywood's Splash Country]].
==Past properties== HFE built several water parks in the 1980s which have since sold to other companies such as [[Wet 'n Wild (brand)|Wet 'n Wild]], [[Frontier City]], and [[Six Flags]]. White Water Branson, built in 1980, was the forerunner and is still owned by HFE; while the White Waters in [[White Water Bay (Oklahoma)|Oklahoma City]] (1981), [[Boardwalk Fun Park|Grand Prairie, Texas]] (1982), [[Garland, Texas]] (1982) and [[Six Flags White Water|Atlanta]] (1983) have been sold.
The 4,000 seat [[Grand Palace Theatre]] opened in 1992 by the Herschends. The theatre was co-owned by singer [[Kenny Rogers]]. Along with Rogers headliners were [[Glen Campbell]], [[Louise Mandrell]] and [[Barbara Mandrell]]. In 1994 HFE entered into a ten-year contract with Radio City Entertainment. The Grand Palace Theatre would be the first to host the [[Radio City Christmas Spectacular]] starring the world famous [[The Rockettes|Rockettes]] outside of [[New York City]]’s [[Radio City Music Hall]]. The shows were successful and led to Radio City Entertainment launching tours of their shows in other cities throughout the United States.
HFE built the $10 million Grand Village Shops with [[Kenny Rogers]] adjacent to The Grand Palace Theatre in 1993. Ozark wares and English [[bone china]] filled the twenty six [[New Orleans]] themed shops. HFE later bought out entertainer Kenny Rogers and sold The Grand Palace in 1996 and The Grand Village in 2005.
American Adventures, a children’s theme park opened alongside [[Six Flags White Water|White Water Atlanta]]. The park was sold to [[Six Flags]] in 1999.
In 1994, The Dollywood Company constructed a large music theatre in Pigeon Forge called Music Mansion. Headlined by James Rogers,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jamesrogersonline.com/home.html |title=Welcome to James Rogers Online |publisher=Jamesrogersonline.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209123830/http://www.jamesrogersonline.com/home.html |archivedate=2012-02-09 |df= }}</ref> the highly successful theatre was operated by HFE until 2001, when it was sold to [[Anita Bryant]]. In 2005 the theatre was sold again and converted to a [[WonderWorks (attraction)|WonderWorks]] location. A Music Mansion Theatre was planned for Myrtle Beach, but never materialized.
In 2003 the Dollywood Company opened a new Dixie Stampede location in [[Orlando, Florida]] along [[Interstate 4]]. The location operated until early 2008, when the property was sold to [[Simon Property Group]] for an undisclosed amount. The building was torn down, and an extension of the Orlando Vineland Premium Outlets was built on the land. HFE has plans to build another Dixie Stampede in the region at some point, though specific plans have not been disclosed.<ref>[http://www.orlandosentinel.com/business/orl-dixie0908jan09,0,451819.story Orlando Premium Outlets' owner buys Dixie Stampede - OrlandoSentinel.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In 2004 HFE purchased the [[Hawaiian Falls]] water parks located in [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]], [[Garland, Texas|Garland]] and [[The Colony, Texas]]. In 2006 all three parks were sold.
Due to unreliable peak season water access, Ride The Ducks in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]] closed in 2007.
[[Celebration City]] in Branson closed on October 25, 2008. The company has plans to restructure the site.
