(Hulu.com destination site) | current_status = Active }} '''Hulu''' (stylized as '''hulu''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|h|uː|l|uː}}) is an American [[entertainment]] company that [[media service provider|provides]] "[[over-the-top media services]]."[https://digiday.com/media/what-is-over-the-top-ott/ WTF is OTT?] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180529203926/https://digiday.com/media/what-is-over-the-top-ott/ |date=2018-05-29 }} Published by [[Digiday.com]] July 7, 2015, retrieved, May 29, 2018 It is primarily oriented towards instant streaming of television series, carrying current and past episodes of many series from its owners' respective television networks and other content partners. Hulu is owned by Hulu LLC, a joint venture with [[The Walt Disney Company]] (holds 30% stake),{{cite news|author= Kramer, Staci D.|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/30/AR2009043001853.html|title= It's Official: Disney Joins News Corp., NBCU In Hulu; Deal Includes Some Cable Nets|date= April 30, 2006|accessdate= October 30, 2006|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110504054305/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/30/AR2009043001853.html|archive-date= May 4, 2011|dead-url= no|df= mdy-all}} [[21st Century Fox]] (holds 30% stake), [[Comcast]] (via [[NBCUniversal]]; holds 30% stake),Although NBC Universal is also a major shareholder (30%) of Hulu, by the [[Federal Communications Commission]], NBC Universal and Comcast are required (for seven years after Comcast acquired NBCUniversal in 2011) not to exercise any right to influence the conduct or operation of Hulu. "Neither Comcast nor C-NBCU shall exercise any right to influence the conduct or operation of Hulu, including those arising from agreements, arrangements or operation of its equity interests (e.g., board seats, voting for directors or other shareholder matters, management and veto rights, etc.) and C-NBCU shall as and from the date of this Order hold its interest in Hulu solely as an economic interest." (MO&O, 1/20/11, FCC Grants Approval of Comcast-NBCU Transaction, [http://www.fcc.gov/transaction/comcast-nbcu.html Comcast Corporation and NBC Universal] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100611084607/http://www.fcc.gov/transaction/comcast-nbcu.html |date=2010-06-11 }}, Federal Communications Commission) and [[AT&T]] (via [[WarnerMedia]]; holds 10% stake). Through a [[Proposed acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney|proposed acquisition]] announced in December 2017, Disney is to acquire Fox's partial ownership, giving it a majority stake if the deal closes.{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/12/14/media/disney-fox/index.html|title=Disney buys 21st Century Fox: Who gets what|last=Goldman|first=David|date=2017-12-14|work=CNNMoney|access-date=2017-12-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171214130140/http://money.cnn.com/2017/12/14/media/disney-fox/index.html|archive-date=2017-12-14|dead-url=no|df=}} Some of Hulu's competitors include [[Netflix]] and [[Amazon Studios|Amazon]]. Previously it was divided into free and paid tiers, with the free service limited in the amount of content accessible by users and accessible via PC only, and a paid service with a larger library of content and accessed via Hulu applications for various mobile and connected devices. The subscription service is, in turn, divided into advertising-supported and mostly ad-free tiers. In 2016, Hulu spun out its free content into a joint venture with [[Yahoo!]] called [[Yahoo! View]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160808005276/en/|title=Introducing Yahoo View, a TV Watching Experience Featuring Hulu {{!}} Business Wire|website=www.businesswire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206185416/http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160808005276/en/|archive-date=2017-02-06|dead-url=no|df=}} and launched a live television streaming service on May 3, 2017. Hulu is currently offered only to users in the [[United States]], [[Territories of the United States|its territories]] and [[Japan]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article/348989/netflix-vs-hulu-streaming-service-showdown|title=Netflix vs. Hulu: Streaming Service Showdown|work=PCMAG|access-date=2017-08-03|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170803175925/https://www.pcmag.com/article/348989/netflix-vs-hulu-streaming-service-showdown|archive-date=2017-08-03|dead-url=no|df=}} == Name == The name Hulu comes from two [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]] words, ''húlú'' ([[wikt:葫芦|葫芦]]/[[wikt:葫蘆|葫蘆]]), "[[calabash]]; bottle gourd", and ''hùlù'' ([[wikt:互录|互录]]/[[wikt:互錄|互錄]]), "interactive recording". The company blog explains:
In Mandarin, ''Hulu'' has two interesting meanings, each highly relevant to our mission. The primary meaning interested us because it is used in an ancient Chinese proverb that describes the Hulu as the holder of precious things. It literally translates to "gourd," and in ancient times, the Hulu was hollowed out and used to hold precious things. The secondary meaning is "interactive recording". We saw both definitions as appropriate bookends and highly relevant to the mission of Hulu.{{cite web|last=Kilar|first=Jason|title=What's in a Name?|date=2008-05-14|url=http://blog.hulu.com/2008/05/13/meaning-of-hulu/|accessdate=2010-07-17|postscript=.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717203005/http://blog.hulu.com/2008/05/13/meaning-of-hulu/|archive-date=2011-07-17|dead-url=no|df=}}
== Business history == Key executives instrumental in the founding of Hulu include Bruce Campbell,{{cite web|url=https://corporate.discovery.com/our-company/leadership/|title=Leadership – Discovery Communications, Inc.|website=corporate.discovery.com|access-date=2016-05-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529041516/https://corporate.discovery.com/our-company/leadership/|archive-date=2016-05-29|dead-url=no|df=}} Peter Chernin,{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/peter-chernin-offers-500m-hulu-84381/|title=Peter Chernin Offers $500M for Hulu|date=2013-04-05|website=TheWrap|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161020070543/http://www.thewrap.com/peter-chernin-offers-500m-hulu-84381/|archive-date=2016-10-20|dead-url=no|df=}} JB Perrette,{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2008/09/mf-hulu/|title=Free, Legal and Online: Why Hulu Is the New Way to Watch TV|website=WIRED|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160527061240/http://www.wired.com/2008/09/mf-hulu/|archive-date=2016-05-27|dead-url=no|df=}} Michael Lang,{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/06/01/we-happy-miramax-deal-brings-hundreds-of-movies-to-hulu-hulu-plus/|title=We Happy? Miramax Deal Brings Hundreds Of Movies To Hulu Plus (And To Hulu)|last=Wauters|first=Robin|website=TechCrunch|access-date=2016-05-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160503174249/http://techcrunch.com/2011/06/01/we-happy-miramax-deal-brings-hundreds-of-movies-to-hulu-hulu-plus/|archive-date=2016-05-03|dead-url=no|df=}} [[Beth Comstock]] and [[Jason Kilar]]. The venture was announced in March 2006 with [[AOL]], [[NBC Universal]], now [[Comcast]], [[Facebook]], [[MSN]], [[Myspace]], and [[Yahoo!]] planned as "initial distribution partners". Kilar was named the CEO in June 2006.{{cite press release |url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20070322005690/en/NBC-Universal-News-Corp.-Announce-Deal-Internet |title=NBC Universal and News Corp. Announce Deal with Internet Leaders AOL, MSN, MySpace And Yahoo! to Create a Premium Online Video Site with Unprecedented Reach |publisher=Business Wire |accessdate=12 December 2017 |date=22 March 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101212907/http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20070322005690/en/NBC-Universal-News-Corp.-Announce-Deal-Internet |archive-date=1 January 2011 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|url=http://www.thestreet.com/s/googles-still-on-top/newsanalysis/technet/10346071.html |title=Google's Still on Top |accessdate=2007-08-29 |date=2007-03-22 |author=Nat Worden |work=[[TheStreet.com]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930180547/http://www.thestreet.com/s/googles-still-on-top/newsanalysis/technet/10346071.html |archivedate=2007-09-30 |df= }} The name ''Hulu'' was chosen in late August 2007, when the website went live, with an announcement only and no content. It invited users to leave their email addresses for the upcoming [[Software release life cycle|beta test]].{{cite news|url=http://www.thestreet.com/s/googles-new-foe-hulu/newsanalysis/mediaentertainment/10376991.html |title=Google's New Foe: Hulu |accessdate=2007-08-29 |date=2007-08-29 |author=Nat Worden |work=[[TheStreet.com]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070904013423/http://www.thestreet.com/s/googles-new-foe-hulu/newsanalysis/mediaentertainment/10376991.html |archivedate=2007-09-04 |df= }} In October, Hulu began the private beta testing by invitation, and later allowed users to invite friends.{{cite press release |url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20071028005079/en/Hulu-Debuts-Private-Beta-Distribution-Partners-AOL |title=Hulu Debuts via Private Beta and on Distribution Partners AOL, Comcast, MSN, MySpace and Yahoo! |publisher=Business Wire |accessdate=11 December 2017 |date=20 October 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222050812/https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20071028005079/en/Hulu-Debuts-Private-Beta-Distribution-Partners-AOL |archive-date=22 December 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} Hulu launched for public access in the United States on March 12, 2008. The first product to launch was the HULU Syndication network, which was designed and developed by the NBC Universal team from New York, on October 29, 2007, followed by the Hulu.com destinations site. Hulu began an advertising campaign during NBC's broadcast of [[Super Bowl XLIII]] with an initial ad starring [[Alec Baldwin]] titled "Alec in Huluwood".{{cite web |url= http://www.hulu.com/watch/58538/hulu-tv-ads-alec-in-huluwood |title= Hulu TV Ads: Alec in Huluwood |author= |date= |work= Hulu |publisher= Hulu |accessdate= May 10, 2009 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090508080115/http://www.hulu.com/watch/58538/hulu-tv-ads-alec-in-huluwood |archive-date= 2009-05-08 |dead-url= yes |df= }} The ad intended to humorously reveal "the shocking secret behind Hulu", portraying the site as being an "evil plot to destroy the world" by suggesting that Baldwin is really an alien in disguise.{{cite web |url= http://news.cnet.com/8301-13577_3-10150197-36.html |title= Hulu to shock the world with Super Bowl ad |last= McCarthy |first= Caroline |date= January 26, 2009 |publisher= CNET News |accessdate= February 2, 2009 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090806043548/http://news.cnet.com/8301-13577_3-10150197-36.html |archive-date= August 6, 2009 |dead-url= no |df= mdy-all }} Advertisements have since aired featuring [[Eliza Dushku]], [[Seth MacFarlane]], [[Denis Leary]], and [[Will Arnett]]. In July 2007, [[Providence Equity Partners]], the owner of [[Newport Television]], became one of the earliest "outside" investors by purchasing a 10 percent stake in the company for [[United States dollar|US$]]100 million [[equity (finance)|equity investment]],{{cite news|url=http://www.cable360.net/competition/web/25376.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120906054018/http://www.cable360.net/competition/web/25376.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 6, 2012 |title=NBC and Fox Jump Through Hulu Hoop |accessdate=2007-08-29 |date=August 29, 2006 |first=Shirley |last=Brady |work=Cable360.net |df= }} before the company was known as "Hulu". With its investment came a seat on the board of directors, where Providence was said to act as an "independent voice on the board". In October 2012, Providence sold its 10 percent stake to "Hulu's media owners" and ceased participation in the board.{{cite news|url = https://techcrunch.com/2012/10/12/providence-equity-sells-its-stake-in-hulu/|title = It's Done: Early Hulu Investor Providence Equity Partners Has Sold Its Stake For $200M|accessdate = 2012-05-12|date = May 12, 2012|first = Ryan|last = Lawler|work = techcrunch.com|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20121013055831/http://techcrunch.com/2012/10/12/providence-equity-sells-its-stake-in-hulu/|archive-date = October 13, 2012|dead-url = no|df = mdy-all}} Early in 2010, Hulu chief executive Jason Kilar said the service had made a profit in two quarters and that the company could top $100 million in revenue by summer 2010, more than its income for all of 2009. [[ComScore]] says monthly video streams reached 903 million in January 2010, over three times the figure for a year earlier,{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/businesstechnology/2011517934_bthulufuture05.html?syndication=rss|title=Hulu, the online-video hub, contemplates its future|last1=Stelter|first1=Brian|last2=Stone|first2=Brad|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2010-04-05|accessdate=2010-04-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622021349/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/businesstechnology/2011517934_bthulufuture05.html?syndication=rss|archive-date=2011-06-22|dead-url=no|df=}} and second only to [[YouTube]].{{cite news|url=http://broadcastengineering.com/news/hulu-plans-subscripiton-service-0426/ |title=Hulu plans subscription service |last=Grotticelli |first=Michael |work=Broadcast Engineering |date=2010-04-26 |accessdate=2010-04-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704080501/http://broadcastengineering.com/news/hulu-plans-subscripiton-service-0426/ |archivedate=2010-07-04 |df= }} On August 16, 2010, a report revealed that Hulu was planning an [[Initial Public Offering|initial public offering]] (IPO) which could value the company at more than $2 billion.[https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20100816/tc_nm/us_hulu_ipo U.S. video viewing site Hulu plans an IPO: report] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820123350/http://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20100816/tc_nm/us_hulu_ipo |date=August 20, 2010 }}{{cite news |author=Dealbook |url=http://dealbook.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/08/16/hulu-is-said-to-be-ready-for-an-i-p-o/ |title=Hulu Is Said to Be Ready for an I.P.O |publisher=Dealbook.blogs.nytimes.com |date=2010-08-16 |accessdate=2010-12-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101022161929/http://dealbook.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/08/16/hulu-is-said-to-be-ready-for-an-i-p-o/ |archive-date=2010-10-22 |dead-url=no |df= }} On June 21, 2011, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that an "unsolicited offer" caused Hulu to begin "weighing whether to sell itself."{{cite news |author= Vascellaro |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303936704576400133483416612 |title= Website Hulu Considers Sale |work= [[The Wall Street Journal]] |date= 2011-06-21 |accessdate= 2011-06-21 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150328030500/http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303936704576400133483416612 |archive-date= 2015-03-28 |dead-url= no |df= }} On October 13, 2011 however, Hulu and its owners announced that they would not sell the company, as none of the bidders offered an amount that was satisfactory to its owners.{{cite web |url= http://mashable.com/2011/10/13/no-hulu-sale/ |title= Hulu Is No Longer For Sale |last1= Parr |first1= Ben |date= October 13, 2011 |work= [[Mashable]] |publisher= Mashable, Inc. |accessdate= June 14, 2013 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20130521112923/http://mashable.com/2011/10/13/no-hulu-sale/ |archive-date= May 21, 2013 |dead-url= no |df= mdy-all }} It was reported that in 2011, Hulu made $420 million. The figure was $80 million short of the predicted revenue.{{cite web |last= Van Grove |first= Jennifer |date= January 31, 2012 |title= Hulu CEO Jason Kilar: Original programming is an important part of the agenda. |url= https://venturebeat.com/2012/01/31/hulu-jason-kilar/ |work= VentureBeat |access-date= August 31, 2017 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170703055106/https://venturebeat.com/2012/01/31/hulu-jason-kilar/ |archive-date= July 3, 2017 |dead-url= no |df= mdy-all }} The vacant CEO post was officially filled by former Fox Networks President Mike Hopkins on October 17, 2013.{{cite web|title=Mike Hopkins Named CEO of Hulu|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20131017006396/en/Mike-Hopkins-Named-CEO-Hulu|accessdate=17 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020060749/http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20131017006396/en/Mike-Hopkins-Named-CEO-Hulu|archive-date=20 October 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In December 2017, Disney announced that they would [[Proposed acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney|acquire 21st Century Fox]], which includes its 30% stake in Hulu. The deal will result in Disney having a controlling interest in Hulu.{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/12/14/media/disney-fox-deal/index.html|title=Disney is buying most of 21st Century Fox for $52.4 billion|last=Riley|first=Charles and [[Hadas Gold]]|work=CNNMoney|access-date=2018-01-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180121041657/http://money.cnn.com/2017/12/14/media/disney-fox-deal/index.html|archive-date=2018-01-21|dead-url=no|df=}} == Partners == Following the start of its service, Hulu signed deals with several new content providers making additional material available to consumers. On April 30, 2009, [[The Walt Disney Company]] announced that it would join the venture, purchasing a 27 percent stake in Hulu. Starting August 15, 2011, viewers of content from Fox and related networks are required to authenticate paid cable or satellite service wherever Fox streams episodes, including on Hulu, to be able to watch them the morning after the first airing. Non-subscribers will see those episodes delayed a week before they are viewable.[[Brian Stelter]], ''[[The New York Times]]''. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/27/business/media/fox-to-limit-next-day-streaming-on-hulu.html Fox to Limit Next-Day Streaming on Hulu to Paying Cable Customers] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130531154143/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/27/business/media/fox-to-limit-next-day-streaming-on-hulu.html |date=2013-05-31 }}". July 26, 2011. Retrieved July 28, 2011. On October 28, 2011, Hulu announced that they had inked a five-year deal with [[The CW]], giving the streaming site access to next-day content from five of the six major networks.Wasserman, Todd, [[Mashable]] [http://mashable.com/2011/10/28/hulu-gossip-girl-cw/] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111030165419/http://mashable.com/2011/10/28/hulu-gossip-girl-cw/ |date=2011-10-30 }} On September 18, 2013, Hulu announced a multi-year deal with the [[BBC]] that will deliver 2,000 episodes from 144 different titles in the first 12 months.{{cite web | title = Hulu BBC Deal, A Positive Step After Some Cloudy Times | url = http://ceoworld.biz/2013/09/18/hulu-bbc-deal-a-positive-step-after-some-cloudy-times | work = CEOWORLD Magazine | date = 18 September 2013 | access-date = 20 August 2013 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130928075905/http://ceoworld.biz/2013/09/18/hulu-bbc-deal-a-positive-step-after-some-cloudy-times | archive-date = 28 September 2013 | dead-url = no | df = dmy-all }} In 2015, Hulu began offering content from [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] for an additional $8.99/month, which is cheaper than Showtime's own streaming service. On June 16, 2016, Hulu announced a deal with the Disney-ABC Television Group for the exclusive SVOD rights to past seasons of seven Disney Channel, Disney Junior and Disney XD series, and more than 20 Disney Channel original movies.{{cite web |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/television/hulu-makes-big-kids-programming-push-new-disney-channel-deal-172048 |title=Hulu Makes Big Kids Programming Push With New Disney Channel Deal |work=[[Ad Week]] |access-date=17 June 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617144309/http://www.adweek.com/news/television/hulu-makes-big-kids-programming-push-new-disney-channel-deal-172048 |archive-date=17 June 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} On September 18, 2016, all content from The CW was removed from Hulu, as The CW's own website and apps became the exclusive portals for streaming their shows during the current season, with Netflix becoming the exclusive streaming provider for The CW shows post-current season.{{cite web | title = The CW Bloodbath is Coming – Hulu Removing CW Shows September 18th | url = http://exstreamist.com/the-cw-bloodbath-is-coming-hulu-removing-cw-shows-september-18th/ | work = Exstreamist.com | date = 17 August 2016 | access-date = 14 November 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20161114085218/http://exstreamist.com/the-cw-bloodbath-is-coming-hulu-removing-cw-shows-september-18th/ | archive-date = 14 November 2016 | dead-url = no | df = dmy-all }} {{As of|2017|January}}, a limited amount of content from [[CBS]]'s library is available on-demand, mostly limited to shows that are no longer producing new episodes.{{cite web|url=https://help.hulu.com/articles/22330147|title=CBS shows on Hulu|website=help.hulu.com|access-date=2017-01-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170105084731/https://help.hulu.com/articles/22330147|archive-date=2017-01-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hulu.com/companies/cbs|title=CBS|website=Hulu|access-date=2017-01-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170105080054/http://www.hulu.com/companies/cbs|archive-date=2017-01-05|dead-url=no|df=}} On January 4, 2017, it was reported that a deal was reached to bring live broadcasts of CBS and several affiliated channels to Hulu's upcoming live streaming service{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-cbs-corp-hulu-deal-idUSKBN14O1Y1|title=CBS signs deal to be on Hulu's live-streaming platform|date=2017-01-04|publisher=Reuters|access-date=2017-01-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170104233511/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-cbs-corp-hulu-deal-idUSKBN14O1Y1|archive-date=2017-01-04|dead-url=no|df=}} as well as to make more shows available on-demand.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2017/01/04/hulu-adds-cbs-to-its-upcoming-live-tv-service/|title=Hulu adds CBS to its upcoming live TV service|publisher=[[Engadget]]|access-date=2017-01-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170105061502/https://www.engadget.com/2017/01/04/hulu-adds-cbs-to-its-upcoming-live-tv-service/|archive-date=2017-01-05|dead-url=no|df=}} In April 2018, Hulu announced a partnership with [[Spotify]] that allows users to purchase both streaming services for a discounted price per month.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/4/11/17222646/spotify-hulu-bundle-deal-now-available-pricing|title=Now you can get Spotify and Hulu together for just $12.99 each month|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-04-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180412001334/https://www.theverge.com/2018/4/11/17222646/spotify-hulu-bundle-deal-now-available-pricing|archive-date=2018-04-12|dead-url=no|df=}} == Products == === {{anchor|Hulu Plus}} Hulu subscription service === At an industry conference held on October 21, 2009, [[News Corporation]] Deputy Chairman [[Chase Carey]] stated that Hulu "needs to evolve to have a meaningful subscription model as part of its business" and that it would likely start charging for at least some content by 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/blog/ADverse_Atkinson_on_Advertising/23941-Chase_Carey_Hulu_to_Charge_in_2010.php?nid=2228&source=title&rid=6454445 |title=Chase Carey: Hulu to Charge in 2010 |date=2009-10-21 |author=Atkinson, Claire |work=Broadcasting & Cable |publisher=Reed Business Information |accessdate=2009-11-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091025045542/http://www.broadcastingcable.com/blog/ADverse_Atkinson_on_Advertising/23941-Chase_Carey_Hulu_to_Charge_in_2010.php?nid=2228&source=title&rid=6454445 |archive-date=2009-10-25 |dead-url=no |df= }} Carey's comment jibes with other News Corp. heads, including Rupert Murdoch who has expressed a desire to charge for content with a number of online units.{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-31001_3-10381622-261.html |title=More signs Hulu subscription service is coming |first=Greg |last=Sandoval |date=October 22, 2009 |accessdate=November 4, 2009 |work=Media Maverick |publisher=CNET |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110617000040/http://news.cnet.com/8301-31001_3-10381622-261.html |archive-date=June 17, 2011 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }} The Hulu monthly subscription service called Hulu Plus was launched in [[Beta test|beta (preview)]] on June 29, 2010{{cite web |url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/29/hulu-unveils-subscription-service-for-9-99-a-month/ |title=Hulu Unveils Subscription Service For $9.99 a Month |first=Brian |last=Stelter |date=29 June 2010 |accessdate=12 November 2014 |publisher=New York Times |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112160157/http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/29/hulu-unveils-subscription-service-for-9-99-a-month/ |archive-date=12 November 2014 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} and officially launched on November 17, 2010.{{cite web |url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/11/17/hulu-drops-prices-to-compete-with-netflix/ |title=Hulu Drops Prices to Compete With Netflix |first=Brian |last=Stelter |date=27 November 2010 |accessdate=12 November 2014 |publisher=New York Times |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112161947/http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/11/17/hulu-drops-prices-to-compete-with-netflix/ |archive-date=12 November 2014 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} Like the free version of Hulu, the content available with a Hulu subscription also contains advertising. However, it offers an expanded content library including full seasons, day-after access to current season content and more episodes of shows available through the free Hulu. A Hulu subscription also provides a wider array of viewing choices. The free-access to Hulu was only available on PCs and laptops, while a Hulu subscription allows viewers to access Hulu through all Hulu-supported devices including set-top boxes, smart TVs, gaming consoles, mobile devices and more. A little more than a year after the launch of the Hulu subscription service, the number of paying subscribers reached 1.5 million.Nakashima, Ryan January 13, 2012. [http://www.newsday.com/business/hulu-plus-ends-year-with-1-5-million-subscribers-1.3448597 "Hulu Plus ends year with 1.5 million subscribers"]. In May 2016, Hulu reported it had reached 12 million subscribers.{{cite web|last1=Stelter|first1=Brian|title=Hulu closes in on 12 million subscribers; plans cable-like TV option|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/05/04/media/hulu-subscribers-cable-bundle/|website=money.cnn.com|publisher=CNN|accessdate=1 November 2016|date=4 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161103234634/http://money.cnn.com/2016/05/04/media/hulu-subscribers-cable-bundle/|archive-date=3 November 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} As of the end of 2017, Hulu reported it had reached 17 million subscribers.{{cite web|last1=Stelter|first1=Brian|title=Hulu closes in on 12 million subscribers; plans cable-like TV option|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/1/9/16868864/hulu-17-million-subscribers-announced-2018|website=theverge.com|publisher=Verge|accessdate=6 February 2018|date=9 January 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207123153/https://www.theverge.com/2018/1/9/16868864/hulu-17-million-subscribers-announced-2018|archive-date=7 February 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} On April 29, 2015, Hulu announced to the press that they would do away with the "Plus" brand name to reduce confusion between the paid and free plans.{{cite news|work=Advertising Age|url=http://adage.com/article/media/hulu-drop-hulu-brand-picks-seinfeld/298305/|title=Hulu Will Drop Hulu Plus Brand, Picks up 'Seinfeld'|accessdate=September 13, 2015|author=Peterson, Tim|date=April 29, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906123704/http://adage.com/article/media/hulu-drop-hulu-brand-picks-seinfeld/298305/|archive-date=September 6, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} The ''Wall Street Journal'' reported in July 2015 that Hulu was exploring an advertising-free subscription option for around $12 to $14 a month.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/article_email/hulu-explores-adding-ad-free-option-to-its-service-1437103682-lMyQjAxMTI1MzE1NzIxMDc2Wj|title=Hulu Explores Adding Ad-Free Option to Its Service|date=July 16, 2015|publisher=Wall Street Journal|access-date=March 7, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160109235948/http://www.wsj.com/article_email/hulu-explores-adding-ad-free-option-to-its-service-1437103682-lMyQjAxMTI1MzE1NzIxMDc2Wj|archive-date=January 9, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} This was confirmed as going forward {{as of|2015|September|2|lc=y|df=US}}, with a "No Commercials" plan priced at $11.99, $4 more than the $7.99 monthly rate for a "Limited Commercials" subscription,{{cite web|title = Hulu – About|url = http://www.hulu.com/about|website = Hulu|accessdate = 2015-04-08|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150406223353/http://www.hulu.com/about|archive-date = 2015-04-06|dead-url = no|df = }} though a few highlight network series (less than 10) would retain pre-roll and post-roll ad pods.{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2015/digital/news/hulu-adds-mostly-ad-free-subscription-service-1201583375/|title=Hulu Adds (Mostly) Ad-Free Subscription Service|last=Wallenstein|first=Andrew|date=2 September 2015|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=2 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150903042841/http://variety.com/2015/digital/news/hulu-adds-mostly-ad-free-subscription-service-1201583375/|archive-date=3 September 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} On August 8, 2016, Hulu announced that it would end the availability of its free streaming service through its own platform, making it oriented exclusively to subscription services. In turn, the company announced a partnership with [[Yahoo!]] to move this free content, which consists primarily of recent episodes of ABC, Fox, and NBC series, to a new website known as [[Yahoo! View]].{{cite web|title=This is the end of Hulu as we know it|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/08/08/hulu-is-getting-rid-of-what-made-it-famous/|website=Washington Post|accessdate=9 August 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160809122415/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/08/08/hulu-is-getting-rid-of-what-made-it-famous/|archive-date=9 August 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|last=Jarvey|first=Natalie|title=Hulu to End Free TV Service|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/hulu-end-free-tv-service-917917|accessdate=August 8, 2016|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 8, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808222239/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/hulu-end-free-tv-service-917917|archive-date=August 8, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|last=Brodkin|first=Jon|title=Hulu will soon end its free streaming options|url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2016/08/hulus-free-shows-move-to-yahoo-as-it-becomes-a-paid-only-service/|accessdate=August 8, 2016|work=Ars Technica|date=August 8, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808160803/http://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2016/08/hulus-free-shows-move-to-yahoo-as-it-becomes-a-paid-only-service/|archive-date=August 8, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} === Hulu with Live TV === In May 2016, Hulu announced that it planned to begin offering an [[over-the-top content|over-the-top]] [[IPTV]] service with "live programming from broadcast and cable brands" some time in 2017.{{cite web|title=Hulu confirms plan to stream live TV next year|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/5/4/11590306/hulu-confirms-live-tv-2017-plans|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=10 August 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160810115549/http://www.theverge.com/2016/5/4/11590306/hulu-confirms-live-tv-2017-plans|archive-date=10 August 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In late 2016, co-owners 21st Century Fox and The Walt Disney Company agreed to supply their channels to the streaming service, joined by Time Warner, which previously reached an agreement with Hulu.{{cite news|last1=Lieberman|first1=David|title=Disney And Fox Agree To Provide Sports And Broadcast Channels To Hulu|url=http://deadline.com/2016/11/disney-fox-agree-provide-sports-other-channels-hulu-1201846186/|accessdate=January 24, 2017|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=November 1, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202030818/http://deadline.com/2016/11/disney-fox-agree-provide-sports-other-channels-hulu-1201846186/|archive-date=February 2, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} The service, marketed only as "Hulu with Live TV," which couples the live TV offerings with Hulu's existing library of television series and films, launched in [[beta testing|beta]] on May 3, 2017. The $39.99-per-month service – which provides support for [[Xbox One]], [[Apple TV]], [[Chromecast]], iOS and Android devices – offers live streams of more than 50 broadcast and cable-originated channels, including feeds of the five major broadcast networks – ABC, CBS, NBC, Fox and The CW – as well as cable channels owned by Hulu co-parents NBCUniversal, 21st Century Fox and The Walt Disney Company, along with [[CBS Corporation]], [[Turner Broadcasting System]], [[Scripps Networks Interactive]] and [[A+E Networks]] (encompassing networks such as [[CNN]], [[Food Network]], [[Disney Channel]], [[A&E (TV network)|A&E]], [[MSNBC]] and [[ESPN]]), with the Showtime OTT service available as an add-on for an extra fee. Currently, live content from the major broadcast networks is limited to [[owned-and-operated station]]s and affiliates based in New York City, Los Angeles, [[Chicago]], [[San Francisco]] and [[Philadelphia]]; Hulu representatives stated that it intends to negotiate carriage agreements with independently-owned broadcasting groups to gain distribution rights to local stations from additional markets.{{cite web|title=You can now watch 50-plus channels of live TV on Hulu with $39.99 upgrade|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2017/05/03/net-video-streamer-hulu-gets-3999-live-tv-upgrade/101218510/|author=Mike Snider|newspaper=USA Today|publisher=Gannett Company|date=May 3, 2017|accessdate=May 9, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170508210018/https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2017/05/03/net-video-streamer-hulu-gets-3999-live-tv-upgrade/101218510/|archive-date=May 8, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|title=Hulu Live TV launches in beta: What you need to know|url=http://www.techhive.com/article/3193912/streaming-services/hulu-live-tv-launches-in-beta-what-you-need-to-know.html|author=Jared Newman|website=[[TechHive]]|date=May 3, 2017|accessdate=May 9, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170509022030/http://www.techhive.com/article/3193912/streaming-services/hulu-live-tv-launches-in-beta-what-you-need-to-know.html|archive-date=May 9, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|title=Hulu Live TV Service Launches With 50 Channels for $40 Monthly|url=https://variety.com/2017/digital/news/hulu-live-tv-service-launch-channels-1202407778/|author=Todd Spangler|periodical=Variety|publisher=Penske Media Corporation|date=May 3, 2017|accessdate=May 9, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170508083536/http://variety.com/2017/digital/news/hulu-live-tv-service-launch-channels-1202407778/|archive-date=May 8, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} Features include the ability to create up of six user account profiles per a single subscription (with personalized program recommendations based on a user's favorite programs and varying simultaneous streams depending on the package), personalized sports recommendations and a [[cloud computing|cloud]] [[digital video recorder|DVR]] with between 50 and 200 hours of storage depending on the level of service (the lower-tier DVR does not have ad skipping functionality).{{cite news|title=Hulu just launched its $40-a-month cable-TV competitor — here are all the details|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/hulu-live-tv-package-details-pricing-channels-features-2017-5|author=Nathan McAlone|website=Business Insider|date=May 3, 2017|accessdate=May 9, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170507140451/http://www.businessinsider.com/hulu-live-tv-package-details-pricing-channels-features-2017-5|archive-date=May 7, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|title=Hulu launches live TV service|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/05/03/media/hulu-live-tv-service/index.html|author=Sandra Gonzalez|website=CNN Money|publisher=Time Warner|date=May 3, 2017|accessdate=May 9, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170503203436/http://money.cnn.com/2017/05/03/media/hulu-live-tv-service/index.html|archive-date=May 3, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|title=Hulu Live TV Bundle: Full Channel Lineup|url=https://variety.com/2017/digital/news/hulu-live-tv-full-channel-lineup-1202407833/|author=Todd Spangler|periodical=Variety|publisher=Penske Media Corporation|date=May 3, 2017|accessdate=May 9, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170508033929/http://variety.com/2017/digital/news/hulu-live-tv-full-channel-lineup-1202407833/|archive-date=May 8, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|title=Hulu Live TV Service Won't Have Viacom Networks|url=https://variety.com/2017/digital/news/hulu-live-tv-service-no-viacom-networks-1202006300/|author=Todd Spangler|periodical=Variety|publisher=Penske Media Corporation|date=March 10, 2017|accessdate=May 9, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170512084000/http://variety.com/2017/digital/news/hulu-live-tv-service-no-viacom-networks-1202006300/|archive-date=May 12, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} Hulu with Live TV hit 800K subscribers in its first year {{as of|2018|May|lc=y}}.{{Cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2018/05/hulu-pay-tv-bundle-hits-800k-subscribers-1202400295/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2018-05-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180601024153/https://deadline.com/2018/05/hulu-pay-tv-bundle-hits-800k-subscribers-1202400295/ |archive-date=2018-06-01 |dead-url=no |df= }} Hulu with Live TV hit 1 million subscribers on September 16, 2018.{{Cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2018/09/16/hulu-hits-1-million-live-tv-subscriber-mark-debuts-emmy-commercial/1304968002/ |title=Hulu hits 1 million live TV subscriber mark, debuts new campaign |access-date=2018-09-25}} == Viewership == Viewership numbers for the site are tracked by measurement firms such as [[ComScore]], [[Nielsen ratings]], and [[Quantcast]]. In partnership with comScore, Hulu is the first digital company to receive multi-platform measurement at an individual level that includes co-viewing for living room devices. When factoring this in, Hulu's reach among adults aged 18–49 increases 50 percent. However, the reliability of these metrics has been drawn into question, partly due to widely divergent estimates. For example, between May and June 2010, ComScore updated its scoring methodology and its estimates for Hulu dropped from 43.5 million unique viewers to 24 million in a single month.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jul/26/business/la-fi-ct-hulu-20100721|title=Hulu's sharp decline in viewership underscores inconsistency in measuring size of online audience|publisher=LA Times|author=Dawn C. Chmielewski|date=26 Jul 2010|accessdate=1 Nov 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170311095132/http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jul/26/business/la-fi-ct-hulu-20100721|archive-date=11 March 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In a comScore digital trends report in 2010, comScore's Digital Year in Review report found that Hulu was watched twice as much as viewers who watched on the websites of the five major TV networks combined.{{cite news|last1=Schonfeld|first1=Erick|title=ComScore: Hulu Is Watched Twice As Much As The 5 Major TV Networks Online Combined|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/02/07/comscore-hulu-tv-networks/|publisher=TechCrunch|date=7 Feb 2011|access-date=11 December 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171212031532/https://techcrunch.com/2011/02/07/comscore-hulu-tv-networks/|archive-date=12 December 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Hulu in May 2018 announced it has surpassed 20 million subscribers in the United States.{{cite news|last1=Gruenwedel|first1=Erik|title=Hulu Tops 20 Million Subs, Inks First Deal with DreamWorks Animation|url=https://www.mediaplaynews.com/hulu-tops-20-million-subs-inks-first-deal-with-dreamworks-animation/|accessdate=May 2, 2018|work=Media Play News|date=May 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180503041617/https://www.mediaplaynews.com/hulu-tops-20-million-subs-inks-first-deal-with-dreamworks-animation/|archive-date=May 3, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} The tally, which puts the company about 36 million subscriptions behind Netflix, was disclosed at a media presentation at the newly-named Hulu Theater at Madison Square Garden in New York. Hulu said it has grown total engagement by more than 60%, with 78% of viewing taking place in the living room on connected TVs. == Programming == === Content partners === Hulu distributes video on its own website and syndicates its hosting to other sites,{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120519822483125987 |title=Can Hulu Find Its Mojo With Viewers? |accessdate=2008-03-19 |date=2008-03-11 |author=Rebecca Dana and Emily Steel |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160109235949/http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120519822483125987 |archive-date=2016-01-09 |dead-url=no |df= }} and allows users to embed Hulu clips on their websites. In addition to NBC, ABC and Fox programs and movies, Hulu carries shows from networks such as [[A&E (TV channel)|A&E]], [[Big Ten Network]], [[Bravo (US TV channel)|Bravo]], [[E!]], [[Fox Sports 2]], [[FX (TV channel)|FX]], [[PBS]], [[NFL Network]], [[Oxygen (TV channel)|Oxygen]], [[RT America]], [[Fox Sports 1]], [[Esquire Network]], [[SundanceTV]], [[Syfy]], [[USA Network]], [[NBCSN]], and online comedy sources such as [[Onion News Network]].{{cite web|url= http://www.thrfeed.com/2009/04/abc-to-offer-shows-on-hulu.html|title= ABC to offer shows on Hulu|publisher= The Live Feed|date= April 30, 2009|access-date= December 11, 2017|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090504084734/http://www.thrfeed.com/2009/04/abc-to-offer-shows-on-hulu.html|archive-date= May 4, 2009|dead-url= no|df= mdy-all}} Hulu retains between thirty and fifty percent of advertising revenue generated by the shows it distributes. In November 2009, Hulu also began to establish partnerships with record labels to host music videos and concert performances on the site, including [[EMI]] in November 2009,{{cite news|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2356071,00.asp|title=Hulu, EMI Strike Deal for Music Videos, Concerts|date=November 18, 2009|publisher=PC Magazine|accessdate=24 December 2009|first=Chloe|last=Albanesius|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091121155534/http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2356071,00.asp|archive-date=21 November 2009|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} and [[Warner Music Group]] in December 2009.{{cite news|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2357529,00.asp|title=Hulu, Warner Music Sign Deal for Music Content|date=December 23, 2009|publisher=PC Magazine|accessdate=24 December 2009|first=Chloe|last=Albanesius|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091227044623/http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2357529,00.asp|archive-date=27 December 2009|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In early March 2010, [[Viacom]] announced that it was pulling two of the website's most popular shows, ''[[The Colbert Report]]'' and ''[[The Daily Show]]'', off Hulu.''[[New York Daily News]]'' article: "[http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/2010/03/03/2010-03-03_comedy_central_pulls_daily_show_and_colbert_off_hulu.html Comedy Central's 'The Daily Show' and 'The Colbert Report' off Hulu] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100306151209/http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/2010/03/03/2010-03-03_comedy_central_pulls_daily_show_and_colbert_off_hulu.html |date=2010-03-06 }}." The programs had been airing on Hulu since late 2008. A spokesman for [[Viacom]] noted that "in the current economic model, there is not that much in it for us to continue at this time. If they can get to the point where the monetization model is better, then we may go back."Multichannel News article: "[http://www.multichannel.com/article/449861-Dauman_Vivendi_Could_Return_To_Hulu.php Dauman: Vivendi Could Return To Hulu]." In February 2011, both shows were made available for streaming on Hulu again. ''The Daily Show'' was again removed from Hulu in March 2017 in order to push viewers to watch the program on Viacom and Comedy Central's apps. Hulu will be the exclusive streaming home for R-rated films from Disney's [[Touchstone Pictures]] and [[Hollywood Pictures]] labels and [[20th Century Fox]]'s pre-[[Proposed acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney|Disney-Fox merger]] film library, as [[Disney streaming service|Disney's upcoming streaming service]] will not feature any R-rated films.{{cite web|author=Mike Fleming Jr|title=Disney Unveils Inaugural Streaming Service Launch Slate To Town; No R-Rated Fare|url=http://deadline.com/2018/02/disney-streaming-service-launch-slate-star-wars-marvel-1202281846/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=April 5, 2018|date=February 8, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180226065353/http://deadline.com/2018/02/disney-streaming-service-launch-slate-star-wars-marvel-1202281846/|archivedate=February 26, 2018|df=}} Hulu in May 2018 announced its first-ever license deal with [[DreamWorks Animation]], becoming the exclusive streaming home for future DWA movies feature films, as well as library films. DWA had streamed exclusively through Netflix since 2013. === Original content === {{Further|List of original programs distributed by Hulu}} From January 17, 2011 to April 24, 2014, Hulu streamed its own in-house web series ''[[The Morning After (web series)|The Morning After]]'', a light-hearted pop-culture news show. It was produced by Hulu in conjunction with [[Jace Hall]]'s HDFilms and stars Brian Kimmet and Ginger Gonzaga. Producing the show was a first for the company, which in the past has been primarily a content distributor.{{cite web |url=http://gigaom.com/video/new-series-the-morning-after-nudges-hulu-into-production/ |title=New Series The Morning After Nudges Hulu Into Production |date=2011-01-18 |author=Liz Shannon Miller |publisher=GigaOM |accessdate=2011-05-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fgigaom.com%2Fvideo%2Fnew-series-the-morning-after-nudges-hulu-into-production%2F&date=2011-07-21 |archivedate=2011-07-21 |df= }} On January 16, 2012, Hulu announced that it would be airing its first original script based program, titled ''[[Battleground (TV series)|Battleground]]'', which premiered in February 2012. The program aired on Hulu's free web service rather than on the subscription-based Hulu Plus. ''Battleground'' is described as a documentary-style political drama.Rother, Larry, January 16, 2012, [http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/16/hulu-announces-first-original-script-based-program/ "Hulu Announces First Original-Script-Based Program".] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029065859/https://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/16/hulu-announces-first-original-script-based-program/ |date=2017-10-29 }} Later that same month, Hulu announced it would air ''The Fashion Fund'', a six-part reality series, and the winner of the show would receive $300,000 to start their career.Poggi Jeanine January 27, 2012. [http://adage.com/article/mediaworks/hulu-introduces-fashion-fund-original-reality-series/232384/ Hulu Adds Unscripted Series 'The Fashion Fund,' Accelerating Original Content Effort."] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120710210257/http://adage.com/article/mediaworks/hulu-introduces-fashion-fund-original-reality-series/232384/ |date=2012-07-10 }} To continue with its original programming movement, Hulu announced that there would be a total of seven original programs that were planned to air on its service: ''Battleground'', ''Day in the Life'', and ''Up to Speed'' were previously mentioned; and on April 19, Hulu added four more shows to its list: ''Don't Quit Your Daydream'', ''Flow'', ''The Awesomes'', and ''We Got Next''. Some of these programs began airing in 2012, while others premiered over the next few years.{{cite news|author=Perez, Sarah|date=April 19, 2012|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/04/19/hulu-announces-four-more-original-series-will-feature-snl-vets-adrian-grenier-of-hbos-entourage-others/|work=TechCrunch|title=Hulu Announces Four More Original Series|access-date=December 11, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029174512/https://techcrunch.com/2012/04/19/hulu-announces-four-more-original-series-will-feature-snl-vets-adrian-grenier-of-hbos-entourage-others/|archive-date=October 29, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} On May 21, 2012, Hulu announced it would be bringing [[Kevin Smith]] to its line-up of original programming. Smith hosts a movie discussion show titled ''[[Spoilers (TV series)|Spoilers]]'', which began airing in mid-2012.{{cite news|author=Wasserman, Todd|date=May 21, 2012|title=Hulu to Launch New Show With Kevin Smith Plus 9 Other Titles|url=http://mashable.com/2012/05/21/hulu-new-shows-kevin-smith/|work=Mashable|access-date=December 11, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029174001/http://mashable.com/2012/05/21/hulu-new-shows-kevin-smith/|archive-date=October 29, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} In March 2016, [[Lionsgate Premiere]] and Hulu jointly acquired distribution rights to the film, ''[[Joshy (film)|Joshy]]'',{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/03/lionsgate-hulu-joshy-1201712664/|title=Lionsgate, Hulu Acquire Comedy 'Joshy'|website=Deadline Hollywood|first=Anita|last=Busch|date=March 1, 2016|accessdate=March 2, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160302195219/http://deadline.com/2016/03/lionsgate-hulu-joshy-1201712664/|archive-date=March 2, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} which was later released on August 12, 2016.{{cite web|url=https://thefilmstage.com/reviews/sundance-review-joshy/|title=Joshy Sundance 2016 Film Review|website=The Film Stage|date=January 26, 2016|accessdate=May 16, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160616225857/https://thefilmstage.com/reviews/sundance-review-joshy/|archive-date=June 16, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} On May 4, 2016, Hulu acquired ''[[The Beatles: Eight Days a Week]]'', as its first documentary acquisition, as part of a planned Hulu Documentary Films collection.{{cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/5/4/11589950/hulu-documentaries-ron-howard-the-beatles-eight-days-a-week|title=Hulu is getting into documentaries, starting with Ron Howard's Beatles film|last=Kastrenakes|first=Jacob|date=4 May 2016|work=[[The Verge]]|accessdate=16 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160507104718/http://www.theverge.com/2016/5/4/11589950/hulu-documentaries-ron-howard-the-beatles-eight-days-a-week|archive-date=7 May 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The film premiered theatrically on 15 September, before debuting on the streaming service on 17 September.{{cite web|title=Watch the Trailer for ''The Beatles: Eight Days a Week – The Touring Years''|accessdate=20 June 2016|url=http://www.thebeatles.com/news/watch-trailer-beatles-eight-days-week-touring-years|publisher=[[The Beatles]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160624042652/http://www.thebeatles.com/news/watch-trailer-beatles-eight-days-week-touring-years|archive-date=24 June 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} === ''South Park'' === On July 12, 2014, it was announced that Hulu had signed a three-year deal purchasing exclusive online streaming rights to the ''[[South Park]]'' library. Through the deal, the [[South Park]] Studios website became powered by Hulu video and featured advertising.{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/pecom/20140712005015/en|title=Hulu and South Park Announce Exclusive Multi-Year Content Licensing Deal at 2014 Television Critics Association Summer Press Tour – Business Wire|work=businesswire.com|access-date=2017-12-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171212193104/https://www.businesswire.com/news/pecom/20140712005015/en|archive-date=2017-12-12|dead-url=no|df=}} Along with this, the domain name changed from "southparkstudios.com" to "southpark.cc.com".{{cite web|url=http://southparkstudios.com|title=South Park – Watch Full Episodes, Clips & More|work=southparkstudios.com|access-date=2017-12-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712171540/http://www.southparkstudios.com/|archive-date=2014-07-12|dead-url=no|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://southpark.cc.com|title=South Park – Watch Full Episodes, Clips & More|work=cc.com|access-date=2017-12-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170927005623/http://southpark.cc.com/|archive-date=2017-09-27|dead-url=no|df=}} Previously, the show had been available on the television website [[Netflix]].{{cite web|url=http://www.knowyourmobile.com/apps/20082/netflix-removes-south-park-and-other-titles-its-library|title=Netflix removes South Park and other titles from its library|work=Know Your Mobile|access-date=2017-12-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171212032206/http://www.knowyourmobile.com/apps/20082/netflix-removes-south-park-and-other-titles-its-library|archive-date=2017-12-12|dead-url=no|df=}} The new site launch caused some technical issues, which were resolved allowing fans to watch uncensored{{cite web|url=http://www.maxim.com/gadgets/all-uncensored-south-park-episodes-available-legally-free-online |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-09-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141019085802/http://www.maxim.com/gadgets/all-uncensored-south-park-episodes-available-legally-free-online |archivedate=2014-10-19 |df= }} episodes and clips. For viewers outside the US, episodes and clips still stream through the "classic" South Park player and nothing changed aside from the new site design. A handful of countries also have their own localized versions of South Park sites, with the old experience.{{cite web|url=http://southpark.cc.com/blog/2014/07/28/south-park-new-site-faqs|title=South Park – New Site FAQs|work=cc.com|access-date=2017-12-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171212031653/http://southpark.cc.com/blog/2014/07/28/south-park-new-site-faqs|archive-date=2017-12-12|dead-url=no|df=}} It was announced that beginning in September 2014, following the premiere of the 18th season, only 30 select episodes will be featured for free viewing at a time on the website, with new episodes being available for an entire month starting the day following their original airings. The entire series (with the exception of "[[Super Best Friends]]", "[[200 (South Park)|200]]", and "[[201 (South Park)|201]]") is available for viewing on the Hulu subscription service. === AT&T === On May 14, 2015, [[AT&T]] struck a deal with Hulu that would give its customers access to streaming service on both regular and premium tiers.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedrum.com/news/2015/05/14/att-strikes-deal-hulu-offer-subscription-service-its-customers|title=AT&T strikes deal with Hulu to offer subscription service to its customers|last=Smiley|first=Minda|work=The Drum|date=May 14, 2015|accessdate=May 14, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518075715/http://www.thedrum.com/news/2015/05/14/att-strikes-deal-hulu-offer-subscription-service-its-customers|archive-date=May 18, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} On October 22, 2016, AT&T announced a deal to buy [[Time Warner]], who owns 10% of Hulu, for $108.7 billion.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2016/10/22/reports-t-agrees-buy-time-warner-more-than-80b/92589816/|title=AT&T agrees to buy Time Warner for more than $80B|last=Yu|first=Roger|work=USA 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/at-t-reaches-deal-to-buy-time-warner-for-more-than-80-billion-1477157084|title=AT&T Reaches Deal to Buy Time Warner for $86 Billion|last=Gryta|first=Thomas|last2=Hagey|first2=Keach|last3=Cimilluca|first3=Dana|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=October 22, 2016|accessdate=October 22, 2016|subscription=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161023013659/http://www.wsj.com/articles/at-t-reaches-deal-to-buy-time-warner-for-more-than-80-billion-1477157084|archive-date=October 23, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/biz/news/att-time-warner-deal-1201897938/|title=AT&T Sets $85.4 Billion Time Warner Deal, CEOs Talk 'Unique' Potential of Combination|last=Littleton|first=Cynthia|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=October 22, 2016|accessdate=October 23, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161023204133/http://variety.com/2016/biz/news/att-time-warner-deal-1201897938/|archive-date=October 23, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} In November 2017, the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Justice Department]] said it was moving to sue to block the AT&T-Time Warner merger.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/20/business/dealbook/att-time-warner-merger.html|title=Justice Department Sues to Block AT&T-Time Warner Merger|last=Kang|first=Cecilia|date=2017-11-20|work=The New York Times|access-date=December 11, 2017|last2=Merced|first2=Michael J. de la|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171211123601/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/20/business/dealbook/att-time-warner-merger.html|archive-date=December 11, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} AT&T completed their merger in June 2018, winning the lawsuit from the Justice Department. === Neon Alley === At the start of April 2014, [[Neon Alley]], a [[Viz Media]]-owned 24/7 anime-oriented streaming service that started on October 2, 2012,{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2012-10-02/viz-debuts-neon-alley|title=Viz Debuts Neon Alley|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160628222130/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2012-10-02/viz-debuts-neon-alley|archive-date=28 June 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} streaming to both US and Canadian markets (similar to Æsir Media Group LLC and Valkyrie Media Partners LLC's [[Anime Network]], [[AT&T]]'s [[Crunchyroll]] and [[Aniplex of America]]'s [[Aniplex of America#Aniplex Channel|Aniplex Channel]]), discontinued its web network format and relaunched as a Free Video on Demand ([[Video on demand|FVOD]]) service streaming anime to the US market through its website or [[Internet]]-connected devices through Hulu. As a result, with Hulu being unable to stream to the Canadian market, Neon Alley stopped streaming to that market and restricted its service to the US market only. This leaves [[Anime Network]], [[Crunchyroll]], [[Daisuki (website)|Daisuki]] and [[Aniplex of America#Aniplex Channel|Aniplex Channel]] as the only anime-focused streaming services streaming to the Canadian market at the same time as the US market, though these four all continue today. On July 21, 2016, [[Tubi TV]] announced that they had commenced streaming of certain Viz titles in Canada.{{cite web|url=http://tubitv.com/blog/2016/07/21/stream-naruto-sailor-moon-viz-media-partners-tubi-tv-deliver-free-anime/|title=Stream Naruto, Sailor Moon & More: VIZ Media Partners with Tubi TV to Deliver Free Anime|publisher=Tubi TV|date=July 21, 2016|accessdate=October 1, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171024131340/http://tubitv.com/blog/2016/07/21/stream-naruto-sailor-moon-viz-media-partners-tubi-tv-deliver-free-anime/|archive-date=October 24, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} Hulu is known for streaming anime titles from many distributors, including [[Funimation]], [[TMS Entertainment]], and [[Bandai Visual]], in addition to Viz Media. === == Availability == {{As of|June 2015}}, access to Hulu is not available internationally outside of the United States and Japan.{{cite web|title=Why can't I use Hulu internationally?|url=http://www.hulu.com/help/articles/171122|website=Hulu.com|accessdate=12 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150609184822/http://www.hulu.com/help/articles/171122|archive-date=9 June 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} === International expansion === In July 2010, the ''[[Financial Times]]'' revealed that Hulu had been working on plans for an international launch of Hulu Plus for several months, and had identified the UK and Japan as markets where its free website and subscription model could feasibly work.Garrahan, Matthew. [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f01d42b0-8ade-11df-bead-00144feab49a.html Hulu eyes launching global pay platform] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924150838/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f01d42b0-8ade-11df-bead-00144feab49a.html |date=2015-09-24 }}, ''Financial Times'', July 8, 2010. Retrieved July 11, 2010. Hulu chief executive Jason Kilar expressed his belief that the US model could be replicated elsewhere, saying "We won't be satisfied until this is a global service."Laughlin, Andrew. [http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a240992/hulu-puts-uk-launch-back-on-agenda.html Hulu 'puts UK launch back on agenda'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110921051701/http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a240992/hulu-puts-uk-launch-back-on-agenda.html |date=2011-09-21 }}, ''Digital Spy'', July 9, 2010. Retrieved July 11, 2010. Hulu's first expansion into an international market took place with the launch of a service in Japan on September 1, 2011.{{cite web |title=Hulu officially launches streaming service in Japan |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/hulu-officially-launches-streaming-service-in-japan/ |website=CNET |accessdate=18 July 2018 |language=en |date=1 September 2011}} On November 8th, 2018, Disney announced that after the closure of their acquisition of 21st Century Fox (which would give them majority control in Hulu), they intend on expanding Hulu to other international markets.{{cite web |title=Disney Confirms Hulu Will Be Offered Internationally After Fox Purchase |url=https://comicbook.com/movies/2018/11/08/hulu-international-subscription-after-disney-fox-purchase/ |website=Comicbook.com |accessdate=8 November 2018 |language=en}} ==== Nippon TV acquisition of Hulu Japan service ==== On February 27, 2014, Nippon Television Network Corporation ([[Nippon TV]]) acquired Hulu's Japan business. The transaction, which is subject to certain regulatory conditions, marked Nippon TV's entry into the SVOD (Subscription Video On Demand) business. Through the acquisition, the Hulu service continues to offer Japanese consumers premium content, including Hollywood and Japanese films and dramas and popular television programming. Additionally, Nippon TV's popular shows and original exclusive content launched on the Hulu service in Japan, expanding its content offering.{{cite news |title=Nippon TV Acquires Hulu Service in Japan |url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20140227006802/en/Nippon-TV-Acquires-Hulu-Service-Japan |publisher=Businesswire |date=2014-02-27 |access-date=2017-12-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205125604/http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20140227006802/en/Nippon-TV-Acquires-Hulu-Service-Japan |archive-date=2017-12-05 |dead-url=no |df= }} Japanese users have access to a library of popular television shows such as the CSI franchise, ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]'', ''[[Prison Break]]'', and ''[[Ugly Betty]]'', and as well as movies such as ''[[Armageddon (1998 film)|Armageddon]]'', ''[[Men in Black (1997 film)|Men in Black]]'', and ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean]]''.{{cite web |title= Hulu launches its first overseas operation in Japan |url= http://asiapacificarts.usc.edu/article@apa?hulu_launches_its_first_overseas_operation_in_japan_17333.aspx |work= Asia Pacific Arts |date= 2011-09-01 |access-date= 2011-09-29 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20131102060011/http://asiapacificarts.usc.edu/article@apa?hulu_launches_its_first_overseas_operation_in_japan_17333.aspx |archive-date= 2013-11-02 |dead-url= no |df= }} === Absence in Canadian market === Hulu is unable to launch in Canada due to the relatively small size of Canada's online advertising market{{cite web|last1=Mudhar|first1=Raju|title=Why these five well-known online services snub Canada|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2016/01/04/why-are-these-five-well-known-online-services-snubbing-canada.html|website=Toronto Star|accessdate=1 November 2016|date=4 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161103235733/https://www.thestar.com/business/2016/01/04/why-are-these-five-well-known-online-services-snubbing-canada.html|archive-date=3 November 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} and because Canada's television networks already have the exclusive online streaming rights in Canada to several titles offered on Hulu, including many mainstream American television network programs.{{cite web |url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/answerman/2015-02-20/.85204 |title=Life Is Just a Game |department=Answerman (column) |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |accessdate=8 August 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160628230637/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/answerman/2015-02-20/.85204 |archive-date=28 June 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} The absence of Hulu in the Canadian market raised concerns by fans of the sitcom ''[[The Mindy Project]]'' when it was cancelled by Fox in the spring of 2015 and subsequently picked up by Hulu; the show's Canadian broadcaster, [[City (TV network)|City]], subsequently announced it would continue to air the series in Canada.{{cite web|title=Mindy Project staying on City despite being dropped by Fox|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/television/2015/05/25/mindy-project-staying-on-city-despite-being-dropped-by-fox.html|website=Toronto Star|accessdate=27 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150928204054/http://www.thestar.com/entertainment/television/2015/05/25/mindy-project-staying-on-city-despite-being-dropped-by-fox.html|archive-date=28 September 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} At present, Canadian consumers have access to several other streaming systems, including a Canadian version of [[Netflix]], [[Amazon Video]] and [[Crave (streaming service)|Crave]], with Crave streaming some programming from Hulu. == See also == * [[Amazon Video]] * [[CBS All Access]] * [[Digital rights management]] * [[Netflix]] * [[Seeso]], a similar service launched by NBC Universal in 2016 focusing on comedy * [[Sling TV]] * [[Video on demand]] == Notes == {{reflist|group=note}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *
