<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:hot.JPG|right|thumb|Torch Juggling]] --> [[Image:Torchjuggling.jpg|thumb|Torch juggling in [[Salamanca Place|Salamanca, Tasmania]]]]
'''Juggling torches''' are one of various [[juggling prop|props]] used by [[jugglers]]. Torches are usually commercially made props that are made of wood and/or metal with a wick attached at one end. The wick is impregnated with a flammable substance (usually [[Kerosene|paraffin]]) and ignited before use.
== Wicks == The two most common wicks used with juggling torches are: *[[Kevlar]] para-aramid *[[Cotton]] Both materials come in reels of material ranging from 13mm to 180 mm wide and up to 100 m long. Around 40–80 cm of wick is wrapped onto each torch. In general, it is best to use hard limiting devices, such as nuts and bolts, to hold the wick onto the shaft of the torch.
== Construction == The torch is usually constructed around a wooden dowel which runs the length of the torch from the knob (base) to the top. The lower 8-10 inch section is fitted with a [[Handle (grip)|handle]], and is the section the juggler uses to catch and throw the torch. The handle can be covered in spiral wound plastic, cloth or leather. The middle of the torch is often larger in diameter than the handle and this section helps to balance the torch and makes it easier to juggle. The upper portion of the dowel is often covered in metal (usually aluminium) with the uppermost section covered in a wick. The wick is wrapped around the top of the shaft several times and secured with screws into the wooden core.
Torches as described are commercially available from all the main juggling/circus skills manufacturers such as [[Renegade Juggling]] (as pictured above), Dubé, [[Beard]], [http://flamesngames.co.uk Flames 'N Games], [[Mister Babache]], Henrys, [http://www.playjuggling.com Play], [[Infinite Illusions]] and cost anywhere from around 15GBP to around 25GBP each. The Ivan's Torch by SupremeFire retail at up to 105GBP ($199.99 USD) per torch.
== Fuels ==
The most common fuel used with juggling fire torches in the US is [[white gas]], or Coleman fuel. Beginning torch jugglers usually use some form of lamp oil (like barbecue lighter fluid or kerosene) since it burns cooler than white gas and is easier on the club itself. Alcohol is generally not considered a good fuel for juggling torches. In the UK fire jugglers almost exclusively use paraffin (kerosene) or lamp oil - treated paraffin that emits less smoke. <ref>[http://www.jugglingdb.com/compendium/skills/fire/juggling.html#fuel Juggling with torches<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== Balls ==
It is possible to buy flammable juggling balls. Gloves are often needed but not always; fyrefli juggling balls for example are designed so the flame sits a few centimeters above the hand. Ball juggling is easier than club juggling, and with juggling fire balls, any stage performances look impressive. However, juggling necessarily requires the hands to alternately grip the flaming balls for 1 or more 'juggling beats'(usually around 0.5 second), known as 'dwell time'. This restricts the size of flame and the duration of the burn to avoid overheating the hands, even with gloves. For these reasons all commercially available fire juggling balls use a smaller wick and flame than standard juggling torches. Some enthusiasts have attempted to overcome this problem using fuel-soaked balls of kevlar rope and welding gloves or similar, but have been unable to achieve more than 30 seconds of useful juggling before the gloves catch fire.
== See also == * [[Fire performance]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.beardjuggling.co.uk/resource/fire-wick-care-instructions Looking after and using fire wicks]
{{Juggling}} [[Category:Twirling]] [[Category:Toss juggling]] [[Category:Fire arts]] [[Category:Juggling props]]

{{Infobox presenter |name = Vic Latino |image = |caption = |birth_name = Victor J. Canales |birth_date = |birth_place = [[Long Island, New York]] |death_date = |death_place = |show = Vic Latino's Neighborhood |station = [[WPTY]] |timeslot = 6:00 a.m. - 10:00 a.m. |style = [[Radio presenter]]
[[Disc jockey]] |country = [[United States]] |prevshow = |web = {{URL|www.viclatino.com}} }} '''Vic Latino''' (born '''Victor J. Canales'''http://www.cmw.net/cmw2009/conference_speaker_bio.asp?panel_ID=0&speaker_ID=1576{{dead link|date=July 2016|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}} in [[Long Island, New York]]) is an American [[radio personality|radio]] and [[television personality]] of Spanish descent. He is co-founder of [[JVC Broadcasting]] which owns radio stations on Long Island and in the state of Florida.[http://www.jvcbroadcasting.com/ JVC Broadcasting] Retrieved January 18, 2018. In conjunction with his radio career, Canales has released several mix albums, including two volumes of ThriveMix, three volumes of [[Ultra.Dance]] and two volumes of Ultra.Mix (on [[ThriveDance]] and [[Ultra Records]]), 1980s Now, Summer Vibes and One Night in N.Y.C. (all on [[Tommy Boy Records]]). ==Career== ===Radio=== Canales began his radio career as part of [[Ed Lover]] and [[Doctor Dré]]'s morning show on [[WQHT|Hot 97]]. He later moved to [[Long Island, New York|Long Island]] stations [[WBLI]] and [[WPTY|WXXP]] , also WPYO in Orlando, Florida before landing a position at [[WKTU]], where he helped make the station's p.m.-drive show the city's second-highest rated, behind only [[Funkmaster Flex]]'s around the same time until November 2006. After leaving WKTU, he joined BPM on Sirius/XM. He later returned to his hometown station [[WPTY]], where he took the duties of the managing partner of Long Island’s own [[WPTY|WDRE]], [[WLIR]] and [[WBON]]. ===Television=== Canales has made television appearances on various networks such as [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], [[National Broadcasting Company|NBC]], [[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]], [[CBS]] and the [[The WB Television Network|WB]].{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p542024/biography|pure_url=yes}} He also made an appearance on [[A&E Network|A&E]]'s ''[[Growing Up Gotti]]''{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p542024/biography|pure_url=yes}} and on the [[Emmy Award]] winning ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'', where he [[DJ]]'ed the opening monologue.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2275296/|title=Vic Latino|publisher=[[IMDb]]|accessdate=January 18, 2018}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== *2005: ''One Night in N.Y.C.'' ===Mixed compilations=== *2002: ''80s Now'' *2003: ''Summer Vibes'' *2004: ''[[Ultra.Dance 05]]'' *2005: ''[[Ultra.Dance 06]]'' *2006: ''ThriveMix 02'' *2007: ''ThriveMix 03'' *2008: ''[[Ultra.Mix]]'' *2009: ''[[Ultramix 2|Ultra.Mix 2]]'' *2011: ''[[Ultra.Dance 12]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.viclatino.com/}} *{{SoundCloud}} *{{Discogs artist}} *{{IMDb name|02275296}} *[http://www.party105.com/our-jocks/vic-latino/pages/vic-latino-bio Party FM Profile] *{{cite web|url=http://libn.com/blog/2009/01/29/vic-canales-speaks-out-about-li-radio/|title=Vic Canales speaks out about LI radio|author=David Reich-Hale|date=January 29, 2009}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Latino, Vic}} [[Category:American radio DJs]] [[Category:American record producers]] [[Category:American television personalities]] [[Category:Club DJs]] [[Category:Sirius Satellite Radio]] [[Category:New York City nightlife]] [[Category:People from Long Island]] [[Category:Radio personalities from New York City]] [[Category:American people of Puerto Rican descent]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{short description|2013 single by Miley Cyrus}} {{Infobox song | name = Wrecking Ball | cover = Miley Cyrus - Wrecking Ball.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Miley Cyrus]] | album = [[Bangerz]] | released = {{start date|2013|8|25}} | format = {{hlist|[[CD single]]|[[Music download|digital download]]}} | recorded = 2013 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]] | length = {{duration|m=3|s=41}}<ref name=AllMusic/> | label = [[RCA Records|RCA]] | writer = {{hlist|[[Dr. Luke|Lukasz Gottwald]]|[[Mozella|Maureen "Mozella" McDonald]]|Kiyanu Kim<ref>see, http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/catching_up_with_kiyanu_kim (BMI news article discussing Kim's contribution to the song).</ref>|[[Stephan Moccio]]|[[Sacha Skarbek]]|[[Cirkut (record producer)|Henry Walter]]}} | producer = {{hlist|[[Dr. Luke]]|[[Cirkut (record producer)|Cirkut]]}} | prev_title = [[We Can't Stop]] | prev_year = 2013 | next_title = [[23 (song)|23]] | next_year = 2013 | misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|My2FRPA3Gf8|"Wrecking Ball"}}}} }}
"'''Wrecking Ball'''" is a song recorded by American singer [[Miley Cyrus]] for her fourth studio album ''[[Bangerz]]'' (2013). It was released on August 25, 2013, by [[RCA Records]] as the album's second single. The song was written by [[MoZella]], [[Stephan Moccio]], [[Sacha Skarbek]], [[Kiyanu Kim]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/catching_up_with_kiyanu_kim|title=Catching Up With Kiyanu Kim|website=BMI.com|access-date=2016-03-26}}</ref> [[Dr. Luke|Lukasz Gottwald]], and [[Cirkut (record producer)|Henry Russell Walter]];<ref>https://secure.harryfox.com/songfile/public/publicsearch.do (first entry on Harry Fox Agency songfile website listing writers); http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=30531 (songfacts website identifying writers and writing process)</ref> production was helmed by the last two. "Wrecking Ball" is a [[pop ballad]] which lyrically discusses the deterioration of a relationship.
"Wrecking Ball" debuted on the U.S. [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] at number 50, and later became Cyrus' first number-one single in the United States after the release of its controversial music video; it retained the peak position during the following week. Nine weeks later, the track returned to number one, and consequently had the largest gap between number-one sittings in ''Billboard'' Hot 100 history without dropping out between. As of January 2014, "Wrecking Ball" has sold three million copies in the United States. Internationally, the song charted strongly; it topped the charts in Canada, Spain and the United Kingdom, and charted in the top ten throughout much of Europe and Oceania.
An accompanying music video for "Wrecking Ball" was released on September 9, 2013. It featured close-up scenes of Cyrus tearfully singing, reminiscent of the clip for "[[Nothing Compares 2 U]]" by [[Sinéad O'Connor]], interspersed with footage of a nude Cyrus swinging on a [[wrecking ball]]. Critics were divided in their opinions of the music video, feeling that it was more provocative than the clip for her previous single "[[We Can't Stop]]". "Wrecking Ball" previously held the [[Vevo]] record for the most views in the first 24 hours after its release with 19.3 million views. At the [[2013 MTV Europe Music Awards]], Cyrus took home the award for Best Video and the award for Video of the Year at the [[2014 MTV Video Music Awards]]. Adding to the video's success, Cyrus won the award for World's Best Video at the [[2014 World Music Awards]] in Monte Carlo. Cyrus has performed "Wrecking Ball" during several live performances, including the [[iHeartRadio]] Music Festival and an episode of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.
==Background== [[File:Beyonce - Montreal 2013 (3) crop.jpg|thumb|150px|"Wrecking Ball" was originally written with [[Beyoncé]] (''pictured'') in mind before being offered to Cyrus.]]
Before directly stating that "Wrecking Ball" was originally written with [[Beyoncé]] in mind, songwriter [[Sacha Skarbek]] tweeted "Beyonce song now becoming a Miley Cyrus song?!! Good/bad? I don't know??!!!! {{sic}}" in December 2012.<ref name="Beyonce">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/news/a541314/miley-cyruss-wrecking-ball-written-in-session-meant-for-beyonce.html|title=Miley Cyrus's 'Wrecking Ball' written in session meant for Beyoncé|author=Meg Drewett|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]. [[Hearst Corporation]]|date=January 3, 2014|accessdate=January 15, 2014}}</ref> His representative commented that ""Originally, the [songwriting session between Dr. Luke and Sacha] was booked to write a song for Beyoncé. But as the song ['Wrecking Ball'] progressed, the songwriters realized the song would not work for her."<ref name="Beyonce"/>
The song, and the cover of its parent album ''[[Bangerz]]'' (2013), were unveiled on August 25, 2013, before Cyrus' performance at the [[2013 MTV Video Music Awards]]. She released the cover artwork for "Wrecking Ball" on September 6, which shows Cyrus dressed in a sleeveless white shirt and underwear while swinging on a [[wrecking ball]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sugarscape.com/main-topics/music/951308/miley-cyrus-unveils-wrecking-ball-artwork-and-announces-music-video-premier|title=Miley Cyrus unveils 'Wrecking Ball' artwork and announces music video premiere|author=Carl Smith|publisher=[[Sugarscape.com]]|date=September 6, 2013|accessdate=January 15, 2014}}</ref> The song was serviced to [[contemporary hit radio]] stations in the United States on September 17.<ref name="CHR"/> It serves as the second single from ''Bangerz'', following the [[lead single]] "[[We Can't Stop]]", which was released in June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rcarecords.com/news/miley-cyrus-scores-her-first-billboard-hot-100-1-%E2%80%9Cwrecking-ball%E2%80%9D|title=Miley Cyrus Scores Her First Billboard Hot 100 #1 with 'Wrecking Ball'|publisher=[[RCA Records]]|date=September 18, 2013|accessdate=January 26, 2014}}</ref>
==Composition== {{Listen | filename = Wrecking Ball.ogg | title = "Wrecking Ball" | description = A 22-second sample of "Wrecking Ball" by Miley Cyrus, where the chorus is heard. | pos = left }} "Wrecking Ball" is a [[pop ballad]];<ref name="RollingStone">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/miley-cyrus-drops-wrecking-ball-20130825|title=Miley Cyrus Drops 'Wrecking Ball'|author=Miriam Coleman|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|publisher=[[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media, LLC]]|date=August 25, 2013|accessdate=January 15, 2014}}</ref><ref name="jason"/> <!--Stacy Lambe of [[VH1]] has also described it as a [[power pop]] song.<ref name=SL>{{cite web|url=http://www.vh1.com/music/tuner/2014-08-20/miley-cyrus-vma-performance/|title=Miley Cyrus’ Video Music Awards Performance by the Numbers|author=Lambe, Stacy|date=August 20, 2014|publisher=[[VH1]]|accessdate=August 22, 2014}}</ref>--> According to the sheet music published at Musicnotes.com by [[Kobalt Label Services|Kobalt Music Publishing America]], it is set in common time with a [[tempo]] of 60 beats per minute.<ref name="MusicNotes">{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtdFPE.asp?ppn=MN0123392|title=Miley Cyrus "Wrecking Ball" Sheet Music – Download & Print|publisher=MusicNotes|accessdate=January 15, 2014}}</ref> The track is written in the [[key (music)|key]] of [[D minor]] and follows the [[chord progression]] Dm–F–C–Gm.<ref name="MusicNotes"/> Miriam Coleman of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' noted that it begins with a [[Minimal music|minimalist]] keyboard instrumentation, which puts emphasis on Cyrus "anguished vocals", and also described it as a "heartbroken counterpoint" to "We Can't Stop".<ref name="RollingStone"/> Cyrus said that "Wrecking Ball" was inspired by "[[OneRepublic]], and the way [[Timbaland]] used to do those big ballads."<ref>{{cite web|last=Diehl|first=Matt|title=Miley Cyrus 2.0: The Billboard Cover Story|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/1567023/miley-cyrus-20-the-billboard-cover-story|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=October 3, 2013|date=June 14, 2013}}</ref>
==Critical reception== "Wrecking Ball" gained mostly positive reviews from contemporary music critics. Writing for ''[[The A.V. Club]]'', Marah Eakin provided a favorable review, calling it a "solid ballad" and describing it as "a modern day '[[My Heart Will Go On]]' that discussed a deteriorated, shortlived young romance."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/miley-cyrus-ibangerzi-103885|title=Miley Cyrus: Bangerz: Music: MusicalWork Review|author=Mariah Eakin|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|publisher=[[The Onion]]|date=October 8, 2013|accessdate=October 10, 2013}}</ref> [[Kitty Empire]] from ''[[The Observer]]'' opined that "the heartbreak section of ''Bangerz'' mostly repays your attention" and mentioned "Wrecking Ball" to be a part of it.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2013/oct/04/miley-cyrus-bangerz-review|title=Miley Cyrus: Bangerz – review|author=Kitty Empire|newspaper=[[The Observer]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|date=October 3, 2013|accessdate=October 4, 2013}}</ref> Although he found the song "predictable," Evan Sawdey of [[PopMatters]] gave it an overall positive review and complimented its production and the build up to its chorus, calling it "the kind of broad mainstream song that shows how you how to properly build up to a chorus before hitting us over the head with it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/175706-miley-cyrus-bangerz/|title=Miley Cyrus: Bangerz|author=Evan Sawdey|publisher=[[PopMatters]]|date=October 6, 2013|accessdate=October 10, 2013}}</ref> Jon Dolan of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' felt that it "[rides] the hunger and confusion that make great coming-of-age pop."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/bangerz-20131004|title=Miley Cyrus 'Bangerz' Review|author=Jon Dolan|work=Rolling Stone|publisher=Wenner Media, LLC|date=October 4, 2013|accessdate=October 4, 2013}}</ref> Writing for [[AllMusic]], Heather Phares considered the track to be a standout from ''Bangerz''.<ref name=AllMusic>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/bangerz-mw0002577863|title=Bangerz – Miley Cyrus|author=Heather Phares|publisher=[[AllMusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]]|date=October 8, 2013|accessdate=October 6, 2013}}</ref>
Writing for [[Digital Spy]], Robert Copsey questioned Cyrus' decision to premiere a ballad in the midst of controversies regarding her "salacious exploits", but enjoyed the song itself and opined that it "proves that there's method behind the madness."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/news/a515810/miley-cyrus-wrecking-ball-single-review.html|title=Miley Cyrus: 'Wrecking Ball' – Single review|author=Robert Copsey|publisher=Digital Spy. Hearst Corporation|date=September 16, 2013|accessdate=January 27, 2014}}</ref> In a more mixed review, Joseph Atilano from the ''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]'' appreciated the lyrics for seeming heartfelt, but felt that its production was "comparatively weaker" by comparison to her earlier projects.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.inquirer.net/115965/single-review-wrecking-ball-by-miley-cyrus|title=Single Review: ‘Wrecking Ball’ by Miley Cyrus|author=Joseph Atilano|newspaper=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer, Inc.|date=October 9, 2013|accessdate=January 27, 2014}}</ref> Mikael Wood of ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' felt that the track proved that Cyrus "isn't just a [[Twerking|twerk]]-bot programmed to titillate", but suggested that her "singing throbs with what feels like an embarrassment of emotion" and found it peculiar that the song discussed the singer's relationship with Hemsworth when her public behavior seemingly suggested that she "couldn't care less about" it.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-st-miley-cyrus-review-20131002-story.html|title=Review: Miley Cyrus' 'Bangerz' a rebel yell with a big bang|author=Mikael Wood|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|date=October 2, 2013|accessdate=October 2, 2013}}</ref>
After a month of voting, on March 31, 2014, ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' declared the song to be the winner of the 2014 Hot 100 March Madness and their favorite Top 5 single from the past year. It defeated songs like "[[Holy Grail (Jay-Z song)|Holy Grail]]" by [[Jay-Z]] & [[Justin Timberlake]], "[[Best Song Ever (song)|Best Song Ever]]" by [[One Direction]], "[[Applause (Lady Gaga song)|Applause]]" by [[Lady Gaga]], "[[Timber (Pitbull song)|Timber]]" by [[Pitbull (rapper)|Pitbull]] & [[Kesha]] and finally "[[Just Give Me a Reason]]" by [[Pink (singer)|Pink]] and [[Nate Ruess]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/6029403/hot-100-march-madness-2014-the-winner-is|title=Hot 100 March Madness 2014: The Winner Is…|date=March 31, 2014|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=August 4, 2014}}</ref>
==Commercial performance== Before officially being serviced as a single, "Wrecking Ball" made a "hot shot debut" at number 50 on the U.S. [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] for the week issued on September 7, 2013, with 90,000 downloads in two days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/chart-alert/5679851/chart-moves-lorde-keeps-leaping-with-royals-miley-cyrus-debuts|title=Chart Moves: Lorde Keeps Leaping With 'Royals'; Miley Cyrus Debuts Next Single; Keith Urban Tops Country Airplay|author=Gary Trust|work=Billboard|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=August 30, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> It reached number 14 the following week with 201,000 downloads.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5680131/katy-perry-dethrones-robin-thicke-atop-hot-100|title=Katy Perry Dethrones Robin Thicke Atop Hot 100|author=Gary Trust|work=Billboard|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=September 4, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> After its official premiere as the second single from ''Bangerz'', the track peaked at number one in the United States in its fourth week, heavily assisted by online streaming credits from its recently released music video; this gave Cyrus her first number-one single in the country. It sold 477,000 copies that week, becoming the third-highest single sales week of 2013, behind the 582,000 units moved by "[[I Knew You Were Trouble]]" by [[Taylor Swift]] and the 557,000 units moved by "[[Roar (song)|Roar]]" by [[Katy Perry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5695590/miley-cyrus-wrecking-ball-swings-to-top-of-hot-100|title=Miley Cyrus' 'Wrecking Ball' Swings Atop Hot 100|author=Gary Trust|work=Billboard|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=September 18, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> In December, "Wrecking Ball" returned to the peak position after being stuck at number or two or three the previous nine weeks as Lorde's "Royals" topped the Hot 100, with assistance from a viral parody video and consequently became the largest gap between number-one sittings in ''Billboard'' history without dropping out between. The next week it tumbled to number 5 as Eminem's "The Monster" featuring Rihanna topped the chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5812407/miley-cyrus-wrecking-ball-swings-back-to-no-1-on-hot-100|title=Miley Cyrus' 'Wrecking Ball' Swings Back To No. 1 On Hot 100|author=Gary Trust|work=Billboard|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=December 4, 2013|accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref> As of December 2014, "Wrecking Ball" has sold 3,640,000 copies in the United States.<ref name=us_sales>{{cite web |url=http://www.hitsdailydouble.com/news/newsPage.cgi?news10227m01 |title=The Big 9 in 2014: RCA |work=HITS Daily Double |publisher=HITS Digital Ventures |date=December 11, 2014 |accessdate=December 11, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/Gb7rE|archivedate=October 17, 2017}}</ref> The track peaked at number one on the [[Canadian Hot 100]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/311278/Miley+Cyrus/chart?f=793|title=Miley Cyrus – Chart history|work=Billboard|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> and was later certified triple-platinum in the country.{{Certification Cite Ref|region=Canada|title=Wrecking Ball|artist=Miley Cyrus|type=single|award=Platinum|number=3|relyear=2013|autocat=yes|accessdate=January 18, 2014}} It reached the peak position on the Mexico Ingles Airplay.<ref name="Mexico"/>
"Wrecking Ball" charted strongly throughout Europe. In the United Kingdom, the song and ''[[Bangerz]]'' both debuted at number one on their respective charts in the same week, making Cyrus the first artist of 2013 to achieve a "chart double" in the country.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-24513946|title=Miley Cyrus achieves UK chart double|publisher=BBC News. [[BBC]]|date=October 13, 2013|accessdate=October 13, 2013}}</ref> It was later certified platunium by the [[British Phonographic Industry]].{{Certification Cite Ref|region=United Kingdom|title=Wrecking Ball|artist=Miley Cyrus|type=single|award=Platinum|relyear=2013|autocat=yes|accessdate=January 18, 2014}} Additionally, the song marked Cyrus' second chart-topping single in the country after "[[We Can't Stop]]". In Belgium, it respectively reached numbers four and five on the Belgian [[Ultratop]] in the Flanders and Wallonia regions,<ref name="Charts">{{cite web|url=http://www.ultratop.be/nl/song/121956/Miley-Cyrus-Wrecking-Ball|title=Miley Cyrus – Wrecking Ball|publisher=[[Ultratop]]. Hung Medien|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> and was eventually awarded a gold certification.{{Certification Cite Ref|region=Belgium|title=Wrecking Ball|artist=Miley Cyrus|type=single|award=Gold|relyear=2013|certyear=2013|autocat=yes|accessdate=January 18, 2014}} The track peaked at number six on the [[GfK Entertainment|Official German Charts]],<ref name="Charts"/> and was later certified platinum.{{Certification Cite Ref|region=Germany|title=Wrecking Ball|artist=Miley Cyrus|type=single|award=Platinum|relyear=2013|autocat=yes|accessdate=August 6, 2014}} It charted at number three on the Italian [[Federazione Industria Musicale Italiana|FIMI]] chart,<ref name="Charts"/> and earned a double-platinum certification.{{Certification Cite Ref|region=Italy|title=Wrecking Ball|artist=Miley Cyrus|type=single|award=Platinum|number=2|relyear=2013|autocat=yes|accessdate=October 24, 2014}} In Oceania, "Wrecking Ball" charted at number two on both the Australian [[ARIA Charts]] and the [[Recorded Music NZ|Official New Zealand Music Chart]].<ref name="Charts"/> It was certified quadruple-platinum in the former country,{{Certification Cite Ref|region=Australia|title=Wrecking Ball|artist=Miley Cyrus|type=single|award=Platinum|number=4|relyear=2013|certyear=2014|autocat=yes|accessdate=January 18, 2014}} and was given a platinum certification in the latter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nztop40.co.nz/chart/singles?chart=2273|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103151034/http://nztop40.co.nz/chart/singles?chart=2355|title=NZ Top 40 Singles Chart|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand]]|date=September 23, 2013|archivedate=January 3, 2014}}</ref>
==Music video==
===Synopsis=== An accompanying music video for "Wrecking Ball" was directed by [[Terry Richardson]], and was premiered through [[Vevo]] on September 9, 2013. The clip features close-up footage of Cyrus emotionally singing to the camera against a white backdrop, having been inspired by the music video for "[[Nothing Compares 2 U]]" by [[Sinéad O'Connor]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/sinead-o-connor-pens-open-letter-miley-cyrus-warning-prostitute-article-1.1475086|title=Sinead O’Connor pens open letter to Miley Cyrus: Don’t let them ‘make a prostitute of you’|author1=Chiderah Monde|author2=Stephen Rex Brown|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|publisher=[[Mortimer Zuckerman]]|date=October 3, 2013|accessdate=January 15, 2014}}</ref> Interspersed throughout are scenes of Cyrus licking a [[sledgehammer]] and swinging on a wrecking ball. At first, she is shown dressed in a sleeveless shirt, panties and [[Dr. Martens|Doc Martens]] boots; as the video progresses, she is then shown wearing only the boots.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://popstyle.ew.com/2013/09/09/wrecking-ball-miley-cyrus-isnt-totally-naked-shes-wearing-shoes/|title='Wrecking Ball' Miley Cyrus isn't totally naked – she's wearing shoes|author=Lindsey Scharf|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|date=September 9, 2013|accessdate=January 14, 2014}}</ref>
===Reception=== {{Quote box | quote = "I think the video is much more, if people get past the point that I'm naked and you actually look at me you can tell that I actually look more broken than even the song sounds. The song is a pop ballad. It's one of these songs that everyone is going to relate to, everyone has felt that feeling at one point. If people can take their minds out of the obvious and go into their imagination a little bit and see kind of what the video really means and the way it's so vulnerable and actually if you look in my eyes I look more sad than my voice sounds on the record it was a lot harder to do the video than it was to record the songs. It was much more of an emotional experience." | source = — Cyrus defending the concept of the music video.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1713881/miley-cyrus-defends-wrecking-ball/|title=Miley Cyrus Defends 'Wrecking Ball': It's 'Much More' Than Getting Naked|author=Christina Garibaldi|publisher=MTV News. Viacom|date=September 11, 2013|accessdate=January 15, 2014}}</ref> | align = left | width = 25% }} The music video received generally mixed reviews from critics, who were divided in their opinions regarding Cyrus' increasingly provocative image. Writing for ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', Jason Lipshutz stated that the "nude Cyrus shown straddling a swinging wrecking ball" was the most surprising piece of the clip.<ref name="jason">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/5687261/miley-cyrus-strips-swings-around-naked-in-wrecking-ball-video|title=Miley Cyrus Strips, Swings Around Naked in 'Wrecking Ball' Video: Watch|author=Jason Lipshutz|work=Billboard|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=September 9, 2013|accessdate=January 15, 2014}}</ref> Amelia Proud from ''[[Daily Mail]]'' provided a mixed review, commenting that Cyrus delivered a visual that was more provocative than its "boisterous" predecessor "We Can't Stop" and questioned if she has "finally gone too far this time".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2416186/Miley-Cyrus-gets-fully-naked-straddle-Wrecking-Ball-video-name.html#ixzz2qVr76mMj|title=Has she finally gone too far this time? Miley Cyrus gets fully naked to straddle Wrecking Ball in video of the same name|author=Amelia Proud|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|publisher=[[Daily Mail and General Trust]]|date=September 9, 2013|accessdate=January 15, 2014|location=London}}</ref> The staff from ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' joked that viewers would be "scandalized/titillated/disappointed in [[Billy Ray Cyrus]]' parenting skills" after seeing his daughter nude and "fellating a sledgehammer. {{sic}}"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2013/09/09/miley-cyrus-wrecking-ball-video/|title=Miley Cyrus takes it all off in new 'Wrecking Ball' video – Watch it here|work=Entertainment Weekly|publisher=Time Inc.|date=September 9, 2013|accessdate=January 15, 2014}}</ref> Writing for ''[[The Guardian]]'', Michael Hann criticized Cyrus' attempts to distance herself from her innocent ''[[Hannah Montana]]'' image, a former television series in which Cyrus portrayed the primary character [[Miley Stewart]], a middle school student who led a secret double life as pop star [[Hannah Montana (character)|Hannah Montana]]. He disapproved of the manner in which she transitioned into a career beyond her childhood success, specifically panning her for "exploring the iconography of porn."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2013/sep/10/miley-cyrus-wrecking-ball|title=Miley Cyrus's new Wrecking Ball video says young women should be sexually available|author=Michael Jann|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=Guardian Media Group|date=September 10, 2013|accessdate=January 15, 2014}}</ref> As of January 2015, ''Billboard'' named the video as the fourth best music video of the 2010s (so far).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/6436761/best-music-videos-2010s|title=The 20 Best Music Videos of the 2010s (So Far)|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref>
James Montgomery from [[MTV News]] noted that the controversy surrounding Cyrus' nude performance in the video was "to be expected" given her recent controversies, and complimented Richardson "for toning down the ''salacious'' scenes (if only for an instant), and allowing the softer, more genuine sides to shine through."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1713726/miley-cyrus-wrecking-ball-video/|title=Miley Cyrus Strips Down (In More Ways Than One) With 'Wrecking Ball' Video|author=James Montgomery|publisher=MTV News. Viacom|date=September 9, 2013|accessdate=January 15, 2014}}</ref> Mikael Wood of ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' opined that the music video tried to paint Cyrus in a more serious light with its scenes of her emotionally singing and crying.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-watch-video-wrecking-ball-miley-cyrus-20130909-story.html#ixzz2qVv7tQIP|title=Watch the video for 'Wrecking Ball' by Miley Cyrus|author=Mikael Wood|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|publisher=Tribune Company|date=September 9, 2013|accessdate=January 15, 2014}}</ref>
''Billboard'' editor Jason Lipshutz opined "Wrecking Ball" is Cyrus' "[[Cry Me a River (Justin Timberlake song)|Cry Me a River]]", for their controversial music videos and the artists' music evolution. "A decade ago, [[Justin Timberlake]] was in "My music will shut everyone up" mode, too, as he railed against a teenybopper image". He concluded "Cyrus is breathtaking and talented, and, now that she has our attention with her own version of "Cry Me a River," can dial down the shock tactics and present her artistic vision in the form of a new full-length."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/5719195/why-wrecking-ball-is-miley-cyrus-cry-me-a-river-opinion | title=Why 'Wrecking Ball' Is Miley Cyrus' 'Cry Me A River' (Opinion) | work=Billboard | date=September 19, 2013 | accessdate=April 22, 2016 | author=Lipshutz, Jason}}</ref>
With 19.3 million views in the first twenty-four hours of its release, the clip held the record for having the most views in that time-frame across Vevo platforms.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/miley-cyrus-wrecking-ball-breaks-most-viewed-video-record/|title=Miley Cyrus' "Wrecking Ball" breaks most-viewed video record|author=Jessica Derschowitz|publisher=[[CBS News]][[CBS]]|date=September 10, 2013|accessdate=January 14, 2014}}</ref> The first-day viewing record was surpassed by the video for "[[Anaconda (Nicki Minaj song)|Anaconda]]" by [[Nicki Minaj]] in August 2014, which received 19.6 million views upon its premiere.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6229110/nicki-minaj-anaconda-vevo-record|title=Nicki Minaj's 'Anaconda' Video Breaks Vevo Record|last=Lewis|first=Hilary|work=Billboard|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=August 22, 2014|accessdate=August 22, 2014}}</ref> The video has received over 970 million views on [[YouTube]]. A director's cut of the music video was released on September 24, which features only the close-up footage of Cyrus singing against the white backdrop. Vanessa White Wolf from [[MTV News]] noted that "the only time Richardson cuts away is at the very end, where, after a quick director's credit page, we see Terry and Miley laughing and mugging for the camera."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1714556/miley-cyrus-drops-emotional-wrecking-ball-directors-cut/|title=Miley Cyrus Drops Emotional 'Wrecking Ball' Director's Cut|author=Vanessa White Wolf|publisher=[[MTV News]]. [[Viacom]]|date=September 24, 2013|accessdate=January 14, 2014}}</ref>
The 2014 Australian art prize the [[Bald Archy]] was awarded to Judy Nadin for ''Wrecking Balls Ashes to Ashes'', [[parody]]ing cricketer [[Mitchell Johnson (cricketer)|Mitchell Johnson]] as Cyrus.<ref name=Herrick>{{cite web|last=Herrick|first=Robert|title=Bald Archy Prize: Miley Cyrus-influenced portrait of wrecking ball Mitchell Johnson takes out top gong|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-01-31/bald-archy-caricature-takes-wrecking-ball-to-competition/5231838?&section=news|date = 31 January 2014|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref>
In an interview in 2017, Cyrus stated that she isn't ''a big fan'' of the music video herself. "'Wrecking Ball' -- I'll do it, but I don't love it... It's when you're so stoked about something and then you have to sing a song that bums you out. And I'll never live down when I licked a sledgehammer."<ref name=Ungerman>{{cite web|last=Ungerman |first=Alex|title=Miley Cyrus Really Regrets Her 'Wrecking Ball' Video: 'I'll Always be Known for Licking a Sledgehammer'|url=http://www.etonline.com/music/217755_miley_cyrus_regrets_wrecking_ball_video|date = 17 May 2017|publisher=Entertainment Tonight|accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref>
==Live performances== On September 21, 2013, Cyrus performed "Wrecking Ball" for the first time during the [[iHeartRadio Music Festival]] in [[Las Vegas]]; she performed twice, first in the afternoon at Festival Village, and later in the evening at the [[MGM Grand Garden Arena]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/5719346/miley-cyrus-debuts-wrecking-ball-live-at-iheartradio-performance|title=Miley Cyrus Debuts 'Wrecking Ball' Live at iHeartRadio Performance|author=Jason Lipshutz|work=Billboard|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=September 21, 2013|accessdate=September 23, 2013}}</ref> Despite generating media attention for a provocative wardrobe, the performance was considered to be "fairly tame considering the VMAs",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/ae/music/2013/sep/23/five-thoughts-miley-cyrus-iheart-radio-music-festi/#/0|title=Five thoughts on Miley Cyrus at the iHeartRadio Music Festival Village|author=Mark Adams|newspaper=[[Las Vegas Weekly]]|publisher=[[The Greenspun Corporation]]|date=September 21, 2013|accessdate=September 23, 2013}}</ref> where she touched recording artist [[Robin Thicke]]'s [[crotch]] area with a giant foam finger and [[Twerking|twerked]] against his crotch.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2402415/Miley-Cyrus-VMAs-Parents-label-performance-sexual-exploitation-20-year-old-tried-shed-Disney-image.html|title=Parents' fury at Miley Cyrus' VMA performance as she desperately tried (and succeeded) to shed her wholesome Disney image by simulating sex acts with a foam finger|date=August 26, 2013|newspaper=Daily Mail|publisher=Daily Mail and General Trust|accessdate=August 27, 2013|location=London}}</ref> On October 5, Cyrus served as the host and musical guest during an episode of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', which gained favorable reviews from music critics.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2013/10/06/miley-cyrus-saturday-night-live/2930265/|title=Miley Cyrus steers clear of controversy on 'SNL'|author=Brian Mansfield|newspaper=USA Today|publisher=Gannett Company|date=October 6, 2013|accessdate=October 6, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.idolator.com/7487740/miley-cyrus-belts-out-wrecking-ball-on-saturday-night-live-watch|title=Miley Cyrus Belts Out "Wrecking Ball" Brilliantly On ‘Saturday Night Live": Watch|author=Mike Wass|publisher=Idolator. Spin Media|date=October 5, 2013|accessdate=February 6, 2014}}</ref> The following Monday, Cyrus performed the track on ''[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]'' as part of their Toyota Concert Series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/toyotaconcertseries/miley-cyrus-visits-today-says-i-dont-ever-really-8C11339820|title=Miley Cyrus says she doesn't 'ever really plan to offend'|author=Randee Dawn|work=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]|publisher=NBCUniversal|date=October 7, 2013|accessdate=October 7, 2013}}</ref> She also performed the song during appearances on ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'' and ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'' later that month.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latenightwithjimmyfallon.com/blogs/2013/10/miley-cyrus-performs-wrecking-ball/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222192923/http://www.latenightwithjimmyfallon.com/blogs/2013/10/miley-cyrus-performs-wrecking-ball/|title=Miley Cyrus performs "Wrecking Ball"|author=Marina Cockenberg|work=[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]|date=October 9, 2013|archivedate=February 22, 2014|accessdate=February 6, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/miley-cyrus-breaks-silence-broken-engagement-liam-hemsworth-article-1.1482625|title=Miley Cyrus breaks silence on broken engagement to Liam Hemsworth: 'I'm the happiest I've ever been'|author=Rachel Maresca|newspaper=Daily News|publisher=Mortimer Zuckerman|date=October 11, 2013|accessdate=October 11, 2013|location=New York}}</ref>
In November, Cyrus traveled to Europe to sing "Wrecking Ball" at the [[2013 MTV Europe Music Awards]] in [[Amsterdam]] on November 10, 2013; she garnered media attention for smoking a joint of [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuana]] on-stage while accepting the Best Video Award for the track.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/miley-cyrus-sings-mtv-awards-smokes-pot-article-1.1512550|title=MTV EMAs 2013: Miley Cyrus smokes joint onstage, twerks during performance|author=Jim Farber|newspaper=Daily News|publisher=Mortimer Zuckerman|date=November 10, 2013|accessdate=November 11, 2013|location=New York}}</ref> On November 17, 2013, she performed the song on ''[[The X Factor (UK TV series)|The X Factor]]'' in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/11/16/miley-cyrus-warned-no-twerking-allowed-during-x-factor-performance-4189226/|title=Miley Cyrus warned against twerking during X Factor performance|newspaper=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|publisher=[[DMG Media]]|date=November 16, 2013|accessdate=November 16, 2013}}</ref> After being criticized for delivering a lackluster vocal performance,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/miley-cyrus-x-factor-live-2803194|title=Miley Cyrus' X Factor performance slammed by fans as they criticise her live vocals|author=Owen Tonks|newspaper=Daily Mirror|publisher=Trinity Mirror|date=November 17, 2013|accessdate=November 20, 2013}}</ref> Cyrus was placed under "vocal rest" by her doctors in preparation of the [[Bangerz Tour]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latinpost.com/articles/3893/20131119/miley-cyrus-bangerz-tour-update-doctors-order-stop-singing-ahead.htm|title=Miley Cyrus Bangerz Tour Update: Doctors Order Miley To Stop Singing Ahead of U.S. Tour|author=Esther Jang|publisher=Latin Post|date=November 19, 2013|accessdate=November 20, 2013}}</ref> During her trip, she also performed on ''[[Wetten, dass..?]]'' in Germany (November 9),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2013/11/10/miley-cyrus-performs-wrecking-ball-on-wetten-dass/|title=Miley Cyrus Performs ‘Wrecking Ball’ on ‘Wetten, Dass..?’|work=[[Rap-Up]]|accessdate=November 16, 2013}}</ref> [[BBC Radio 1]]'s [[Live Lounge]] in London (November 12),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/miley-cyrus/news/miley-cyrus-covers-lana-del-rey-for-live-lounge|title=Miley Cyrus Covers Lana Del Rey For Live Lounge|publisher=MTV News. Viacom|date=November 12, 2013|accessdate=November 16, 2013}}</ref> and the 2013 [[Bambi Awards]] in Germany (November 14).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hollywoodlife.com/2013/11/14/miley-cyrus-performing-wrecking-ball-video-bambi-awards-2013/|title=Miley Cyrus Performs ‘Wrecking Ball’ At The Bambi Awards|publisher=Hollywood Life|date=November 14, 2013|accessdate=November 16, 2013}}</ref> On November 24, Cyrus performed "Wrecking Ball" at the [[American Music Awards of 2013|2013 American Music Awards]]; a digitally animated cat projected on the screen behind her lip-synced the lyrics alongside her.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/american-music-awards-2013-miley-cyrus-feline-groove-article-1.1528026|title=American Music Awards 2013: Miley Cyrus performs 'Wrecking Ball' with feline backup|author=Jim Farber|newspaper=Daily News|publisher=Mortimer Zuckerman|date=November 25, 2013|accessdate=November 25, 2013|location=New York}}</ref> In December, she performed at Jingle Ball concerts in [[Los Angeles]] ([[KIIS-FM Jingle Ball]]), [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|Saint Paul]], [[Atlanta]], New York City, [[Washington, D.C.]], [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]] and [[Sunrise, Florida|Sunrise]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/business/press-releases/miley-cyrus-plans-2014-tour-superstartickets-com-announces-savings-on-miley-cyrus-tickets-1.6425460|title=Miley Cyrus Plans 2014 Tour – SuperStarTickets.com Announces Savings on Miley Cyrus Tickets|newspaper=[[Newsday]]|publisher=[[Cablevision]]|date=November 12, 2013|accessdate=November 16, 2013}}</ref> Cyrus also performed "Wrecking Ball" on ''[[Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve|Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve with Ryan Seacrest]]'' in [[Times Square]] on December 31.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://popcrush.com/miley-cyrus-get-it-right-wrecking-ball-new-years-eve/|title=Miley Cyrus Performs 'Get It Right' + 'Wrecking Ball'on New Year's Eve|author=Amy Sciarretto|publisher=PopCrush|date=December 31, 2013|accessdate=January 1, 2014}}</ref>
An episode of ''[[MTV Unplugged]]'' starring Cyrus premiered through MTV on January 29, 2014;<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/01/21/showbiz/tv/miley-cyrus-unplugged-ew/|title=Miley Cyrus will star in her own 'MTV Unplugged'|author=Ray Rahman|publisher=CNN|date=January 21, 2014|accessdate=January 21, 2014}}</ref> she performed an [[Acoustic music|acoustic]] version of "Wrecking Ball", among several additional tracks from ''Bangerz''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metrolyrics.com/news-story-see-what-songs-miley-cyrus-performed-on-mtvs-unplugged.html|title=See What Songs Miley Cyrus Performed On MTV's 'Unplugged'|publisher=MetroLyrics|date=January 30, 2014|accessdate=February 6, 2014}}</ref> On May 27, 2014 Cyrus performed the song during the [[2014 World Music Awards|World Music Awards]] held in [[Monte Carlo]], [[Monaco]]; where she also won four World Music Awards. She wore a gown with a scenic theme based on flowers during the performance. It received positive reviews for its understated simplicity and strong vocal delivery. Cyrus returned to perform the song during the musical festival on June 21, 2014, [[Summertime Ball]] at [[Wembley Stadium]] of [[London]], in front of 80,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cyrus|first=Miley|date=June 22, 2014|url=http://www.capitalfm.com/artists/miley-cyrus/news/summertime-ball-2014-setlist/|title=Miley Cyrus Brings Her Naughty Side – And Her Sister – To The #CapitalSTB!|publisher=June 21, 2014}}</ref> Cyrus has performed the song during her ongoing [[Bangerz Tour]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/entertainment/Review+Miley+Cyrus+kicks+weird+Bangerz+tour+Vancouver/9511144/story.html|title=Review: Miley Cyrus kicks off weird Bangerz tour in Vancouver|author=Francois Marchand|newspaper=The Vancouver Sun|publisher=Postmedia Network|date=February 15, 2014|accessdate=February 17, 2014}}</ref> A critic from the ''[[Nashville Scene]]'' praised the performance, writing, "Wrecking Ball was sung by Miley and earnestly shouted in unison by the arena, some of the audience tearing up."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashvillecream/archives/2014/08/08/miley-cyrus-w-lily-allen-at-bridgestone-arena-8-8-14|title=Miley Cyrus w/Lily Allen at Bridgestone Arena, 8/8/14|date=August 8, 2014|publisher=''[[Nashville Scene]]''|accessdate=August 9, 2014}}</ref> Blake Hannon praised Cyrus' vocal delivery, writing, "The crowd kept going when things slowed down for Wrecking Ball. It was the highlight of the night, and not because of anything visual. The costumed characters vanished and the screen was black, with Cyrus belting out one of the best pop power ballads in recent memory with only a smattering of lights. It's a reminder that beneath it all, Cyrus has a voice — and a pretty big one, at that."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kentucky.com/2014/08/10/3374057/review-miley-cyrus-at-the-yum.html?sp=/99/684/|title=Review: Miley Cyrus at the Yum! Center in Louisville|author=Hannon, Blake|date=August 10, 2014|publisher=Kentucky|accessdate=August 11, 2014}}</ref>
==Cover versions and media usage== In September 2013, British singer-songwriter [[James Arthur (singer)|James Arthur]] covered "Wrecking Ball" on [[Radio Hamburg]] in Germany.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/09/25/james-arthurs-wrecking-ball-cover-better-than-miley-cyrus-original-4112089/|title=James Arthur’s Wrecking Ball cover better than Miley Cyrus’ original?|newspaper=Metro|publisher=DMG Media|date=September 25, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> Later that month, [[The Gregory Brothers]] released a [[Country music|country]] version, which Laura Vitto from [[Mashable]] felt "trades in Miley's pop-ballad sound for a twangier feel."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2013/09/10/country-wrecking-ball-cover/|title=Listen to This Country-Western Cover of Miley Cyrus' 'Wrecking Ball'|author=Laura Vitto|publisher=Mashable|date=September 10, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> American singer-songwriter [[Alonzo Holt]] released his own rendition in October, which featured vocals from Arthur; it peaked at number 97 on the [[UK Singles Chart]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zobbel.de/cluk/131102cluk.txt|title=Chart Log UK: New Entries Update|publisher=Zobbel|date=November 11, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> and number 71 on the [[Irish Singles Chart]].<ref name="IRE">{{cite web|url=http://www.chart-track.co.uk/index.jsp?c=p%2Fmusicvideo%2Fmusic%2Farchive%2Findex_test.jsp&ct=240001&arch=t&lyr=2013&year=2013&week=43|title=Chart Archive > October 24, 2013|publisher=[[Irish Recorded Music Association]]}}</ref> American group [[Haim (band)|Haim]] covered "Wrecking Ball" during their performance on [[BBC Radio 1]]'s [[Live Lounge]], while the trio [[London Grammar]] sang it for the same session in December.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/events/e49xn3#p01n8v7b|title=Live Lounge London Grammar|publisher=[[BBC Radio 1]]. BBC|date=December 12, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> [[Rumer Willis]] later sang the track during a performance which Chiderah Monde from ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]'' felt "captured more of the emotion behind the song" than Cyrus' version.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/rumer-willis-covers-miley-cyrus-wrecking-ball-article-1.1468089|title=Rumer Willis covers Miley Cyrus’ ‘Wrecking Ball’ in emotional stage performance|author=Chiderah Monde|newspaper=Daily News|publisher=Mortimer Zuckerman|date=September 26, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014|location=New York}}</ref> American singer [[Rebecca Black]] uploaded an acoustic version to her [[YouTube]] channel in November.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=off8TabPlNU|title=Wrecking Ball – Miley Cyrus – (Cover) by Rebecca Black|publisher=[[YouTube]]. [[Google]]|date=November 8, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> Canadian singer Sarah Blackwood of [[Walk Off the Earth]] also released an acoustic version.<ref name="cities97">{{cite web|url=http://www.cities97.com/onair/paul-fletcher-48746/video-sarah-blackwood-walk-off-the-11973461/|title=Video: Sarah Blackwood + Walk Off The Earth – Wrecking Ball|author=Paul Fletcher|publisher=Cities97|accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref>
Danie Geimer, a contestant on the [[The X Factor (U.S. season 3)|third season]] of ''[[The X Factor (U.S. TV series)|The X Factor USA]]'', performed the track during the first live show on October 29,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/videos/x-factor-recap-demi-lovato-tosses-frontrunner-20131030|title='X Factor' Recap: Demi Lovato Tosses Frontrunner|author=Katy Kroll|work=Rolling Stone|publisher=Wenner Media, LLC|date=October 30, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> while Dami Im from the [[The X Factor (Australia season 5)|fifth season]] of ''[[The X Factor (Australian TV series)|The X Factor Australia]]'' sang it in the semi-final round.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yourtv.com.au/blog.aspx?blogentryid=1154059&showcomments=true|title='Better than Miley'? Dami Im's 'Wrecking Ball' stuns X Factor fans|publisher=YourTV. [[MSN]]|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> [[Marley Rose]] ([[Melissa Benoist]]) covered the song and parodied elements of the music video for the ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'' episode "[[The End of Twerk]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/5793078/glee-recap-the-end-of-twerk-episode-not-as-bad-as-it-sounds|title='Glee' Recap: The 'End of Twerk' Episode Not As Bad As It Sounds|author=Rae Votta|work=Billboard|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=November 15, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> [[Christina Grimmie]] sang the song during the Blind Auditions of [[The Voice (U.S. season 6)|sixth season]] of [[The Voice (U.S. TV series)|''The Voice'' USA]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Stampler|first=Laura|title=This "Wrecking Ball" Cover on The Voice Puts Miley to Shame|url=http://entertainment.time.com/2014/02/25/christina-grimmie-wrecking-ball-the-voice/|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=May 7, 2014|date=February 25, 2014}}</ref> Australian artist Kat Jade auditioned with a stripped-back/single-piano version in the third season of [[The Voice (Australia)|''The Voice'' Australia]] after posting a popular acapella version<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J5t8AKkqk6g|title=Wrecking Ball Kat Jade|work=YouTube|accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref> of the song to her Youtube channel.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCKpPbvljQDYa0mHqACGHnDw|title=Kat Jade|work=YouTube|accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref> [["Weird Al" Yankovic]] covered the song as the first in his polka medley "[[List of "Weird Al" Yankovic polka medleys#"NOW That's What I Call Polka!"|NOW That's What I Call Polka!]]" for his 2014 album ''[[Mandatory Fun]]''.<ref name="LinerNotes2">''Mandatory Fun'' ([[liner notes]]). [["Weird Al" Yankovic]]. [[RCA Records]], a division of [[Sony Music Entertainment]]. 2014.</ref> Metal band [[August Burns Red]] covered the song for the compilation album [[Punk Goes Pop 6]]. [[Melisa Cantiveros]] impersonated Miley Cyrus in [[Your Face Sounds Familiar (Philippines season 1)]] and performed this song, which she won the season.
[[50 Cent]] told ''[[NME]]'' that the song was the one he would perform at [[karaoke]]: "Just a big pop song that no one would suspect, just to fuck with them. Make them go, ''What?''"<ref>{{cite journal|first= Gavin |last= Haynes |title= Soundtrack of my life |magazine= ''[[NME]]'' |date= October 1, 2015 |page= 48}}</ref> The song was featured in the film ''[[The Night Before (2015 film)|The Night Before]]''.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}}
==Credits and personnel== Credits adapted from the liner notes of ''[[Bangerz]]''.<ref name="LinerNotes">{{cite AV media notes|title=[[Bangerz]]|others=[[Miley Cyrus]]|year=2013|publisher=RCA Records}}</ref> ;Recording *Engineered at Conway Recording Studios ([[Hollywood]], California); Luke's In the Boo ([[Malibu, California]]); Monster Island Studio ([[New York City]], New York); Maison de Musique ([[Toronto]], Canada); Harmoney Studios (West Hollywood, California); Capitol Studios (Hollywood, California) *Mixed at MixStar Studios ([[Virginia Beach, Virginia]])
;Personnel {{col-begin}}{{div col|2}} *Charlie Bisberat – violin *Mike Caffery – engineering *David Richard Campbell – strings *Steve Churchyard – engineering (strings) *[[Cirkut (record producer)|Cirkut]] – songwriter, producer, programming, instruments *Kevin Connolly – violin *[[Miley Cyrus]] – [[lead vocals]] *[[Dr. Luke]] – songwriter, producer, programming, instruments *Andrew Duckles – viola *Eric Eylands – assistant *Serban Ghenea – mixing *Clint Gibbs – engineering *John Hanes – engineering for mixing *Sven Heidinga – engineering *Suzie Katayama – contracting, cello *Kiyanu Kim – songwriter *Songa Lee – violin *Darrin McCann – viola *[[MoZella|Maureen "MoZella" McDonald]] – songwriter *[[Stephan Moccio]] – songwriter, piano *Grace Oh – violin *Joel Pargman – violin *Alyssa Park – violin *Sara Parkins – violin *Rachael Pindlen – assistant *Steve Richards – cello *Irene Richter – production coordinator *[[Sacha Skarbek]] – songwriter *Rudy Stein – cello *John Wittenberg – violin *[[Steven Wolf]] – drums {{col-end}}
